38677229.review:
C'è un intero settore videoludico, quello dei giochi commerciali a tripla A, che cerca di vendere un pacchetto di fantasie costruite sulla grandiosità dell'esperienza. Grafica fotorealistica, sopraffazione dei sensi, possibilità di gioco multi-stratificate, achievement che richiedono decine se non centinaia di ore di dedizione...

Parallelamente esiste un altro filone, composta da giochi solitamente (ma non necessariamente) afferenti al settore indipendente, che invece vanno in una direzione completamente opposta, dove tutte le componenti del gioco sono estremamente sintetiche e rivolte alla purezza del game design. Questo di solito si traduce in un'estetica molto ricercata, in possibilità di gioco più ridotte ma anche molto più particolari, in un approccio al gameplay molto più adulto, diretto, senza fronzoli.

[i]Devil Daggers[/i] è assolutamente uno dei capisaldi di questa categoria.

Il gameplay è ridotto all'osso: sei in un'arena, piatta e finita, e arrivano orde di mostri, orde che tra l'altro non sono casuali ma sono procedurali. Se uno di loro ti tocca, muori. Devi semplicemente star lì e farli fuori tutti. Hai una sola arma con due modalità di fuoco; se resisti abbastanza arrivi a sbloccarne una terza di dubbia utilità. E quando muori il gioco è finito: non puoi fare altro che ricominciare e cercare di resistere più a lungo. Il gioco tiene traccia del tempo che sei riuscito a sopravvivere, ti mostra il tuo record, e ti ficca una classifica nella quale puoi vedere i risultati globali, quel che hanno fatto i tuoi amici, e i replay del risultato migliore di tutti quanti.

Basta, il gioco sta tutto qui. In cinque minuti hai già visto tutto. Anzi, in cinque minuti ti sei già fatto dieci partite perchè il tuo record di sopravvivenza è di quaranta secondi.

Questa sorta di gameplay minimale come un pallottola, freddo e sintetico come un colpo d'accetta, è peraltro condito da una grafica assolutamente allucinata: un 3D ricoperto di una finta pixel-art che rimanda a certi grandi nomi del passato tipo [i]Doom[/i], coi quali per la verità il gameplay non ha nulla a che vedere ma che evidentemente fa partire un qualche tipo di associazione mentale con un periodo nel quale andavano di moda giochi molto più [i]arcade[/i] di oggi. Da questi il gioco eredita anche il font, che è credo lo stesso che veniva usato in certi giochi tipo [i]Risky Woods[/i]. E poi ci sono i mostri, che sono mucchi di teschi di varie forme e composizioni, mescolati con delle cose tentacolose e insettose di netta impronta pulp; in generale sembra di trovarsi dentro ad un incubo acido inspiegabile e allucinante.

[i]Devil Daggers[/i] viene tra l'altro, a ragione, applaudito per il suo geniale design sonoro: a parte la parvenza di colonna sonora, che sembra essere pure quella una specie di memoria marcia uscita da un Soundblaster dei primi '90 e rimessa in sesto con strumentazioni moderne, gli effetti sonori hanno un'importanza assoluta all'interno del gameplay. Molto più che in altri sparatutto è infatti importantissimo tenere le orecchie tese per riconoscere quali nemici stiano arrivando e da dove, perchè tutti emettono suoni diversi - dal battere i denti al tamburellare le proprie dita insettose sul terreno - e alcuni di essi hanno percorsi altamente prevedibili che è necessario tenersi a mente per evitare di camminare guardandosi continuamente alle spalle.

Insomma, [i]Devil Daggers[/i] da una parte è l'anti-sparatutto per eccellenza, è la negazione più plateale di tutto quanto verso il quale il genere si sia mosso nel corso degli ultimi trent'anni. E parallelamente è però lo sparatutto perfetto, quello più unico, quello più impeccabile e privo di sbavature, quello che o lo ami o lo odi, ma se lo odi lo odi non perchè ti fa ca**re, lo odi perchè sai che è semplicemente qualcosa con il quale tu non hai niente a che spartire, un po' come la pancetta a colazione, che sì, fa bene, però poi ti fa anche schifo perchè tu a colazione sei stato cresciuto col caffè e il toast con marmellata, no? Ecco, [i]Devil Daggers[/i] è così.

For $5, this game is a pretty good "bang" for your buck and can easily keep you occupied, frustrated and pissed off for a good while!

It is a pixelated FPS with a simple concept, kill and survive...You have 4 weapon modes, 2 to start and an upgraded homing weapon, if you are of the few who survive long enough to acquire it and a final upgrade upgrade that is needed for the hardest moments.  Your base weapons are continuaout knife throwing and a kind of burst shotgun effect.

The simple pixelated devilish art design is a pleasure too look at and try your damnedest to avoid and kill.  I really like the simple color palette, allowing for a nice aesthetic, while not detracting from your ultimate goal of survival.


ACHIEVEMENTS:  There is only one achievement...Simply survive for 500 sec (8.33 mins)...With over 118,000 players on the leaderboard, only a little over 100 have achieved 100%...Good luck!

37985812.review: The most painful seconds of my life. I love it!

37985056.review:
Devil Daggers is an easy to play with 4 arrow keys and mouse aim to shoot, hard to put down, simple first person shooter that puts you in a horrific micro world on a single platform face to face with thousands of skulls. These skulls are relentless in their pursuit of you. You need to stay moving and look around at all times or you'll turn around into a wall of bouncing bone. Most attempts last less than a minute, because once you get hit that's it. You're sent to the leaderboard, but you can get back to the game with a click of the retry.

Shooting is easy, hold down the mouse button and a steady stream of dagger bullets will flow from your hand. Press the mouse button and they will shotgun out in a fat burst of projectiles. The problem with that is I was never able to consistently fire that shotgun burst after 40 minutes, so I just never used it. The enemies are always on top of you. Enemies take a bit of damage before they dissipate and they'll turn a bright orange when low on health. What's that... an easy mode where enemies have less health? No... welcome to the pit, you were sent here to die.

Its a needlessly difficult game, a bit unfair, there is no warning you're about to die from a wall of skulls other than you know enemies will always be on top of you. That's just the arcade nature of it. If you don't want to put up with that, then this clearly isn't the game for you. Because you can just get right back into the thick of it, there's no sort of lost progress. You have what you have going in as you will have when you die.

While most first person shooters waste time on levels and enemy variety, Devil Daggers keeps it simple. You are here. You will never leave here. You will run around in an infinite circle bull fighting enemies until you die. Towers will crop up to spawn enemies. Usually one burst pours a dozen or so skulls with a secondary horned skull that does laps. These horned skulls drop gems. Destroying enemy towers will dislodge red gems. When you stop shooting, the gems get pulled toward you.  Collecting gems will eventually upgrade how many daggers you can shoot.

Devil Daggers puts forth a convincing environment and great sound design. Other than that, if you have seen a minute of it, you have seen the game. Sure more enemies happen, but there's little variety here when even the most basic enemy will kill you dead.

With all the frustration and aggravation, its still a tough game to put down as you're dumped right back into the game with nothing lost. You can keep running on that treadmill away from enemies for all eternity until you finally realize how much time has passed by.

Un seul et unique but (et un seul mode de jeu d'ailleurs) : survivre le plus longtemps possible. Facile à dire mais vraiment difficile à faire. Devil daggers n'est pas un jeu facile, loin de là ! Vous tirez, vous tuez, vous esquivez...et vous mourrez. Puis vous recommencer pour améliorer votre temps de survie. 

Bref, rien de bien original mais le jeu a ce petit quelque chose qui le rend unique. Les graphismes, l'ambiance, les ennemis, etc... font de ce jeu, un petit jeu indé qui vaut largement le coup ! Après, ce n'est pas le genre jeu auquel vous y jouerez des centaines d'heures (à part pour les accros du genre ou les "try-hardeurs"). Pourtant, ça vaut quand même la peine d'essayer ! 

Ah oui, petite précision, ce jeu fait stresser ! Non pas pour le côté "horreur" mais pour le côté "try-hard" ! Si vous aimez aussi rager, c'est fait pour vous.

Je le recommande donc.

37453798.review:
JUMP__ JUMP__ JUMP__ JUMP__ STREEEEEAM-JUMP__JUMP__JUMP__STREEEEEAM-JUMP-BLAST-BLAST-JUMP

Devil Daggers is the best pieces of quake made into one whole endless level. It's minimalism and arcade style pacing is masterfully crafted for a pleasant learning curve that will keep you in this strange and hellish platform for quite a while. 

Aesthetically it seeks to replicate the look and feel of the very firt 3d polygon games and the low res capabilities of machines at the time of their conception. The pallete is greys, reds, oranges, and muted borwn on a black canvas. The sounds are purposefully low res. The mechanics are simple. The physics are enchanting. The ai is predictable but the games focus on movement is so crucial that you are always learning new techniques. 

The best part of the game however is the championing of score by time videos that you can watch and learn from. The tutorial is built into the failure. As you continuously fail you are lead to leader boards with the ability to watch the scores of those just above and below you as well as those of your friends. 

It is a game that has brought out the best of the old school 3d shooter, and yet it has no map, its just a blank plane with spawning enemies. 

Super impressive, would love to see what Sorath has next. 

Enjoy.

36922707.review:
If you want your nerves wrecked and your fingers reduced to gnarled carrots, this is for you. 
Beating your own high score in Devil Daggers is one of the most satisfying feelings granted in a video game. The challenge and heart palpitations leading up to that sweet little *ding* are always worth it. Climbing the leaderboards is grueling, yet the intuitive replay system greatly assists players to learn from their own mistakes, as well as pick up some tricks from the top 100 players. The visual and aural design is on point, with the enemies being easily locatable by standing out against the black abyss, whilst emitting terrifyingly discernable noises. 
Patience is a virtue, and death is your tutor.

36898915.review:
This game made skulls scary again.

Pick up the Devil Dagger and become doomed to fight an endless battle against skulls, skulls with horns, horrifying spider skulls, and other skull-monstrosities. This is an arcade-type game where the goal is to survive for as many seconds as you can, resulting in a higher leaderboard position. As for the end-goal of the game, if you survive for a really long time, you'll be awarded with the game's sole achievement, perhaps the ultimate bragging-right.
The gameplay is relatively simple. You only have two weapons: a shotgun-blast of daggers(single clicks) and a rapid-fire stream of daggers (holding down the mouse button). You die from touching anything, and most enemies' method of attack is to either chase you or act as obstacles you can accidentally run into. Most enemies are faster than you if moving in a straight line, so part of playing well is to frequently make tight turns so that most enemies have a tougher time catching up to you. Like many classic FPS games, you can bunnyhop to increase your speed and fire a blast at the floor to propel yourself into the air. These abilities can sometimes get you out of tight situations. Certain enemies drop red gems, and if you stop shooting for a few seconds you can attract any gems toward you. At certain amounts of gems collected, you gain firepower.
The difficulty gives intense satisfaction when you finally beat your or a freind's high score, even if by just a few seconds. Despite how hard it is, the mechanics of the game are so well-refined that no deaths ever feel unfair or cheap. That's not to say that you won't get frustrated with yourself if you're having a bad session.
The artstyle is also really cool; it has a dark PSX/early-3D look to it. That in addition to the fantastic sound design and lighting effects make this game really stand out as something unique.
If you enjoyed Doom, its 2016 reboot or other fast-paced FPS classics and want something simple, challenging and addictive to play at the drop of a hat, I highly recommend Devil Daggers.

36896306.review:
Devil Daggers harks back to arcade games of old. The goal is simple. Survive for as long as you can to get the highest score. 

     It may seem surface level and short lived, but something about it just keeps bringing me back. It gets your pulse pounding. It gets your adrenaline rushing. It gets your mind melting in both anger and satisfaction at the same time, and as impressive as that may seem, it is all under the simple guise of getting a high score. 

     How is that possible? Other FPS arena games don't capture the simple, yet oh-so addictive feel of this game. Maybe it's the sound design. Maybe it's the nostalgic graphics. Maybe it's the breakneck pace. Whatever it is, it keeps us chasing after something as simple as a high score. I can't recommend giving this cheap, quick, amazing game enough. You're only missing out by not trying it.

36656008.review: I have a love/hate relationship with this game, which is by no means a fault with the game itself. The game is heavily stylized to look as though it came from the Playstation 1 era and placed in what looks to me like a lovecraftian nightmare. It is a difficult, almost quake esque arena-shooter. There is only one level and your job is to do one thing: Survive. Doing just that is by no means an easy task as the average play session (at least for me) lasts only about a minute to a minute and a half (if even that, might feel longer with everything it throws at you). As soon as you die, you are met with a leaderboard showing how long you lasted that time as well as others, which is of course, standard. BUT, it also gives you the option to watch the replays of all the players on said leaderboard, so if you find yourself getting stuck in one particular section you might be able to learn how to better deal with a scenario from studying the higher ranked players, i absolutely love this feature. Overall, if you enjoy games you can play in short bursts, and also love the feeling of quake esque shooters this might just be worth your five dollars. 8,5/10

36631590.review:
Devil Daggers is ONE HELL OF A GAME! Me and a friend both bought it at respectively the same time and must I say it's been an adventure! We both started out, running around on the playing field just trying to see who can stay alive the longest and beat each others scores. But as time went on, we slowly started to see that there's multiple tactics to really survive. 

Devil Daggers is a challenging game with a interesting learning curve, yet features awesome/satisfying gameplay elements like perfect jumping, shotgun shooting, and Rocket Jumping! You'll feel so much momentum and power in this game!

As you start to get farther and farther, more challenging enemies like spiders, bigger skulls, more spawners and even centepedes come out of the abyss to kill you. But there is a learning curve to this game because the same enemies will appear at an allocated time. 

So as you make it to (120 seconds) a centepede appears, and at first you'll think to yourself (HOW DO I EVEN KILL THIS THING!) But the more you make it to that time the more you'll be able to practice that segment. It's like a system that pulls you in because you have to work hard to even be able to practice and I assure you the reward of progression is so satisfying!

Another very cool feature is that you get red gems that increase your firepower, making both your machine gun and shotgun shoot more daggers at a time. And once you get the 3rd upgrade, (70 Gems) you can fire homing daggers that OBLITHERATE everything on the stage. (Almost everything)

The game lets you keep track of your friends scores, with results being uploaded in real time, and you can even watch replays of your friends instantly.

Me and my friend are probably trying to beat each others scores as you're reading this review. 

Just get this game please, it's an awesome time waster that is so addicting. Best 5$ you will ever spend.

35865563.review: This game has become one of my all time favorites. It is pretty quick to start, pretty easy to pick up, and nearly impossible to master. However, if you want to play such a game, you need to able to pump some time into it. The first few records are quick to come by and easy to pass, but when you reach midgame, things get to be a bit tougher. I say mid game, but really it's more like silver times. There really is no endgame, just an endless loop of pure hell that speeds up as it goes. But enough of the rambling, and back to the point. Once you reach times like those, the difficulty suddenly hits a massive incline that looks something like a straight up 90 degree angle. When you pass such a thing though, it gets easier till about the gold ranks, and does so again, except much worse this time around. If you eventually pass the gold ranks, you reach the red or devil dagger ranks. Let me tell you, I spent more time getting past the gold dagger ranks than I spent getting past all the others combined, but it was worth it. I have reached the 500 mark, and passed it, and I can tell you that there is when the real fun begins. Really, nothing to me is more fun than this hellish nightmare we call Devil Daggers.

35822835.review:
Devil Daggers, in un certo senso, incarna perfettamente la filosofia hardcore applicata al mondo dei videogiochi. Eccezionale nella sua semplicità, il gioco ruota intorno ad alcuni elementi essenziali: gameplay ad altissimo tasso tecnico, curva di difficoltà a crescita rapida e vertiginosa e comparto grafico essenziale, reminiscente degli FPS in 3D della meta degli anni '90.

Armati esclusivamente di daghe magiche, il nostro obiettivo in Devil Daggers sarà quello di respingere il più a lungo possibile le ondate demoniache che verranno periodicamente evocate nell'arena di battaglia. Una volta uccisi, alcuni nemici lasceranno cadere dei cristalli rossi, che potremo accumulare per incrementare la potenza di fuoco dei nostri pugnali; questi dispongono di due modalità di fuoco, la prima più veloce e precisa, la seconda con una rosa più ampia, più lenta ma potenzialmente più dannosa. Per quanto agili e reattivi, inevitabilmente prima o poi subiremo un colpo, nel qual caso dopo una schermata riassuntiva con tempi, punteggi e statistiche dovremo ricominciare tutto da capo.

Un vecchio detto recita che "il Diavolo è nei dettagli", e questo gioco sembra esserne la prova lampante. Per quanto sia concettualmente semplice (spara ad ogni cosa che si muove, schiva quello che non riesci ad uccidere), alla prova dei fatti senza la giusta preparazione le prime partite si concluderanno in una manciata di secondi con dei sonori fallimenti e un crescente senso di frustrazione. Con una buona dose di pazienza e tanta, tantissima pratica riusciremo piano piano a migliorare il nostro score: il gioco NON è battibile, quindi la voglia di superare il proprio record e scalare le classifiche di Steam diventa necessariamente il solo e unico stimolo a proseguire.

Le immagini piuttosto sgranate ci riportano all'epoca dei primi rendering 3D, rievocando in una certa misura lo stile di QUAKE; il motore grafico di Devil Daggers è leggero e performante, con framerate granitico anche nei frangenti più caotici. Gli effetti sonori (risate demoniache, sospiri, versi animaleschi) sono tutti di ottima fattura, e l'audio direzionale da il grande vantaggio di poter stabilire con anticipo la direzione di arrivo dei nemici, anticipandone le mosse; in quest'ottica il peso dell'assenza di un soundtrack vero e proprio non si fa assolutamente sentire.

E' difficile NON consigliare Devil Daggers, ma al tempo stesso bisogna riconoscere che si tratta di un prodotto di nicchia, diretto ai veri appassionati di FPS old-school e in particolar modo a quella player base hardcore che ama misurarsi con livelli di difficoltà proibitivi. Se vi riconoscete in una di queste categorie e non avete ancora provato Devil Daggers dovete assolutamente rimediare: vi state perdendo uno degli FPS arcade più adrenalinici e skill-demanding di sempre. In caso contrario, statene alla larga: frustrazione e rabbia sono sempre dietro l'angolo, e senza la giusta spinta il gioco perde subito gran parte del proprio appeal.

[i][b]Se questa recensione ti è piaciuta clicca "Segui" sulla [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/retrogamingcafe/curation]pagina del Curatore[/url] del mio gruppo: sarai sempre aggiornato con i miei personali consigli e le recensioni dei migliori titoli indie/retro/roguelite in circolazione![/b][/i]

35432506.review:
So what is Devil Daggers?

Devil Daggers is a FPS game that is great when:
-you have too much time.
-you're in a loading screen.
-you're super bored.

So there is no story behind the game, you press play, grab some daggers, and shoot the hell out of demons (no pun intended). Easy you may think, but no no no. You spawn on a platform and suddenly there spawns a weird thingy with a red point on it. You look at it and wondering:"I have no clue about this bullshit" and then you're dead. You see a leaderboard that tells you nothing only how hard you suck. So you start again and realise that there are skulls coming out of the Hovering thing, so you just shoot'em and hey they die (can skulls die?). So you think:"Hm thats pretty easy" until you get to ~40-50 seconds. There a shitload of floating Skullspawner now and all you do is walking Backwards and trying to hit at least something. You cant really overlook the enemies because they are just some Brown flying shitheads in front a background that is even blacker than  vantablack. Jumping around the stone platform you suddenly realise some big things swirling around the map. You go to them and...
You die.
So you start again and try run after run to beat your record until the last guy finsihed with loading (LoL or something like that) and you close the game.

The Goal?
Survive as long as you can.
How?
Shoot the Skulls that are flying around but dont touch'em!
Why?
I dont know man you get a dagger but you can't stab anyone.

What i like about the game:
If I'm bored i just go to Library Start the game do 10-15 Rounds and close the game. Its not really a game that you play 4 Hours straight.
It has a really cool art Style.
The game isnt going in that deep, like Binding of Isaac, where you find Items, have to clear rooms, have a Story. No its just pressing play and start shooting.

What i dont like about the game:
300M/B download size? I mean its not that much but for comparison, Spintires only has 500M/B and its full 3D game with more than just one Map.
There is only one Map, one gamemode, no Support for modding (atleast i didnt see any mods).

So is it worth the 5€? I think so!

35402063.review:
Devil Daggers by ‘Sorath’ is a fresh take on an old genre. If you say the first-person market is oversaturated, you may be making an understatement. Some of the most popular games of this decade and this past few years were first person shooters. Devil Daggers is different; instead of killing yet another group of terrorists in games like Counter-Strike or Insurgency, or killing space aliens in Halo or Destiny, Devil Daggers focuses on skill and takes you back to the days of Doom and Quake.

Devil Daggers is a fast-paced shooter set in hell and makes you face ‘endless legions of demons’. The movement is incredibly fast and your weapons are throwable daggers. While there are only 13 types of enemies, every round feels different and unique. This game will make you feel frustrated and angry, but you come to back to it for another round. 

I recommend you play this game with headphones because this game is terrifying. The endless horde of enemies and the wonderful sound design make this game a great one, especially for late at night with the lights turned off.

35229615.review:
I spent most of my playtime watching replays from other people. there is a charm in overanalyzing the struggle of other players just so you can implement these sick moves yourself and then die so that people can watch your own struggle and overanalyze it.

Somehow a single map, with the same enemy spawn times was worth all this time for me.
It's a leaderboard climbing game where you can watch replays. This in a vacuum would have never dragged me in. I think what did it is the personality and character of the game, the uniqueness of the enemies and the amount of stuff it throws at you.
The clear disadvantage is that because the game is supposed to be simple and hard, you are locked in a strict list of deadlines to meet not allowing much divergence. Also there is one official level even tho there is a way around it.

Not for everybody, you need some serious base skills to get where the game shines the most.
I would however recommend it even for just watching replays of capable players, that in itself was worth the price for me because i witnessed how players can radically improve over time subtly changing their style which was very interesting.

The game is really simplistic, you have three weapons and your goal is just to survive as long as you can.
It may seem boring, but what's special about this game is it's simplicity and challenging difficulty. You can barely get a grip here. It can happen, but only if you're doing well.
If you're new and just getting into all the challenges, getting past them might seem as a pain in the butt, but honestly after you git gud, then the further you go, the better you feel. You know you're doing good. If not, you constantly try to pump up your skill level. And trust me, if you're patient it's going to happen sometime. If you die, you know you can do better. So you retry with a hope of beating the score.
And that's the thing: Devil Daggers sucks you in.
You never really know when you can really give up, and you always feel like you can beat your score. That's what I both hate and like about this game. What I value about games is replayability, and Devil Daggers provides that, even though it's simple as hell.
Would highly recommend.

It's also a pretty good game for letting your anger out. Just play this, turn on some good rock music and up you go.

35142069.review:
For $5 this is a steal. It's insanely addictive and you'll be constantly trying to raise your high score. PLus you can view a replay of your top score and replays of other people, including friends who play the game as well.

There is only one achievement and only ~0.1% of Devil Daggers players have earned it; you need to survive for 500 seconds/8 minutes and 20 seconds. It sounds simple enough, until you've actually played the game.

Do not be discouraged when you consistently die less than a minute into a run. This is normal. Eventually you'll get the hang of things, learn what spawns when, what strategies work, and whatnot.

Since there is no tutorial, here's some things you'll have to know vefore getting started:
- Some enemies (i.e. squids, horned skulls, spiders, etc.), drop red crystals.
- If you stop firing, the red crystals will float towards you.
- Collecting 10 red crystals will get you your first weapon upgrade.
- Collect more crystals to earn more upgrades.

- Holding down the "fire" button (LMB by default) will fire daggers much like a machine gun.
- Tapping the "fire" button (LMB by default) will shoot out daggers like a shotgun blast.
- You can traverse farther distances than usual by jumping and and dagger blasting the ground at the same time (tap the "fire" button).

35136437.review:
[h1][b]Devil Daggers - Death in a video game form.[/b][/h1]

It's just You, Your daggers and a f*ckload of enemies.
In Devil Daggers You cannot ultimately win, You cannot "complete" the game. Death will always be waiting at the end of Your efforts. But that's what makes this game special. The time You survived is equal to the amount of skill and determination You have. (Not even luck can save You here, it'll maybe grant You one or two seconds but nothing more). Devil Daggers is brutal, unforgiving, it doesn't allow You to make mistakes.

That being said, it's not a game for everyone. Only people who are willing to offer a piece of their lives to refine movement, shooting techniques or monster spawning patters and to make it their second nature, only these people can really enjoy Devil Daggers. Seeing even a tiny bit of progress towards the achievement (and past it) is emotionally rewarding. It's not like You unlocked some new weapon that makes the game easier. No. It's You. It's always about You. Every bit of progress means that YOU are a better player. You rised above Your weaknesses and conquered them, and not many games can evoke this feeling...

[i]Devil Daggers sucked me into its hellish dimension, it wants me there, it wants to torture me, make me suffer, it wants to see me dead, over and over and over again... but, I'm still standing, fighting against my inescapeable destiny. I'll be dead anyway, but I won't give up. Not until I'll give everything I got.[/i]

34926860.review:
Do you miss the days where games were simply "blast stuff forever?" Is Hell your vacation destination? Do you wish you could shoot knives out of your hand so fast it looks like a polygonal flamethrower? 

Also, do you not mind dying?

Devil Daggers is a really simple game. It honestly is just shoot things until you die; that's the entire game. The tricky bit is to last as long as possible without dying, which is so much easier to say than to do. The longest round of Devil Daggers I've had was around 2 minutes, and that took a lot of effort and practice. In fact, the only achievement in the game asks you to survive  500 seconds, or 8 minutes and 20 seconds. At the time of this writing, 0.1% of all players of Devil Daggers have managed 500 seconds.

This literal hell of shoot, die, repeat is still very engaging though. It's based on Arena shooters of old (in particular it reminds me of Quake) that featured mechanics like Strafe Jumping to build up speed and "rocket" jumping, and keeping an older looking demonic vibe to all the enemies.

Which fits well. The Vantablack level of darkness frames a stone platform, where all the shooting happens. Over the course of a run, specific enemies will spawn in and around the platform, screaming and screeching to life in a horrifying way. Devil Daggers is definitely best played with headphones on, since the expertly engineered audio is not only immersive and terrible to behold, but absolutely essential in pinpointing where enemies are coming from. This, combined with tight controls and simple shooting mechanics mean that players are easily sucked into the dark abyss that is Devil Daggers.

So what lives down there in the dark? As soon as you pick up your dagger, the game throws all kinds of horrible things at you; chattering hordes of skulls, floating spiders, gargantuan centipedes... there are 13 enemy types in all, but they all work together beautifully. Enemies in Devil Daggers will always spawn at certain time periods, meaning that (with practice) you can predict what's coming next and how to handle them. It's insanely well tuned, and absolutely brutally hard to overcome without being obtuse. Repeated attempts see improvement, and players that pay attention and learn the rhythms of the game can get pretty far in.

To help the player, you can upgrade your base weapon by collecting red stones from dead enemies. So long as you're not firing, the stones travel directly to the player, so good play requires knowing when you need to shoot, and when you need to get precious stones. With enough of the things, players get an improved weapon; faster firing rates, more damage, and eventually a panic button that fires homing daggers all over the place. It's a simple mechanic that requires practice to really get the hang of, since too much time spent collecting stones means time spent not shooting, and time not spent shooting is time enough for the hordes you're facing to overwhelm you.

The reward for all this is minimal, though. If you're not into arcade-style high scores and competition, then Devil Daggers will be an absolute waste. The entire point of the game is surviving the longest you possibly can, and if leaderboards or personal bests aren't your thing, then this game isn't for you; but if that type of masochism appeals to your tastes, then guess what? This game is literally built for specifically that.

In order to help players learn, Devil Daggers saves the replays of a player's personal best, and makes them available to everyone for viewing. You can actually watch the best players in the game get their high score from their perspective, and learn how they managed it. It'll obviously be tougher than it looks, but replays are still insightful and helpful for those looking to get one of the hardest achievements I've ever seen.

Devil Daggers sits at a $5.49 CAD on Steam, which is perfect for 11 hours I've put into it so far. It's a really focused, tightly tuned shooter that, for those who are looking for brilliantly designed, satisfying mechanics from their 1990's arcade shooters, is an absolutely great time.

34812999.review:
A game can be great or terrible for a number of reasons; recently we've seen examples of games failing in the AAA market due to horrible stories, bad character development, etc...

Devil Daggers has no story nor characters, so what is *does* have better be good.
And it is. Very much so.

What Devil Daggers does offer to the player is a seamless FPS survival arena with incredibly tight 90's-era controls, immense replayability, enchanting and original graphics, and some of the absolute best sound design I've ever heard in a video game.

**Controls & Game Flow**
Anyone who grew up with or even simply played a game like Quake or Doom knows that when it comes to movement, what is realistic is not always fun. Many modern titles include realistic movement speed, reloading, little to no jumping, and the ability to interact with objects (stopping the flow). Quake was not like this. Quake rewarded the player for taking advantage of the engine by bunny-hopping and strafing, and DOOM never interrupted the action with cutscenes or reloading. Devil Daggers would be nothing without tight controls, and it's safe to say that it actually *improved* on the high-skill-ceiling controls of 90's-FPS titles (mastering modern mechanics such as the "rocket jump"). Like a bullet hell, your actual hitbox is very small, smaller than you think it is. The pinpoint-precision occasionally demanded by Devil Daggers is one of its biggest strengths. 

**Replayability & Advancement**
There are no permanent upgrades in Devil Daggers. Only your skill will save you. The challenge offered to the player, as well as the golden, elusive reward of the DEVIL DAGGER achievement (the one and only achievement, achieved by a mere 98 people at the time of writing) provides a scenario where playing and replaying are encouraged, and doing so will really open up opportunity to get better at the game, keeping you constantly challenging your Personal Best.

**Visual & Audio Design**
Aethetically and functionally, both the graphical and audio design are stellar. You can see how precise and minimalist the graphics are from the trailers. While minimalist, the eerie pixelated visuals of Devil Daggers manage to be very unique to the title. But the department in which the game really shines is its audio design. Every enemy makes a unique sound, easily recognizable, and thanks to the game's simulated 3D-surround sound capabilities, with headphones on you can determine the location and distance of enemies based solely on sound, and do so consistently. Situational and spatial awareness are absolutely essential in Devil Daggers, and the sound design keeps no information from you in this regard. Hearing is truly just as important as seeing in this game, and no other FPS I've played has been able to say the same.

**Conclusion**
For $4.99, Devil Daggers is definitely worth your time. Even though the majority of us will in all likelihood never "beat" the game, Devil Daggers is about the adventure, the constant pursuit of that end goal. And in this pursuit the game really shines.

34356242.review:
Make no mistake what you're getting with this game. It is one punishing arena full of enemies that keep spawning until you die, and there is no real progression once you hit a few minutes without dying. But to this day, I can't get [b]anywhere near[/b] that point, and I'm still totally engaged. 

What it ends up being is a skill tester, and one that in my opinion is nearly perfect. The sound design is incredible. I can literally dance my way backwards through a crowd of enemies knowing who and where they are by sound alone. The graphics are low-res, but the art design is excellent and the whole thing just feels creepier because of the vague definition around the pixels on my 1080P monitor. And the controls are so tight you'll feel like a demon god as you climb the (admittedly high) difficulty curve. The longest I can last is a couple minutes even when I'm in top form, but I know every time I die that it was my fault, and the game allows for some incredibly tight maneuvers if you can pull them off. It's like some wierd lovechild of DOOM and Ubermosh, and I love it to pieces.

[b]TL;DR[/b]
This game has its creepy, satanic mood down perfectly. This game has its very high skill curve down perfectly. This game has its combination of frustration and addictiveness down perfectly. If you want punishment and pitch-perfect design, this game has you down perfectly too. This is hell. Welcome.

34240468.review:
While Devil Daggers lacks many of the features modern FPS games boast, such as the ability to aim down sights, the ability to move at more than one speed, a story, and, in fact, guns, that simply stops it from getting bogged down by unnecessary mechanics, offering possibly the purest FPS gameplay one can find.

The player's abilities are extremely limited, being able to run, jump, hold left click for a machine gun style firing pattern, and double click for a shotgun style blast, but this ensures the player always knows what they can do, they can do it quickly, and they can switch between shooting styles with a fluidity reminiscent of Devil May Cry's on the fly Gun and Devil Arm switching.

These simple mechanics mesh with some outstanding enemy design to create tense battles, as enemies surround the player from all sides. While each enemy is programmed to behave in a certain way, the sheer volume of Lovecraftian horrors that spawn in the arena makes keeping track of them difficult, ensuring that the player is always kept on their toes. Thanks to the incredible sound design, each enemy has its own distinctive sound, which is necessary with the first person perspective to keep track of the arena.

If that sounds difficult, it's because it is- the game tasks the player with surviving for as long as possible, then uploads players' best times to a global leaderboard. The world record currently stands at a little over 1000 seconds, which equates to around 17 minutes. Most players' average campaign time will be between 45 and 60 seconds, with the game's only achievement being offered to the 0.1% of players that manage to survive for 500 seconds or more. This is not a game for people who won't enjoy dying over and again, or those looking for an in-depth story, but for those willing to be overwhelmed in an extremely difficult game with the only incentive being to "git gud", Devil Daggers is a good place to start.

34216473.review:
I've never really been a fan of those incredibly fast paced shooters such as Doom or Quake. Something about them never seemed all that appealing. My friend is absolutely obsessed with those types of games and will always tell me how much of an idiot I am for not playing them and that I should really give them a shot. So, as a compromise,I bought this. 

Devil Daggers is a great game but also a very challenging one. The idea is simple enough. You just need to survive for as long as you can on a hellish platform as wave after wave of enemies swarms you. Sounds kind of dull now that I've written it, but it is anything but. You really need to learn to master this games mechanics if you ever want to get a time higher than 200 seconds. You need to be know the weapon better than the back of your hand (ironic seeing as the weapon IS your hand) and how to best utilize it for each enemy. Rocket jumping, shotgun blasting, short burst, bullet damage, precise aiming and strafing is necessary if you want to prevail. 

The enemys are introduced slowly, but you better get used to them pretty quick, because the game is going to throw tons of them at you. Each enemy poses its own challenges, such as the flying monsters requiring you to shoot off every gem from its body before it will die, or the egg spawners who can steal your upgrade gems and turn them into more demons. The design of the demons is incredible and can make some of them really unsettling. Turning around and seeing a floating dark skull inches away from your face can be surprisingly scary when your not expecting it. Each demon has its own AI aswell, which gives them another layer of challenge and interesting design. 

I will also quickly note that I love the sound design on this game. Wearing headphones or having good speakers can help you hear where the enemys are going to spawn, which sounds overpowered but actually just gives you a fair chance at staying alive. It is a great feature and I am very impressed with how accurate it is. 

If its not obvious, I love this game. I think it is a fantastic and well executed fast paced shooter that really rewards you for your time and effort. A must have. 

8/10

(P.S. Even after playing this for as long as I have and loving how it handles, I'm still not interested in Doom or Quake. And weirdly, my mate, who I said loves those games at the start of this review, doesn't actually like this game very much. Go figure.)

34142162.review:
11/10 will blow my brains out again. One day, I will earn the sole achievement that resides within the hell that is Devil Daggers, but until then, I remain an empty, broken husk of a man that once was.

[h1]But seriously,[/h1]

I do recommend this game for fans of speedrunners/speedshooters/perma death/nostalgic feelings/[i]suicide[/i]/difficulty/minimalism/trying to break high scores/going insane/ and amounting to nothing.

Devil Daggers is a relentlessly brutal, albeit very minimalistic FPS. The "goal" of the game is to survive for 500 seconds or longer. The Devil Dagger achievement remains one of, if not the most elusive Steam achievements on record, and with good reason. While most players will never snag the single achievement Devil Daggers has to offer, there is still some fun to be had. The art style is a unique homage to 90's FPS's & arcade games, and fits surprisingly well; it's cheap; it's challenging; and most importantly, it's entertaining. [b]FAIR WARNING:[/b] Devil Daggers is [b][i]NOT[/i][/b] for the faint of heart, or the easily irritated. This game is not for everyone, but if you are interested in it, you will most likely get some enjoyment out of it.

34134283.review:
I have streamed this game on twitch. That doesn't mean much of anything... but what does matter is how utterly addictive that is. The game is built to be a quake/doom version of Flappy Bird.

You try your damn best to get just slightly further than you did the time before. The game taunts you with your friends scores, as well as those around the world. It uploads the best runs for each person for all to see. So you try. And try.

And try some more.

But it barely matters because a skull manages to slip behind you and wacks you.

Then you get an alert that your friend beat your score.

So you get utterly determined... you HAVE to be the best amongst your friends.

Absolutely the best social disorder game ever... you will consider murdering your friends after a time simply to protect your high score.

34128205.review:
This is a fun and brutal little FPS game with an early 90's feel and some creepy lighting and sound effects. You start in a dark wall-less room, pick up your weapon/ability (it's actually unclear) and start to wonder what you should be doing when you suddenly get swooped at by skulls and killed. I established that there are towers with gems to collect and that they spawn the skulls but that's about as far as I got. 

Devil Daggers has one achievement on Steam, but don't be thinking it'll be an easy 100% completion. You need to stay alive for 500 seconds (just over 8 mins), which sounds straight forward until you realise that only <0.1% of the game's players have managed it. In my 20 minutes of playtime my maximum time spent alive was 33 seconds!

I got this game as part of a mini Humble Bundle and paid only a few $$ for this and a number of other titles so I can't complain about value for money. I would not be saying the same if I had paid the full price of £3.99. It is an enjoyable game, nicely made, but it a difficult and suited best to short induvial sittings. With no save mode, variation or progression; it is not going to provide hours of entertainment; I would recommend this game but ideally on sale and only if you know what you're getting.

Simply put, you feel "at peace" right as the game starts. Time slows down and you can hit every dagger dead center with no issues. 

I lightly farmed perfectly and got Level 3 midway through killing the first centipede. I started feeling cocky and then proceeded to completely screw up the 2 3-Pack spider waves. Immediately after, the 6-pack of Squid 1's spawn and I raced around the arena praying to a god I've never believed in and managed to clear the arena. 

After clearing the arena, three Squid 2's and a Squid 3 spawn and I f*cking kill everything.

The ground shakes after I killed the Squid 3, and three Gigapedes spawn, each with 50 gems, just scraping one of them would get me the Level 4 upgrade. I scraped one, got 40-something gems and "absorbed" the gems. Two Level-1 spiders spawn as well as a new type of spider, the dreaded... Spider 2...? Okay, yeah, Spider 2, not just a Giga-Spider. Anyways, I kill all 3 of the spiders, scrape again, get Level 4, 3 more spiders spawn, completely wipe the floor with them, and then three Squid 3's spawn. I kill those as well. After killing the Squid 3's, I spewed out at least 30 homing (f/d)aggers and ran around the arena as a handful of Squid 2's spawn. I kill all the skulls, destroy the Squid 2's, and finish off the Gigapedes.

The ground shakes violently as I see a shimmering, red, and also gargantuan figure start to materialize in front of me. And before I know it, the screen flashes red, the black abyss turns into a hellscape before my eyes and in the center of the arena, I saw what looked like the Statue of Liberty's head was chopped off, set on fire, and was given a $100 coupon for Hot Topic. I then learned that the name of this enemy is simply the [b] [i] LEVIATHAN. [/i] [/b]

I ran around the arena like a headless chicken for the next minute and a half and another gigapede spawns, complete with two Spider 1's and a Giga-Spid- I mean Spider 2. I kill the spiders and then continue running around like a lost child in a Wal-mart and I hear this ear-drum shattering noise behind me. I flick my mouse around and I see a Skull 4 that was recently inside of the Leviathan, shrieking like a banshee too. Horrified, I spam the shotgun and the beast wouldn't slow down. I eventually killed it, but not long before I looked at the top of my screen, with 497 seconds, I knew for a fact that I was going to hit the 500 second mark. Time slowed down to a screeching halt as I bunny hopped away from the skulls, and I did it. I hit 500. I die and then a shiny, beautiful, red dagger flashes on my screen, spinning.

I then proceeded to jump out of my chair with enough energy to send my self into the f*cking ceiling.

11/10

33873899.review:
Devil Daggers is the closest thing I have ever seen to a perfect game. I have never played anything like it. You know, back when I used to play games for 30 - 40 hours every two weeks, it was divided between at least 3 - 5 games. In less than a single week, Devil Daggers has not only taken my playtime from the last two weeks from 4.9 hours to 20 hours+, but it has made up about half (as of writing this) of my normal two-week playtime TOTAL. As of writing this, with 16 hours logged (probably 4 of which were spent on the homescreen), my high score is 192 seconds. So what is it about this game that's so captivating? Well, I'm gonna explain it all.

The Visuals:

The low-poly 3D models mixed with an extremely low resolution and dark, gritty color palette make this game look very unique. Even when things are far away and they are being drawn using less of the massive pixels in the resolution, you can tell exactly what you're looking at.

The Game Mechanics:

I have NEVER played a game with game mechanics as tight and polished as this one. Not even the overrated games of today (CS:GO, Rocket League, Overwatch, and so on) can come close to this. It's not overcrowded with different game mechanics but what they have work together in a very meaningful and seamless way. From the Rocket Jumping, Momentum, and Two-Purpose Daggers with travel time, to the spawn times of the enemies, the swarm mechanics (which I've never seen done so well before), and the shape/size of the platform. Everything. Not ONCE have I died and considered myself to have been killed by anything other than my own incompetence, and for a competitive, score based game, that is very important.

The Sound Design:

You know, as an amateur musician and aspiring audio engineer and producer, great sound design gives me a boner. I have reached the point where I've trained my ear to notice every detail of every sound, so the more you treat my ear and the better your sound works with what's being shown on screen, the more I have to rave about it. And let me just say.. This is quite possibly the single best sound design I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing in gaming. The most recent Battlefield games come close, but the sound here is so excellent that with enough practice you could probably play the game blind. Also, despite having no obligation to do so, the developer has added support for 3D binaural sound, which means when played with the right headphones, the skulls are suddenly floating right past your ear and behind your head and it feels as real as a fly buzzing around in the room near you. Every action, every enemy, and every position has a clear place in the frequency spectrum and overall soundstage of the game. Every sound adds to how satisfying the gameplay is, and you can't play the game without it. Believe me, I've tried.

The Addiction/Replayability:

I genuinely fear that this game has already started to make whatever self control for gaming I thought I had vanish entirely. Every run feels completely unique, and even though I know I'm seeing the same enemies I fought last round, it still feels like an entirely new experience with new decisions to make, new problems, and new ways for me to get myself out of a pinch. Everything just feels so dynamic, and I've played games with way more content that got old way quicker (My interest is still growing and has yet to hit a plateau). This has led me to "one more round" myself past midnight and into the wee hours of the morning.

The Performance:

I own a normal laptop. Quad-core 2.2ghz AMD A8 processor with AMD Radeon R5 Graphics and 12 GB of RAM. Not at all suitable for gaming. Well, I still get a solid 60fps early on and it still remains playable to the very last seconds of my 192 second record. If you have ANY sort of GPU, you have nothing to worry about. This is likely due to the massive pixels, low-poly models, and the fact that all that exists in the game world is a platform and hundreds of demons on it. Who knows? Maybe it's also some good old fashioned optimization.. That seems to be rare today, especially with every developer these days hopping on Unity or Unreal Engine.

The Verdict:

It's 2 am, and I'm tired. Just buy the game. It costs about as much as a fast food meal and it'll be 50 times as enjoyable for many hours longer. However, if you do buy it, prepare for a real challenge, one created simply by crafting creative enemy types to be fought with solid game mechanics instead of the generic cookie cutter fps enemies of today.

33573778.review:
-Play style- Keyboard (With Headphones... turned way up!)
Wow, what can I say. I haven't really been that far into this. Partly because my skill set puts me at odds with these fast paced, dash and shoot, types of games. But from what I can tell. A progressive, rogue-like, arena shooter. Like a bullet hell game. But with hell spawn as bullets. Each "level" doesn't so much as start as it blends with the previous. With scarier looking creatures coming out of the dark dark mists of the abyss with every few kills. 

It IS addicting. In the same way that Paranautical Activity was in the first weeks of owning it. Just without a random dungeon to crawl.  The demons know where you are. They are coming to you. I imagine it has something to do with the power infused blade you take at the beginning of the game.

The sounds are great. I mentioned headphones right at the beginning. Just do it! The monsters are scary. Make it loud enough that you can hear the music and then go to town. I found my self wincing and cringing in those tense moments were there were baddies on all sides. I love scary sounds. And each of these creatures has a particular creep about them to give you just the right amount of chills.

Finding out just how far you can go, or what new and well crafted beasts you will come across, is allot of fun. Or maybe you fall prey to the feeling of "I very, nearly, almost, did not die right there!!" 

And expect to die allot. I read this in so many different games reviews. But I find it to be important that it is followed by "so much fun". Otherwise whats the point. It isn't frustrating. It can kill you constantly and yet have you rushing back in for more. Brilliant.

Also, leader boards. As in, the only true way to tell how far you got, is by seeing how many points you racked up. Seeing your best score right in front of you gives incentive to go for one more round. But the friends, and global leader boards, also hold some allure. For you competitive types.

-TLDR-

Its good. Check it out!

33546578.review:
[h1]An incredibly simple and satisfying challenge.[/h1]

[i]Devil Daggers[/i] is a fast-paced arena shooter that will always keep you moving and thinking ahead. Nowhere is safe and there are no brakes on this nightmarish fight for survival. The goal and main premise of the game is two-fold:
[olist]
[*]Defeat the myriad of different skull-based entities with your magical dagger hands and prolong your death.
[*]Upgrade your power by collecting crystals dropped by various enemies.
[/olist]

And that's it. That's the entire game.
What makes this unique and fun instead of impossibly hard and tedious is [i]Devil Daggers'[/i] amazingly quick replayability and challenging learning curve. Runs take less than 5 minutes for most players and these short times encourage you to play just one more time to try to beat your record. The enemy AI is unforgiving but fair - every single monster has a certain behavior that can be plainly seen or described and played around. Applied knowledge of these mechanics gives the player a huge advantage when in a tight spot; the simplicity of the controls allows this nuance to shine through and easily be picked up on.

In a game all about skill, the only randomness [i]Devil Daggers[/i] has is enemy spawn locations. This isn't a drawback as the arena is circular and everything has a sound cue telling you where, when, and what enemy type is spawning.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
[list]
[*] Simple concept with plenty of patterns and tricks to learn
[*] Short rounds make it easy to go "one more round"
[*] Gameplay is difficult but never unfair
[*] Competitive leaderboard
[*] Replays available for your friends' runs as well as your top time
[*] Breaking a record feels truly satisfying
[/list]

[h1]CONS[/h1]
[list]
[*] Steep learning curve that sometimes requires the player to die, learn, repeat
[*] Can be frustrating to players not used to twitch-shooter style games
[*] Only one game mode
[/list]

For a $5 game you get so much replayability and a worthwhile challenge. [i]Devil Daggers[/i] is a wonderful, small gem that I do not regret buying and cannot recommend more to those looking for something challenging that does not soak hours of your time.

33453646.review:
[b]Firstmost, a alert: this is a really expensive per time game.[/b] See that lonely achievment for getting 500 secs alive? Once you get beyond that point there will be no more content and you will be in a endless enemy pattern loop.

Devil Daggers is a game for only some people... no I'm not talking about hiscorers and hardcore people. It's more restrict than that.[b]It's a game for the hardcorer's who like to crowd control swarms.[/b] The trailer is not capable of showing this well. To really know how it's the dynamic, see a elite player doing a long run. (You need anyway to get good enough at this game...)

The game has 13 enemies, but they can be boiled down to only 4 some categories: Stuff you run at max speed to escape from (skulls, spiderlings), stuff you run at full speed to kill a weak spot (spiders, spires),stuff that you find a sweat spot to hit strong (centipedes) and one that floats erratically (skull2). Almost everthing kills on contact, and that's the only action that can kill you (unless you make a dumb mistake of falling). Because of this, the tactics in the game become mostly "run form the mob to kill the target", that becomes repetitive really fast (and yeah... we are talking about a game of only 500 seconds... aggravate this with your replays)

In terms of mecanics, you have a lot of oldschool oddities here. Like runstraffing, rocket-jumping and bunnyhoping. but I'm not sure if all then were implemented for good here, for example: bunnyhoping seemed more a chore of remembering to press space than a thing that interferes in the tatics.

Despite all that DD is really a well made game, they put a lot of effort to simulate magic carpet and quake style of sound and graphics and are really authentic. Unfortunately, they didn't have much stuff to apply it as it's only one room with only one kind of floor, adds to it the lack of music to keep the blood pumping (and to make timing more easy) and the general darkness at long range. I wish I could have a easy mode just to appreciate the artwork. It's incredible, I want a bigger game using this stuff.

I'm sure that this is a good game and was built with a lot of love, but as a DooM player I discovered this is not my type of dish and because I was mislead, I give a negative. But maybe it's your gold! You really should test yourself and see if you feel like going for one more try. That's why there is a steam refund system, no?

33389141.review:
Devil Daggers, a game that looks like a simple wave shooter on first glance, but in reality is so much more.

The concept of Devil Daggers is very simple. An arena, endless waves of enemies and you in the middle doing your best to survive as long as you can. Also something that has to be said straight away, Devil Daggers is hard, very hard. Most people that try the game will play it for a few hours, reach a point where progress slows down and just stop playing. And exactly that is the point where you have to stick with it and learn to get better. Finally figuring out a hard part, or setting a new Personal Best after a long time of stagnation feels more satisfying than anything else.
Many may not understand why you would keep pushing hours and hours for only a few seconds of improvement, but the adrenaline rush it gives you is just incredibly addicting. 

There is so much more I could say about Devil Daggers, the buttery smooth gameplay, the amazing sound design, the community, that is one of the friendliest I have ever been part of,...
The list would go on and on, but I will stop it here and highly suggest you to check out Devil Daggers, because it is one of the best gaming experiences I ever had.

33262409.review:
I fell in love with this game. As simple as you can get, yet one of the most challanging experiences I've played. Controls are very responsive and movement is fast and smooth. Thanks to the low visuals, you won't see a major FPS drop when your screen is near 100% enemies. But don't let that be a dig about its appearance. At first glance I asked myself "Why would you intentionally want to look like an early 3D Playstation game?" But after playing it, the low-tech look really adds to the atmosphere of the game. My longest time has only been 130 seconds after my first sit down with this game, showing that there's lots of room for me to improve and possibly hit that 500 seconds.

The only gripes I had with this game were there was not really any noticable music (I turned the DOOM (2016) Soundtrack on, works pretty well.) and I wish I could bind the Auto Fire to another key, as there are moments I go to do a shotgun blast but end up tossing a pellet at an enemy (Ended a few runs that way.). In the end, great game for fans of horde shooters and for people that want to challenge themsleves with a quick bursts of games.

32780060.review:
Let me start by saying I've never had "fun" with this game. I wouldn't say I haven't enjoyed my experience with it, but I definitely wouldn't call the hellish anxiety-ridden fear-driven bunnyhopping stress adventure this game offers "fun". Now, I'd also like to express the fact that this game genuinely seems to try to make you feel helpless. It achieves the opposite of what Doom does. You feel like at any given moment, something could pop up behind you and kill you. Paranoia is the ketchup to this game's roast beef.

Yet I still keep coming back.

If I had to personify this game, I'd call it an abusive father. You keep getting the snot beaten out of you, and the game keeps telling you this is your fault, or that it's only doing this because it loves you. But fuck, when you get its approval, it feels [i] so [/i] damn good. All in all, I recommend this game, but please understand that it won't make you feel happy.

32704459.review:
A solid 1 minute and 30 seconds of gameplay (often times not even that!).  

What is Devil Daggers you may ask?  Well, I'll tell you friend; it's a cosmetically retro styled (think Quake graphics) arena shooter where you essentially try to survive as long as possible whilst killing and enduring increasing waves of enemies (you will be ranked).  My personable best is 2 minutes and 52 seconds btw.

I got this game for under $3 dollars CDN and I knew what to expect.  I bet a lot of people will play the game for 5 minutes, give up and move onto something else.  And I honestly I can't say they're wrong for doing so; this game is certainly not everyone's cup of tea (hell, it's not most people's cup of tea).

But if you're looking for a solid 10-20 minutes of intense, albite repetitive and extremely difficult gameplay, give this game a go, and don't pay more than $3 for it.

32258381.review:
This is one of the most limiting games I've ever played. Chances are you know what Devil Daggers is about. You run around a pitch black arena, you get one weapon, you die in a single hit, there are no pickups, and you fight an endless stream of enemies, which either remain stationary and fire projectiles at you or they follow a single path to you. This tries to pass itself off as a "pure" arena shooter, and even blatantly steals its look from Quake, but what this comes down to is endless generic shooting without any real substance. It's a crime that there's no level design as you're just on a floating platform in the middle of a black void. There's zero story or context, and while that's not necessarily a bad thing, here there isn't even a feeling of progression. This game is as purely about gameplay as you can get. This has been a universal point of praise for DD, but it's a major problem here because it doesn't feel like there's any point to it, or any fun to be had.

When I say it's pure gameplay, I mean it. There are no environments, no areas to explore, no secrets to find, no explanations or mysteries or really anything to discover or uncover. This is Arena Shooter: The Game, but all this means is you're in a pitch black arena with endless floating bad guys to shoot. In a game like Serious Sam: TFE or TSE, there's a sense of progression, like you're actually doing something that has an effect. You explore environments with actual level design and layouts. There will be environmental hazards, hills, plateaus, items, pickups, obstacles, ramps, and otherwise things to use to help you when you get bombarded by enemies. Yes, you will fight in large "arenas" in Serious Sam, but you're never just in a literal circular platform floating in the middle of space.

Devil Daggers feels like a mod made by someone who wanted to strip Quake of everything that made it fun just to test his skill by seeing how long he could survive against endless waves of increasingly impossible to avoid enemies and projectiles. It is clearly skill-based but the skill you develop to get better in this game won't apply to any game except this one. It relies on predictable AI and manipulating the game's point system to get into a frenzy mode. The controls are like Quake's, but should it be praised for being derivative? You really have to hate yourself to try and beat some of the records put on by people with no lives who have played this game for a thousand hours. And that's really the problem with this game. There's no reason to play except to get on the leaderboards. Even if you make first place, I fail to see what the accomplishment is there. A game with no multiplayer better have spectacular AI, since human enemies always have the potential to be smarter than AI ones; this game's AI feels like it would be beaten by the original Quake's AI. 

There's no interesting art or sound design. There's no music. There's no interesting weapon design or variety. There's no information. The enemies look like they belong in a Quake mod. The only strategy is to manipulate this game's undisclosed point system to earn you certain...things (?) at certain points to progress against enemies with more health. I can appreciate the attempt to make a gameplay-focused game, but Devil Daggers makes me want to gouge my eyes out with devil daggers. You're better off watching a video of the high-score record of this game and then never looking at it again.

My biggest problem with Devil Daggers is that it was actually ranked as like number 6 in the top FPS's of all time and the best game of 2016 by Rock, Paper, Shotgun (a source that's supposed well-informed and well-versed in video games). It's just not. Even they say you can't play this game for longer than 15 minutes at a time, and there's a reason for that. This game is ugly and [b][i][u]ludicrously[/u][/i][/b] redundant. I get that stripping an entire game down to the fundamental principle of arena-shooting was the goal, but it has several arbitrary decisions and leaves me with questions that I have to seek the forums for answers to. For instance, why does your weapon fire projectiles instead of use hitscan? Why do the projectiles move so slowly? Why does it take so long to redirect your movement? How does the point system work? When do you go into berserk mode and what does it allow you to do? This game has serious problems, yet it has been hailed as one the best games of all time and consistently receives next to no criticism.

DD has one trick up its sleeve: bombarding you with enemies and projectiles to avoid in a cramped space. It's literally the FPS equivalent of a SHMUP with one never-ending level that takes place in a pitch black arena (or should I include the brown floor?). Read the other reviews of this game--and keep in mind the reviewers' hours--and tell me that Devil Daggers hasn't been unfairly hailed as a godsend when there could easily be a much better "pure" arena shooter. This game is ugly, devoid of a good-looking style, and plays just a Flash game that your friend dares you to try out just to make you feel like a bad player. [i][u]Bizarrely, Devil Daggers has been over-refined, over-thought, and overly-stripped down to the point where there is truly no point in playing it[/u][/i]. Arbitrary gameplay decisions aside, there's just nothing interesting to look at, listen to, or play. It's a game that revolutionizes nothing, which has no end, no chance of survival, and no merit except in what it stole from a much better game.

I really thought I would like this game, and I really wanted to like it, because we NEED a game like Devil Daggers. Too often new games come out that claim to have super-realistic graphics and claim to push the envelope of graphics, sound design, or realism, but have none of the brutality or skill basis that characterized FPS's in the 1990s. Those games were all about twitch reflexes, accuracy, movement, speed, control, precision, strategizing, weapon prioritization, and things like that. At its core, you can tell the developers of Devil Daggers have a kernel of understanding of what people valued in those games. And I think the people who played it believed that since this new game is a "pure FPS," they thought it took the throne and became a shining example of the epitome of arena shooter gaming. Whether the developers tried to do that, I don't know, but what I do know is that it ended up taking away all that gave meaning to those games. You're in a black void with no music, hardly any sound effects, graphics blockier than the original DOOM, and enemy variety that only consists of floating skulls, monoliths, centipedes, and tentacle monsters. This POS literally won RPS's game of the year award. 

[i][u]Apparently all it takes to make a game of the year is to make a game whose difficulty depends on avoiding a ridiculous number of projectiles and floating enemies while you figure out how to stack kills in such a way as to get you slow-mo mode at certain times. This is so limited that it's absurd.[/u][/i]

Don't get me wrong, I love gameplay-oriented games like DOOM and Quake, but Devil Daggers lacks everything that made those games fun. Even the new release of Rise of the Triad is more fun than Devil Daggers, because at least there's an environment. With Devil Daggers, there are simply no environments, no enemy weight, no gravitas, no tone, and no atmosphere. Furthermore, it tries to claim a stake in a genre from which it strips away everything in order to be the "most refined" or "purest," when that's ultimately a strike against it because there ends up being not enough variety or anything creative enough to merit continuing to play.

I'm sorry if I'm not a masochist, but I don't find it fun to endlessly die and have to restart a million times to beat a record I'll never beat. And for an arena shooter to not be fun is a crime, especially in this day where we need the arena shooter genre to come back.

32031094.review:
Superb game.

Are you old enough to remember playing Defener in the arcades?

If you're a hardcore gamer and you've never played this then you're missing an important piece of history - get it on MAME.

Do you still play the original DOOM?  Start every level with a pistol and 50 rounds on (at least) Ultra Violent difficulty?  Modded it to Brutal Doom?

Played Original Tempest/Tempest 2000?

More recently, Meatboy etc?

Devil Daggers is a PURE skill-based shooter.   It's like games used to be - simple on the surface but underneath, so complex that they take months to master and HARD!

Devil Daggers is beautiful for its purity.  I've been playing for a total of 4 hours at this point and I am blown away.  It is the same vibe that Defender/Doom/Old school hard/skill based games have.

No handholding with this game. You have to LEARN and PLAY 100%.  There is no quarter given.

So far I have survived 63 seconds.   I know I will survive longer.   I get better as I play.

This game sells for pocket change.  It is a masterpiece.  If you like old-school hard skill-based games then you will love this.

Seriously.   Get this game and PLAY IT.

"Spiders and Daggers" Review

Short: You can put this dumb shit away and play a better fps. And not be wasting time.

Played enough. Seen enough. Should be called "Spiders and Daggers" because they're the enemy that varies the difficulty simply out of slight invicibility(miss target? get punished WAY HARDER with a curled up invicible spider ball you have to wait on to hit....) and can throw off kill-time(I can easily beat half the scores in the world and the game is still too hard simply bc of 1 and only 1 enemy(also, might as well start over if the spider curls up just once)). If it was just the other enemies, this game would be a big big dissapointment, anyways. Seeing how the spiders are the most unreasonably hard(for being a massive priority-they steal your upgrades) and, again, they can curl up and f*** you up so bad that the player might as well start right the f*** back over. The rest of the game looks cool. Not worth the frustration over one enemy's bad gimmic.

The leviathans would be cool to shoot at, but the spiders spawn in 3's at that point, steal your upgrades and makes Devil Daggers into Spider Daggers. If you don't have level 3 through Farming(and the game doesn't say you can farm, it requires other people's gameplays to help explain the game). I was happy up to the Farming being a necessity. Why can't I just beat a bunch of enemies and be rewarded? 

Pros: not a hefty price, at least a few hours of fun...
Cons: the game is pacman w/gun and infinite ghosts(oh and a spider that changes things up to help things appear as a "full game")

I don't like this game.
I 100% recommend it, but I don't like it.

The graphics: Love 'em. 90s style >>>> CoD: UltraStupidlyRealisticAndCreepy
The controls: Quake. Standard FPS controls. You can crank your FoV to over 120.
The gameplay: Predictable, yet unpredictable. Everything spawns at a set time, but doesn't stay the same enough to predict. Especially when you're new to the game. And can't predict things even when you aren't new to a game.

If you like hardcore, singleplayer, competitive, endless, arena shooter-style games, you'll probably love Devil Daggers, even though I didn't.


Note: Devil Daggers was recommended to me by Emberstone, the (as of writing) 73rd best time globally.

31727619.review:
[h1]十分少见的复古FPS[/h1]

手感与著名上古FPS QUAKE 十分相似，弹道轨迹 背景音乐 画面都十分相似，而且有火箭跳。制作组肯定是 QUAKE 的老粉丝。
游戏机制十分简单，玩家需要做得就是干掉敌人，尽可能久的活下去。游戏中有只有一种方式升级武器，就是收集特定怪掉落的宝石，根据收集数能获得不同级别的武器。就我个人而言，我认为这是一款值得一玩的Rouguelike极限挑战游戏，十分不错。

如果你是一位对上古FPS游戏感兴趣，或者是想锻炼自己的枪法（预判 瞄准 ）或者锻炼自己的走位技能的人，那我大力推荐这款游戏，它绝对能让你上瘾。游戏本身并没有什么缺点，可能存在的唯一缺点就是它实在太难了一点，如果不稍微练习下，可能只能玩1分钟左右1把。当然随着技术的提高，对游戏机制的理解越发深刻，自然能发现更多的乐趣。

[h1] 游戏机制详细分析	[/h1]

武器模式共有三种
1.连射 鼠标左键长按 一般用于清除少量骷髅或者攻击蜈蚣时使用
2.霰弹 鼠标左键单击 清楚大面积骷髅或者攻击体积较大敌人时使用（蜘蛛 后期的要塞）
3.追踪匕首 鼠标右键 相当于雷电等弹幕游戏中的炸弹 十分珍贵 尽量只用在紧要关头 清理超出控制量的敌人时使用

武器升级宝石收集数
LV2. 10
LV3. 70
LV4. 220
其中只有LV3以上才能使用追踪匕首
具体的武器参数可以参考社区指南

[h1] 生存技巧	[/h1]

游戏中有全球排行不少人止步于160s上下，这是第一道难关，蜈蚣怪和大量2级触手怪，大部分人因为清理速度不够，死于其中，我也是其中之一 = =
国外大佬的打法是通过前期的Farm, 也就是故意留着大部分的触手怪爆首领级骷髅刷宝石，尽快达到LV3，然后一口气清掉所有怪。因为后期难度的突然上升，如果不采用Farm的打法很难撑到300s以后。详情各位也可以参考社区指南。
