31096104.review:
Kurz: Bockschwer, aber herausfordernd, motivierend und spaßig!

Laaaaang:

Bei DD spielen wir einen namenlosen Protagonisten, der in einer runden (und seeeeehr dunklen) Arena steht und so lange wie möglich gegen immer wieder nachkommende Dämonenhorden überleben muss. Eine Handlung, Charaktere oder irgendwelche Lore gibt es nicht.

Wir haben zwei "Waffen" (eigentlich Feuermodi der mit der Hand unserer Spielfigur abgefeuerten Teufelsdolche...) zur Verfügung, einmal das gute alte (und präzise) Dauerfeuer und dann eine Art Streuschuss, der zwar eine größe Fläche mit Projektilen endeckt, dafür aber langsamer schießt (weil man hier für jeden Schuss die linke Maustaste wieder drücken muss).

Ach, und überleben heißt hier genau eines: Nicht getroffen werden. Jup, ein Treffer und man ist tot und die Runde damit vorbei. Man stirbt übrigens auch, wenn man aus Versehen vom Rand der Arena in den Abgrund stürzt...

Ziel ist wie gesagt das möglichst lange Überleben. Man bekommt für die überlebte Zeit Punkte, so dass man dann nach der Runde in die globale Bestenliste eingetrage wird. Man hat also immer einen Anreiz, noch besser zu werden um in der Liste nach oben zu klettern. Es gibt noch einsammelbare rote Kristalle, die von manchen Gegnern bei deren Ableben fallen gelassen werden und die - bei genügend gesammelter Anzahl - unsere Angriffe verstärken.

Es gibt nur ein einziges Achievment, für das man 500 Sekunden am Stück überleben muss. Wenn man jetzt mal bedenkt, dass spätestens nach 1-2 Minuten (also 60-120 Sekunden) einen derart mit Gegnern zuballert, das man mit ziemlicher Sicherheit stirbt, dann dürften wohl nur die wenigsten Spieler jemals ne Chance haben, diesen Erfolg freizuschalten.

Insgesamt ist DD ein tolles Spiel, auch für Zwischendurch. Eben gerade weil im Normalfall die Runden doch recht kurz sind. Aber vorsicht, es macht süchtig! "Nur noch eine Runde" wird man sich hier öfter denken...

Der Schwierigkeitsgrad ist hoch, aber fordernd und motiviert zu immer neuen Anläufen. Einziger Minuspunkt ist aus meiner Sicht, dass man quasi ständig die ersten 60 Sekunden des Spiels wiederholt, weil die Gegner in jeder Runde genau in der gleichen Reihenfolge auftauchen (nur an leicht unterschiedlichen Stellen in der Arena). Das kann dann trotz des Suchtfaktors schon mal nerven. Hier wäre vielleicht für eine eventuelle Fortsetzung ein System mit Angriffswellen besser, wo man dann als Spieler selber wählen kann, bei welcher (bereits freigeschalteten) Welle man einsteigen möchte.

Der grafische Stil, der an Spiele aus den 90ern angelehnt ist, gefällt mir sehr gut (was eventuell damit zu tun haben könnte, dass ich in besagten 90ern aufgewachsen bin... ;-) ) und wirkt insgesamt sehr zeitlos und zur Höllen-Thematik passend.

Der Sound ist eher zurückhaltend, aber immerhin kann man anhand der Geräusche der Gegner zumindest zum Teil erkennen, wo sie sind bzw. wie nahe sie an einem dran sind.
Ach ja, ich sollte vielleicht noch erwähnen, dass sich die meisten Gegner ein klein wenig schneller als unsere Spielfigur bewegen, weshalb weglaufen keine Dauerlösung ist...

Fazit:

DD ist saumäßig schwer, macht aber immer wieder Gaudi. Aber eine gewisse Frustresistenz sollte man schon mitbringen, da man selbst als geübter Shooterspieler hier sehr oft den Löffel abgeben wird und den Anfang quasi in Endlosschleife wiederholt.

Den Preis von 5 Euro halte ich für angemessen, auch wenn ich persönlich das Spiel in einem Sale für weniger (ich glaub es waren knapp 3,50) bekommen habe.

Wer irgendwas mit Shootern anfangen kann (und auch gut darin ist, diese zu spielen ;-) ) und ein kurzweiliges Spiel sucht, der ist hier genau richtig.

31044712.review:
퀘이크1 분위기가 나는 FPS게임이다.
난이도가 높은데, 조준이 어려운것이 아니라 한대 맞으면 죽기 때문이다. 

마치 비행슈팅게임을 FPS로 옮긴 느낌인데 비행슈팅은 그나마 3인칭시점이라 뒤에서 오는 공격을 보고 피할 수도 있지 이건 미니맵도 없어서 경험, 사플, 그리고 몹몰이 하는 센스 등이 필요하다. 즉 에임보다 운영이 중요한 게임이다.

그러나 이 게임에 익숙해지기 전에 대다수 사람들은 30분 내로 이 게임을 삭제할 것 같다.

게임 컨셉에 아쉬운건 체력개념이 있고 떨구는 보석을 메디킷 개념으로 만들고 미니맵은 아니라도 아주 근접시 날아오는 방향지시 정도라도 해줬다면 많은 사람들이 엔딩까지 보고 즐거운 마음으로 이 게임을 추천했을지도 모른다. 지금같은 모드는 경쟁목적으로 하드코어 모드로 했더라면 하는 아쉬움이 남는다. 이렇게 됐다면 라이트, 하드유저 모드 잡을 수 있을텐데. 게임자체가 직관적인 재미가 있어서 만인이 즐겨줬으면 하는 바람이 있다.

게임의 컨텐츠는 없다시피 하기 때문에 정가로 사면 어차피 대다수 사람들이 극악의 난이도 때문에 한 시간도 안 즐길게 뻔하다. 한 시간 해보고 재미없으면 환불하는게 낫다. 필자는 세일할 때 사서 그냥 가끔 십분하고 끄는걸 반복하고 있어서 그냥저냥 아깝지는 않다.

도전과제가 하나밖에 없는데 달성하려면 500초를 버텨야한다. 요령 없으면 보통 처음엔 60초 근처가 한계인듯하니 커뮤니티에서 공략들을 숙지하고 상위권 유저들 리플레이들을 보고 연구하도록 하자. 팁이 있다면 몹을 처치해서 보석을 먹으면 무기가 업그레이드 되고, 그럴수록 게임이 쉬워지는것 같다. 초반을 버티기가 어렵다.

점프는 가속점프랑 로켓점프 둘다 된다.
총은 좌클릭하면 샷건. 좌클릭누르고 있으면 머신건이 나간다. 샷건은 지면에 대고 점프하면 로켓점프된다. 샷건은 보스들 약점인 보석맞추기에 적하하고 사용하는듯 하고 머신건은 주로 잡몹들 잡을 때 유용하다. 가속점프는 퀘이크의 느낌과 달리 효과가 미미하다. 고수들 영상보면 아예 뛰지도 않는다.

31003406.review:
Devil Daggers is an absolutely fantastic simplistic looking shooter that is anything but simplistic. Armed with basic WASD movemen controls and your left mouse button, you're set to fail time and time again; however, failure is satisfying in Devil Daggers. You will always take something from your last run. I found myself learning audio cues, enemy placements, and optimal aiming and timing skills with each momentous death. 

It's tough as nails, but it's worth every second of your time (and I mean every second, as you'll be watching your counter in the top left from the corner of your eye to "NEW HIGHSCORE" your friends or climb the leaderboards yourself.) The UI is clean and minimalistic, only giving you what you need with toggle-able aspects such as the in-game timer. The graphics are gritty and nostalgic but smooth and fresh enough to separate itself from quake shooters of yore. 

I heavily recommend picking up Devil Daggers for such an affordable price. It's a must have to play in quick bursts, or to sink in hours on. It may be a challenge, but each second you overcome your last run will be liberating. Remember to take breakes and breathe, you'll be here for awhile. Embrace your hellish arena and survive. You've got this.

30912656.review:
Devils Daggers is a diamond - it's compact, incredibly hard, and what little there is has been polished to perfection.

Devils Daggers is a minimalist FPS arena shooter. The goal is to survive as long as possible. You get one stage, which is a flat arena surrounded by abyss. You get one weapon, and die in one hit. There is one enemy spawn pattern, with some randomized positioning.

The audio design is amazing, the visual direction is strong, and moving and shooting feels beautiful, with a lot of nuance to the sparse mechanics.

You will die a lot. Let's be clear on that. This is a game for the kinds of people who like SHMUPS or 'arcade' style games where you replay the game hundreds of times trying to get better. If you aren't that sort of person, you will not like this game. If Devil Daggers still sounds interesting to you after hearing that, I'd highly recommend it.

30910619.review: This game is extremely challenging, and extremely addicting. Can take up either 5 minutes or 5 hours of your time if you let it.

30910553.review: This is such a tight, cohesive and wonderfully expressed concept. I have 1hr of play on record, but believe me, that is a LOT of games of Devil Daggers. Simple summary, 1st person horror survival, you have 2 styles of shooting, stream of bullets, or shotgun blast. You can jump although it rarely helps, and you can run. And you WILL run. The key to it is multi-faceted, first you need to aim well, second to move well, but most important, and the thing you pick up? Is to listen. Each enemy or challenge comes with key audio tricks, and the volume indicates distance. In time you're running, shooting, and ****ing yourself. I would say this game is worth the standard 5 bucks cost, but arguably given the scope, it's a sale purchase unless you KNOW you like sadistic challenge.

30682140.review:
I've been a huge shooter nut since we got Doom for our old 486, and this game looked super interesting to me. Unfortunately, I didn't know what I was in for. While the combat, controls, looks. all the building blocks are really well done, I didn't realize that this was going to be a survival shooter with a single level where the average person doesn't make it more than a few minutes. While the game is largely skill-based, it's frustrating as all hell when a random enemy breaks free from the herd behind you and kills you in a moment of pure luck. This means that you don't get to see a lot of the neater enemies or powers unless you're always 100% on your A-Game and have a dash of luck in the case of the AI. 

If there were maybe an easier mode that made the rounds last a little longer (just to break up the monotony of throw-away runs) or some different levels, I could probably say "This isn't for me, but I could recommend it." As it is, though, this is a game pretty much made for people who want to obsess over a single game and try to compete on a leaderboard.

To clarify, I wish the creators had put more effort into describing what the game is versus what it actually is.

DEVIL DAGGERS: A TEXT ADVENTURE. (TM): A CORPORATION OF QUESTIONABLE AUTHENTICITY.

You see a dagger: What do you do?

Take Dagger_

You take the dagger, and are presented with a large, eerie platform, not being able to see anything more than a few yards ahead of you. Suddenly, a large, demonic tower slowly crawls towards you, a small red gem glistening off the side. The tower would then open abruptly, tentacles writhing around in the air as a horde of skulls begin to pour out of the disgusting sight, lumbering their way towards you. One skull would be more prominent than the others, slightly larger with a set of horns adorning it's face. You ready your weapons. What do you do?

Engage the large skull_

Error. "Engage the large skull is not a valid command"

*Head banging against the keyboard*

. . .

Engage the horned skull_

You fire your daggers at the horned skull, quickly eliminating it from your list of threats. However, the crowd of smaller, more agile skulls are nearly upon you. You may be able to dodge out of the way, but this will not eliminate the problem. What do you do?

Engage the small skulls_

You fire a few shots into the dense crowd of skulls, loosening the group up considerably, as the straggling skulls break up and split off, only to turn around and turn back towards you. The Demonic tower is now closer to the center of the platform, with another one in sight entering from your right. You must multitask now, engage the first tower and remove it from play, or eliminate the skull threat?

Shoot the tower_

*This process will repeat a few times*

Suddenly, a large, horrific spider-like creature floats into your field of vision from the abyss beyond, screeching a ghastly howl, piercing your ears. The various skulls behind you are not a threat at the moment, but will be soon. This spider could be a much larger threat, and should probally be dealt with, however, more towers are now amassing in the center of the arena, this could present an even larger problem. What do you do?

/Help_

//:C Program Files/Steam/Steamapps/Common/DevilDaggers/Help: "Choose an answer, dumbass."

Shoot the bigass bug_

//: It's an arachnid.

Shoot the arachnid_

" 'Shoot the arachnid' is not a valid command"

Shoot the spider_

You shoot the spider a few times and the unholy beast falls back into the depths from where it came, the skulls behind you catching up. The pace seems to be picking up now. A massive doom tower slowly lumbers it's way onto the field as a tidal wave of giant demon worms, skulls, spiders, and other unspeakable monstrosities flood into your direction from all directions, closing in on you with great haste. What do you do?

THE LAST STAND_

DEFEND. TILL. THE. END.

*Lots of bloodcurdling screaming*

30660565.review:
If you’re thinking of buying Devil Daggers, ask yourself the following:

1) Do I have five dollars?

2) Do I have a mouse?

3) Do I have friends—specifically ones on steam who have this game, so I can beat their scores?

4) Do the neighbors suspect me?

If you answer “yes” to the first three and “no” to the last, then Devil Daggers is a good game for you right now.

Below is an explanation of each yes, and the no.

“Do I have five dollars?” Five dollars is how much it costs, with a penny to spare. And if you don’t have five dollars lying around, well…maybe your neighbors do. So just go to their house when they’re asleep, and collect any money you see lying around. Then when you have enough, leave their house, wait ‘til the morning; then go to your bank and make a deposit.

“Do I have a wired or wireless mouse?” Yeah, you can’t play this on your laptop pad. And it doesn’t matter how quality it is, or if you got the neighbor’s dog to bark 666 times. Thing is you’re gonna need a proper (computer) mouse.

“Do I have friends who have the game so I can beat their scores?” This is self-explanatory. Whenever you die in Devil Daggers, you get to see your score, along with your highest score, and your friends’ top scores, and the top players’ scores. They’re basically how many seconds you’ve managed to last. Sorta like the lock in her door. Or the candles in your basement.

“Do the neighbors suspect me?” Playing Devil Daggers is a leisure/escapist act, so if you want to get the most from it, it’s best that your neighbors aren’t searching around your house for their virgin. Because if they are, then you may experience anxiety, as you hear them walking together on your lawn, or pressing your door bell. If they’re snooping around, now’s the time to wash and hide the blade. You’ll also need to scrub the blood and markings off the floor, and get rid of the body. 

So now, do you have three yes’s and a no? Then yes. Get Devil Daggers. Maybe you’ll only play it for eighty minutes as I did. But it’ll be an interesting interlude, ‘til the full moon comes, and the nieghbors are asleep.

30531534.review:
[h1]DEVIL DAGGERS[/h1]
Devil Daggers is a very nicely designed indie game, that is essentially an endless arena shooter, competing to beat everyone else's scores. How good is it? Let's find out.

[h1]DEMON BLASTING FUN[/h1]
Devil Daggers is just straight up fun. You will die in one hit. No ifs, ands or buts. The difficulty is absolutely off the scale. The game is simply nothing but endless Demon killing fun. No interuptions. You are equipped with two weapons; a rapid-fire SMG-like spell, and a super-powered shotgun-like spell. Both serve their uses to the fullest, and are very balanced in terms of enemy damage. The most common enemy you'll see are the Skulls, which are spawned from big tentacle monsters. These Skulls die in 1-3 hits, and will swarm you by the hundreds if left alive. Not killing them will result in their speed becoming faster, this makes tactical kiting a must if you want to stay alive. Some other harder and less common enemies include Spiders, Horned Skulls and Worms. All of these serve as harder enemies that will attack once you get past a certain time limit. The sound design and graphical is absolutely fantastic, and brought me back to games like DOOM. You can even watch replays to see where you went wrong, which is a cute feature. And then there's the online leaderboards, which are self-explanatory. This game's one flaw is how small it is. Even though it has alot of content, there is only one single map, and it is no bigger than 50x50 meters. This is still satisfying, but I'd like to see more maps, you know?

[h1]RATING[/h1]
Devil Daggers delivers and absolutely fantastic nostalgia trip into an unholy-blasting first person shooter, and it is one of the best small games I have ever played. Do your self a favour: spare the chocolate-bar price and pick this up, you won't regret it. It will bring you hours of frustrating and rewarding gameplay. I always think that you should rate games based on price to content, and for this game, I give it an easy [b]8.8/10[/b].

30416014.review:
Albeit simple, this game is an intensely addictive and fast-paced arena shooter that can be enjoyed both in small sessions and hours at a time, the latter usually occurring by pure accident. 

When starting a game, one would expect to see an opening cinematic, tutorial or at least a title message, but Devil Daggers does none of that, starting with a basic menu screen and removing any unecessary filler that may be considered the norm for games nowadays. I'd like to think that this is because the game realises that isn't a deep, philosphical or particularly ambitious game on any account, and is rather meant to be experienced at face value: That being pure, unfiltered entertainment. I think that phrase sums up this entire game, personally; you won't be thinking about it for years to come, you likely won't discuss it for hours at a time, but you will have fun and isn't that really what matters when playing a game. I think the aesthetic simplicity of this game is one of its best aspects, as that makes it unintimidating for newcomers and easy to pick up and play casually after a long, stressful day.

Technically speaking, Devil Daggers is a joy to play. Rythm-slowing reloading is completely scrapped, a decision mirroring the design of the 2016 adaptation of DOOM, and the strafing and movement is incredibly sharp and responsive, which is necessary in a game of such difficulty. The jumping also feels spectacular and allows the player character to feel affected by physics and weighty. Furthermore, the retro-esque visual design of the game deserves recognition, the surreal appearances of the monsters being both intimidating and simultaneously fun to shoot away at to the heart's content.

Devil Daggers isn't a game that will be praised and remembered for the decades to come, very little games will, but for the time being it is a fantastically well-rounded game that you will likely enjoy for a good while. I know I certainly will.

30363206.review:
An absolutely exhilarating game. I suppose you can say this is a bit like if Quake and Heretic were put together into a game about surviving an arena with an endless amount of enemies. This isn't an FPS where you can mindlessly run around and shoot enemies, you need to think quickly and react even quicker while you attempt to bunnyhop away from the hordes of skulls that never let up.

A lot of people complain that they can't survive for long, and I know this may seem very unhelpful, but 'get gud' is literally all there is to it. When you first play, you will die over and over and over again. But over time you will learn patterns, how to prioritise your targets in any situation, and generally improve your aim.

But even then, there are many guides that will give you a lot of information on the game and its enemies, such as their health and behaviour (as well as tips for fighting them):
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=640200664

The game's soundtrack is pretty much composed of the sound effects. Everything from the general ambience to the sounds of the enemies gives the game a very uneasy feeling. The game has a (particularly frightening) menu theme, but doesn't really have any music playing during a run (probably since listening for your enemies' audio cues is so important), but I suppose you could just play Quake 1's soundtrack in the background.

The artstyle is also lovely too. Not only does it take direct inspiration from Quake 1's unique gothic looks but it pretty much nails the 'ye olde' FPS look entirely. The devs made sure the 90s look actually looks 90s without lazily making the game look like minecraft just for the sake of 'wow so retro!' 

The game on the whole is bloody brilliant, and it's only 4 quid! The game might not have a large amount of content, but you'll want to keep playing due to your desire to get better and beat your times.

The only thing I hope for now from the devs is a sequel that expands the game with a single player campaign. Even if it's not a direct sequel to Devil Daggers, it would still be amazing if it still has the same kind of artstyle and gameplay with handcrafted levels. It would essentially be the Quake 1 sequel we never got (though I suppose DUSK will scratch this itch for the meantime).

Recommended!

30349808.review:
This game is a god damn masterpiece.  Most (most) of the negative reviews are from people who played less than an hour.  One of the more common complaints is that it's too hard, and that there isn't enough content.

These people are wrong.

There is SO MUCH MORE to this game than at first glance.  The better you get at the game, the more you see of what lies beyond the first couple minutes.  Not only that, but it's surprisingly strategic.  You will eventually develop a routine for the first minute, and for the minutes after that.  The first two minutes that you struggled with so badly become child's play.

Aside from the gameplay, the leaderboard is one of the best features in the game.  You can watch replays from other players, and go into a top-down view to see the whole playing field.  The best players' replays are the key to getting better.  Watch them, and learn from them.

Honestly I can't recommend this game enough.  It's one of the best shooters I've played in a while, and while it is repetitive, the drive to improve your time by just a few seconds is very strong.  If you buy this game, you need to devote some time to it so you can see what it has to offer.  Don't make a judgement from the first hour.

30268794.review:
To start off, if you are thinking of getting Devil Daggers and you dont want to do mcuh reading up on it, then i 100% suggest you Buy it.

Devil Daggers is a First Person Shooter that may bring back memories of Quake™ through the graphics, and the gameplay is eirely similar to Geometry Wars (yet in first person)

I haven't put too much time into the game, but that mainly because i find myself using it as a way to pass time.
This is a great game for people of an older audience, e.g. 40+, as it tests your hand to eye coordination whilst also giving you a way to enjoy yourself in your spare time.

This game can be rage inducing at times, my advise is that if this happens to you (or more so when it happens to you) just head off it for 30mins+ and watch some youtube.

If you are planning to get this game for achievments, then don't get too exited; Devil Daggers has only got 1 achievment.
This achievment is unlocked by Surviving in one run for 500 seconds. This is extremely hard to unlock, and i havent got it yet myself.    My personal best is 121.0477 to put it into perspective.

If you are a bit of a try-hard however, you may be able to get above 500 seconds and possibly go for the world record.

If You want to see some gameplay and a review for this game, in a visual format then feel free to check out my video on it, and also other creator's videos on Devil Daggers.

(FYI i got this game through a Steam CD Key from G2A)

Thank You For Reading.
Video link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RmNQkz_gPCY

30266357.review:
Süchtig machendes kleines Stück verhexte Software.
Mein Persönliches Highlight 2016. Wenn ihr gerne auch nur einer Minute länger zu Leben hinterherjadt: perfekt.
Es ist ein Level, doch wen stört es wenn es das härteste und beste der letzten Jahre, selbst über den Shooter Markt hinaus ist.
An sich erscheint diese Level als unspäktukulär, es ist eine ebene viereckige flache graue Fläche, doch was dieses Spiel wirklich wahnsinnig gut zu meistern weiß, ist eine in dieser Art wohl "fast" vergessene Kunst: die Gegnerplazierung.
Diese wirft einem mit einer simplen, stehts fairen, höllischen Schwierigkeit eine Masse von in Phasen erscheineden und Typen unterteilte Arten von Gegenern entgegen, die es zu studieren und zu lernen gilt.
Hierzu kommen dann noch der Bedarf von schnellen Reflexen und Movement, gekröhnt von einer nicht unterschätzbaren fantasischen Sound Raum Localisierung, die es zu perfektionieren gilt.

This game is Old School DOOM (or Hexen) distilled into it's purest and most potent form. DOOM limited you with silly color-matching puzzles and weak weapons with ammo conservation and dandy monsters that didn't simply kill you instantly.

Pure FPS arena arcade skill-based lovecraft pixelgrunge goregasm.

30191443.review:
This game is phenomenal. The gameplay is intense, stressful, and overwhelming. The graphics are choppy and paint a dreary hellscape. The monsters are scarily powerful and intimidating, and they only get worse with each passing second. Mistakes are punished quickly.

So what's fun? What's fun is dying, dying, and dying, as if it will never end, then finally getting one run in which you actually kick ass. And then you play for another hour and have another few great runs, and you beat some of your old records. You begin to formulate a strategy to survive. You learn to stick to the strats and handle the chaos. Like all great games, you can feel yourself getting better with each play.

30182148.review:
The sounds, the textures, the feel of shooting daggers while skulls chitter and gurgle in your ears as you strafe and jump around a horde, trying to clear spawners and avoid flinging yourself off the edge into the abyss.

If you're a fan of running, jumping, and shooting, and strive to git gud and beat your records, it's well worth the modest 5 dollars. It has a replay system that works with its global leaderboard, and the way the player moves is very comfortable and smooth, the gunplay of shooting the daggers feels solid, and you certainly won't feel like you're shooting boogers for bullets. There's no cheap deaths in this game, just you making mistakes so it's very hard to get mad.

30176779.review:
[h1] Alors Devil Daggers, qu'est-ce-que c'est ? [/h1]

Devil Daggers est un fps/die and retry dévelloppé par un petit studio indé. Dans ce jeu, vous incarnez ... quelqu'un (?) qui combat ... des choses (qui ressemblent à des crânes et des araignés, mais aussi des centipèdes :c).

[h1] Côté gameplay: [/h1]

De ce côté, le jeu est minimaliste: se déplace, sauter, tirer (deux tirs différent: maintenir le clic gauche pour tirer en continu, un clic gauche pour tirer un "gros tir") .
Si vous arrivez à collecter assez de ... ruby ? gemme ? je sais pas trop, mais si vous collecter assez de ces choses, alors vous deviendrez plus puissant (jusqu'à votre mort), et vous débloquerez une attaque spéciale qui envoie des dagues sur les ennemis (en appuyant sur le clic droit) :o
De plus, le gameplay m'as rappellé celui de doom, niveau vitesse de déplacement, et surtout ... un semblant de rocket-jump, faisable en tirant un "gros tir" en dessous de vous en sautant

[h1] Côté Graphismes: [/h1]

Ce sont des graphsimes old-school assumés, qui rendent étrangement très bien :o

[h1] Mais le jeu en lui même ?[/h1]

Le but est simple: Tenir le plus longtemps possible sans éclater votre clavier. (nan sérieusement, le but est de survivre à des vagues d'énnemis)
Mais ce jeu est ... génial. Malgré que très répétitif, j'ai pris mon pied. J'ai adoré mourrir, remourrir, rager et remourrir jusqu'à battre mon propre record ne serais-ce que d'un dixième de secondes :)
De plus, un scoreboard est présent, vous permettant de voir votre classement mondial mais aussi un classement avec votre liste d'amis :o

[h1] Donc ... vaut-il le coup ?[/h1]

Cela dépend de vos gouts, si vous n'aimez pas recommencer encore et encore, alors ne l'achetez surtout pas. Mais si vous voulez essayer de persévérer et de grimper dans le scoreboard mondial, ou même juste y jouer sans vous soucier de votre score, alors foncez :3

Je précise aussi que si vous arrivez à survire 500 secondes, alors vous débloquerez un achievement flambant neuf, que les chasseur d'achievement apprécieront car seul 48 personnes l'ont débloquer au moment ou je rédige cette évaluation :o

30174543.review:
It makes me outrageously happy to play a game where there's nothing random to it, no silly perks or loadouts to contend with, none of that. You just sit and you learn. The more you learn the more the number, your high score, goes up. That's it.

A refreshingly small-scope game that utterly holds to that scope. The graphics and sounds work beautifully, the longer you last the more horrors you eventually see, the game delivers a truly hellish vibe with relatively simple means. The weapon is well balanced, satisfying and rich to use.

The only flaw I find with this game is that the sound for the laughing skulls is a little inconsistent. Sometimes it's quite loud and the skull is far behind you, other times you're caught by surprise because it sounded further away than it was. Just another thing to learn, but it is certainly a flaw.

To bring up any other complaint with the game is usually to say "I wish they made something entirely different." Which is fine, this game is probably only truly for a very small subset of people, but it does what it does and it does it nearly perfectly. An utterly admirable game, even if for only that reason.

30162829.review: Wow. Honestly, i bought it because i expected something more than.. this. It gives even less content than i've imagined it would. The game is very pretty on the surface, but on the inside, it's really simplistic to the point it's just boring and not all that cool than it tries to be. This is so overhyped and it's really pathetic that people call this something like a "game that is nothing like anything out there, period". Because, let's be honest, it's a very tiny project. Is it beautiful? Yeah, yeah it is. Is it fun? Yeah, for like 5 minutes. But paying money for this and playing it like if it's a game? I don't know if i would. I'm a huge fps enthusiast. I've played millions upon billions of fps games, it's one of my top favorite genres ever. But while playing this i just kept thinking to myself: "i'd rather play a really cool doom mod right now". I'm shocked that this game is praised by idiot critics and even has a metascore of 83 (on par with all the good AAA games out there). So i guess, all it takes to be praised is to be all old-school-y and flashy, and to lack all the essence in terms of gameplay, while gameplay in reality is something that made all those good old-school fps games actually good, don't you think? Just adding features like "bunnyhop", "rocketjump" and etc. in an incredibly dull game is not enough to make it "oldschool". All that is said, it's really not the game's fault, nor the creator's. It's the same deal as with Gone Home, which wasn't a bad game on its own, untill people started raising up the bars of expectation on other people, and this game is just another victim of this hype. I guess it's an okay "game" to play at work from time to time, considering you have almost no time to play bigger games. Or for any other reason, it's an okay time sinker, as if there is not enough out there already. But this is still a huge let-down. Hopefully, DUSK will be there to save oldschool gaming and restore its dignity.

30162630.review:
This is the perfect arcade game, and it only could have been fully realized on PC. Rather than a convoluted storyline or intricate game mechanics, Devil Daggers presents you with a very simple control scheme and only one goal; survive. Pro tip: You can't. This game will challenge anyone for the first few hundred tries, and by then, you'll be hooked.
The learning curve is steep, and the enemies a sadistically hard- Just the way I like it.
No matter what kind of gamer you are, or what genre you prefer, this game belongs in your library. It's affordable, can suck up hours of your time, and can run on almost anything, barring (Most) calculators.
Why are you still reading this? You should be trying to beat your high score right now!

30159971.review:
Devil Daggers is one of those games where you can physically feel your progress. No artificial level up systems. No arbitrary acheivements. It's just pure progress in your own personall skill and knowledge.

Your first run will last around 15-30 seconds, usually from an unexpected skull behind you. You eventually learn what to listen for so you can anticipate the enemies. Then you start mastering the shooting mechanics of the game. Then you start memorizing the spawning patterns. Then you start strategizing what enemies to shoot first. Next thing you know, you're already lasting over 2 minutes on each run.

This game is ridiculously frustrating, but it's such a rewarding test of dexterity and on-the-dot strategy. I wholly recommend this game, especially at its low price (it's even 50% off at the time of this writing!).

30158959.review: It's like a FPS version of Geometry Wars in Hell

30153155.review:
Mając dłoń, dwa tryby strzelania i ograniczony teren umrzesz szybko lub pożyjesz wystarczająco długo by zrozumieć, że minuta to dość sporo. 90 sekund to już zgłodnieć można. 

Gra wydawać może się prosta. Strzelamy i giniemy na arenie, na której pojawiają się wrogowie. Jak jednak jest to podane! Przede wszystkim fajna, oldskulowa grafika. Wrogowie z klimatów Cthulu, dźwięki na bardzo wysokim poziomie. 

By przeżyć trzeba nie tylko strzelać, ale także być w ciągłym ruchu. Tempo jest dość wysokie co sprawia, że w pewnym momencie czujemy się jakbyśmy tańczyli. 

Co mnie zaskoczyło to fakt, że broń ma swoją balistykę. Będąc w pędzie, strzelając do pędzących pod innym kątem, na innych wysokościach wrogów musimy celować z odpowiednim wyprzedzeniem. 

W tych samych momentach sprawdzają się różne taktyki, broń można upgradować, są rocketjumpy i więcej. Gra jest więc dość urozmaicona. 

Dobre dla tych co chcą się na chwilkę rozerwać i dla tych co chcą się sprawdzić i przeżyć legendarne 500 sekund.

30132943.review:
... Where to begin?

Shall I tell you of the crackling cackle of skeletal monstrosities as they fade beneath the fury of the blades? Shall I speak of the scratching of the spiders' cries against my eardrums? Shall I try to convey the crumbling tremors as a centipede burrows beneath the floor of the arena, making a sound like the breaking of the earth itself?

Or shall I confess to the visions that came to me as I tried to sleep the second night after purchasing this game, of screaming skulls diving towards me, startling my body awake with a panicked twitch?

It's a perfectly satisfying portrait of FPS heaven and/or hell. You and your daggers against an infinite onslaught of enemies. No permanent upgrades. No unlocks. Everything you do in a run stays in that run. Could have been some sort of stat upgrade system. There isn't.

This game makes me feel weak and naked and afraid. And I love it to death and beyond.

30128439.review:
A satisfying gameplay loop.

Devil Daggers is a pure survival FPS where you're tasked with surviving as long as possible against a demonic horde, with large devils spawning swarms of skulls and bugs to beset you. You have two "guns", a rapid-fire stream of daggers and a quick shotgun like burst you activate with a double-click. You don't run out of ammo. You just try to control the crowd swarming you and eliminate the larger devils before they make it worse. Then you die, respawn, and try again. There is no progress, no advancement, no real change despite the increasing variety and deadliness of the devils.

That all said, it's a very solid little loop of gameplay, owing to the excellent sound design (giving you an aural cue as to the devils around you and their proximity) and the quick nature of the game play. Right now I have the top of my awfully wide Steam friends list at ninety-nine seconds of survival. There's an achievement at five hundred, but I never expect to see it.

If you're up for a punishing, simple, FPS experience loop of gameplay excellently done, this is worth your time. It is exactly as advertised and nothing more, but is priced to match that.

30107717.review:
Наверное, многие люди интересуются, каким же образом можно повысить свою эффективность в плане очков в Devil Daggers.  Конечно же, каждый стремится к блистательным высотам, но, как известно, жизнь является весьма несправедливой штукой, в которой некоторым людям приходится закладывать ростовщику свой велосипед, чтобы взять напрокат костюм и отправиться в гости к семейству малоизвестных  дантистов.  Там, во время скромного банкета, нет ничего лучше, чем сметать со стола все имеющиеся блюда. И хоть поданное мясо вполне себе может быть второсортным, его зачастую достаточно, чтобы набить свой желудок и не умереть с голода. Благо, взятый на вечер костюм позволяет проворачивать такие вещи, оставаясь в глазах других достойным человеком с 500 или даже 600 очками, который может заработать себе на ужин. Просто иногда бывает и такое, что очередная неловко брошенная в гортань буханка хлеба может встать поперек горла, превратив все происходящее в какой-то нелепый фарс. Тогда, ты скорей всего опозоришься в приличном обществе, ведь вместо презентабельного поведения тебе останется только лишь размахивать руками в разные стороны и краснеть от недостатка кислорода. Такие вещи обычно ставят крест на всем положении в социуме, раскрывая позорные 100 очков.

Конечно же, наем дорогих тренеров может повысить успешные результаты с 200 секунд до 300, но мой личный консультант в этом плане настроен весьма пессимистично. Будучи беженцем из Польши  он, как и многие другие его соотечественники, достаточно сильно настрадался за свою жизнь, что не может не сказываться на его прогнозах. И хоть он держит малоприметную конторку рядом с бильярдным клубом, я думаю, он вполне себе знает, о чем говорит. Он с трезвым профессионализмом оценивает всю ситуацию, добросовестно проводя анализ мастерства. Мы потратили многие часы на разработку уникальных методик и стратегий, но на данном этапе, мы решили довольствоваться тем, что есть, сделав вывод, что лучше всего будет вернуться к этому вопросу чуть позже. У нас, так сказать, образовался достаточно надежный деловой тандем, который позволяет ощутить твердую почву под ногами, способную стать хорошим поприщем для будущего развития.

И хоть многие люди спокойно могут добиться показателей в 400 или 500, до сих пор неизвестно, стоит ли действительно спускать свои сбережения  или брать кредиты на дорогих наставников и аналитиков, обещающих поднять эффективность. Закладывание недвижимости или активов для покупки качественной консультации, конечно же, может принести плоды, но как мне кажется, подобные вещи вполне себе могут быть надувательством. Ведь, в конце концов, никакой специалист не позволит нарастить потенциал сверх меры. Тщательно продуманной стратегией он только лишь способен раскрыть его, но никак не приумножить, вмиг обратив 100 очков в 600 или даже 700.

30069331.review:
Basically: this game is perfect if it's what you're into. It's fast-paced survival action against skulls, skulls with horns, skulls with tentacles that spawn the skulls and skulls with horns, giant skulls with spider legs that spawn miniature skulls with spider legs, and rarely non-skull related enemies. All of which fly at you from pitch blackness, faster than you can run, and instakill you. You must survive as long as possible against Mr. Skeltals forces, armed only with Satan's Kitchen Knives.

This is one of those rare examples of a game that has managed to pack in a lot of addicting fun into a small price ($5, though it was on sale when I got it) and low hardware requirements (good for me because my computer is crap). If you're somebody who likes games that actually press you to stay on the move, keep your ears as open as your eyes, and most of all develop insane twitch aiming, this is for you. Expect to get good, very good, if you want to get far in this game. Conventional tactics typically used in easier modern survival video games will not work, enemies are too fast and varied in movement patterns to kite or camp. You will kill or be killed. If you're not the type of person who likes that, don't bother, I'm sure there's a ~$60 (plus ~$60 of "DLC") hand-holding "AAA" game out there for you. 

The only downside is that the gameplay is short and only has one map(an incredibly simplistic one at that) and enemy spawn pattern(the spawn pattern is actually pretty intense). Though I guess you could consider that a good side: for $5 this game makes a very nice, short, but replayable gameplay experience. It's a very good game for attempting to rise the world leaderboards, compete with friends, or even just for trying to get a new personal best. Also personally I really like the style, visually the game does a very good job of hitting that pixelated arcade look while also being a little spooky with its abyssal horror theme. The sound is well done too, every enemy makes unique sounds, this is why using your ears in this game are so important. I do not recommend playing it without headphones.

29522721.review:
This is easily one of the strangest first person shooters I've ever played, and that's awesome.

Taking an "old school" style and turning it into a haunting, atmospheric piece of art is an impressive feat in and of itself. This game drips with a disconcerting and dangerous atmosphere you just can't really find in giant AAA titles. Somehow they turned old school looking Quake 1 style graphics into a visual statement that's frightening and exciting to blast through.

This is not your typical first person shooter. I'm not sure if this genre has a name but the gameplay falls somewhere in line with the movies Groundhog Day or Edge of Tomorrow, only you know...in hell or something. There isn't really a level it's just a flat plain wrapped in darkness. Demonic enemies appear all around you some on a timer and some triggered by the death of other enemies (I think), and you simply try to survive as long as you can through wave after wave. This sounds simple except that I basically garuntee you the first time you play you'll die within the first 5 seconds. 

Then you simply respawn and try again. The enemies more or less will spawn in the same way they did before you and you use your knowledge of previous runs to help you along, but rest assured this game is painfully difficult. Success is measured in "Seconds that you survived" and watching better players replays (a built in feature of the game) will only make you want to try again, over and over. 

Seriously the amount of sweat you'll shed just to add a few seconds to your best time is a testament to how fun this game actually is. 

Give this deceptively complex game a try!

29511252.review:
This is one o' them "deceptively simple" contraptions you hear about on the news. 

Easiest way to describe this game is "first-person Geometry Wars." High skill ceiling, easy to learn. The game takes place on a relatively small platform that you strafe and circle around while floating skulls trail and chase you. That's not to say the game isn't dynamic, however, as new types of skulls and "daggers" (spawners) are slowly introduced that all require their own unique approach and strategy. 

Your score is determined by how many seconds you survive, and honestly if you're not interested in competing for high scores among friends or the world, you may not find much to entertain yourself here. But if you do like games built around high score challenges, this game is almost perfect because of its bite-sized game durations and a natural progression of difficulty that makes it easy to play it over and and over and notice yourself slowly getting better at the game without even being very intentional about it.

29510821.review:
Devil Daggers is an incredibly challenging and refreshingly old school first person shooter that does not advertise itself as such, therefore you know you can trust it. I actually would classify this game as an "experiemental indie title" similar to games such as Hylics, Hotline Miami and Void & Meddler. It REALLY does have that sort of atomosphere for me. 

The graphics style is a mix of Doom, Quake, an old VHS tape, and the inside of Satans brain. The art style is slightly minimalistic and the mosnter designs remind me of Shadow Of The Colossus and maybe even. . . Brutal Legend? It's so hard to even classify, the monsters definitley look absoulutely stunning either way. 

Devil Daggers gameplay is placed purely on skill and nothing else. There is no upgrade tree, no item shop, no story, no world building, no multiplayer. There IS however a scoreboard. For some people that is a turn off (However that 4.99 price point definitely was a turn on for me) and those people need to understand that this game is NOT for someone who loves competiveness or perhaps even someone who likes the old FPS games. Its difficulty is staggering (very reminiscent of Dark Souls, or God Hand, you must take time to hone your skills or this game will punish you brutally) and it only has one arena. Everything is smooth, quick and fluid, as is death. It will come very often so prepare yourself.

All in all, play it. It's literally 5 bucks, it's super fun, and hell, why not? 9/10 easily. If you want some gameplay to play in the background on your Youtube channel while you talk about some edgy subjects then this is one of your best bets.

29431449.review:
You are in an arena, you shoot endless waves of skulls with hand magic, you dodge the endless waves of skulls over and over as more things made of skulls appear, you die with one hit, you hit R and the game resets, you try to get a higher score, forever, and ever, and ever, and...

Devil Daggers is one of the most niche FPS games I've played in a long time. It is something you will likely understand in about 10 seconds and then it is purely down to player skill regarding if you survive. The premise is there is a "devil dagger" (I think?) and once you pick that up you can shoot magical bullet things from your hand. You transport into a circular arena with a deadly drop at the edges and then an eternal wave of enemies begins to pour in, from skulls, spires made of skulls, spiders made of skulls, snakes made of skulls, other types of skull related things come in, skulls, skulls, skulls! You shoot the skulls, and that is it. As a result its simplicity will no doubt be off-putting to many: it appears shallow both in its enemy variety and weaponry (magic hand, that is it) and the fact there is no easily defined plot. This simplicity is Devil Daggers strength, it does very few things, but that which it does do is VERY well done. If there is any comparison to make it would be a Serious Sam arena stripped of all the level design fluff leaving only the bare combat, making you scoot about prioritising enemies and considering when to fire and when to not fire, when to use the basic magic machine gun attack or hold off for a second for a single magic shotgun burst, or when to stop firing altogether to make the power-ups  fly to you. Everything is fast, instinctual and reactionary and for that it is possibly one of the most bullshit free FPS games I think I've played in many, many years.

The simplicity of Devil Daggers makes me hold back from saying I advise it. I conditionally advise it. It is so basic that you will either love it or hate it.
Do you like FPS? If the answer is no, stop.
Do you like realism? If the answer is yes, stop.
Do you need deep narrative? If the answer is yes, stop.
Do you like twitchy, fast paced games? If the answer is no, stop.
Do you like score attack games with no real greater purpose than just fulfilling your need to have an endorphin rush, something to sink time into now and then rather than a long and meaningful experience that the games industry seems to keep pushing? If the answer is yes, maybe this is the game for you.

Just remember, if you stop moving, you die.

In this game, you play as a jello man who has just found his mother's magical oven mitt. Our jello-like protagonist is thrown into the ninth layer of hell for his sins. There, he must fight demons. While playing as Jello Man you will inevitably be swarmed, but watch out don't back up too much, you might fall off of the post it sized platform you're on. 29388703.review:
Think you're good at FPS games?
Devil Daggers will completely destroy your confidence.

It is as raw an FPS as you're likely to get. There are very few of the tropes that most FPS games carry as baggage. In Devil Daggers...there's no map, no health kits, no lives, no continues, no save points, no plot... and no escape.

You have death constantly rain down on you and swirl around you. You fire back with daggers to hold them off.... and that's IT. 

You will be lucky to last a minute before death finds you and ends your game.

...and you will play it again and again and again. Much like the arcade games of old, it's easy to play - and near impossible to master. The difficulty is brutal and unforgiving... which makes it great for a high-score challenge, and great as a casual game that you don't want to invest much time into (not that it will let you anyway!)

After suffering death and reincarnation over and over again.... you will have a religious experience. Your mind will become Zen. You will FEEL where those skulls are behind your back without even seeing them. You will be at one with the force, and then... only then.... you might last an entire **three minutes** before dying!

Devil Daggers has the best impression of hell that I've seen in a video game. Visually, sonically, and stylistically, it is downright evil... and to top it off the gamplay is addictive while being utterly merciless. Most soul crushing of all is being able to witness replays of the uber-humans who have survived past 500 seconds on the leaderboard.

Why am I dying to live, if I'm only living to die?

I literally cannot recommend this game enough to anyone reading this review. All I want is to keep climbing the leaderboard. With great effort, I have achieved near top 3%, but I always want to get better.

For example, it occured to me that the game spawns a spider demon very early in the game, around 30 or 40 seconds, and not again until about 140, at which point it spawns several at once. 29056034.review:
Maximum fun per cent

I really love this game. Usually i don't care about highscores in games, but this game got it right.
The game will put your skills to a hard, hard test while it gives you a movement-system, which is very fluid and precise.
I love this movement-sytem to death, i could bunnyhop, strafe-  and rocketjump all day and night in this game.

The game is very predictable, meaning that every enemy appears to a specific time, but everything happens so fast, when you do something slightly different, faster, slower or in different order, you will have an different outcome you'll have to deal with. To me this game always manages to challange me and i always want to optimize a little more so i can squeeze out a few seconds more.

The game can also be very frustrating and sometimes you get a feeling like, "omg, this is to much!!!!" But it pisses you off in a way, you wan't to continue, well at least it worked for me, the last session i had, i found myself playing this game for about 4 hours, never felt bored for 1 minute. Mostly because of that fluid movement-system and because it feels so good to wreck these fools. After all, it is a very rewarding yet simple game, with hidden complexity underneath it.

The graphics, they are done pretty good i think. It's an very cohesive artstyle. I especially love how the animations/pixels melt into each other, if that makes sense... very fluid again. The colors are picked well, giving it a dark but also colorfull feel.
Sometimes i have a hard time to maintain my overview, when a lot is going on, because of the pixely graphics itself, but it ain't all that bad. After all in my opinion they got a very good art direction, which helps the overall feel of the game.

The sounddesign is also something with thought behind it. It can be very minmalistic, but you wan't to have it that way, so you can hear where the enemies are and what they are doing at any given time. It has this sick and transdimensional vibe to it. The first weapon sounds weak to me but the the other ones, oh my god, they sound like a device invented in collaboration by satan and cthulhu. Very punchy and weird in a cool way.
	
So if you like your challange and a game which can be played in short burst or if you are an addict like me for hours upon hours, for 5 Dollar you can't go wrong!

This game is the perfect waiting aid. Installing a big game and don't to use a lot of processing power? Devil Daggers. Waiting to join a friend in a multiplayer lobby when their match ends? Devil Daggers. Have a few minutes to kill but not enough to play longer games? Devil Daggers. Don't know what else to play? Devil Daggers.

It's a fast, action packed game of endurance that pits you against an endless stream of demonic monsters in an attempt to squeeze a few more seconds onto your high score. You'll be using a lot of fps tactics of old as you bunny hop, strafe, and dagger jump around the map in order to gain an edge. Your weapon has two fire modes that allow you to either cut through hoards of enemies like butter, or go in for a takedown. As you might have guessed from my choice of words, this game is immensely satisfying to play once you get the gameplay down.

If you enjoy punishing games with permadeath with the sole objective being to survive as long as you can and getting the highest possible score, this could be for you.

The gameplay and mechanics are solid and I can definitely see the appeal of it. However for me the game is just far too frustrating. I find it very difficult to aim since there's no crosshair and the very low resolution art style makes it difficult to see. I understand that's on purpose and adds to the challenge but to me it just adds frustration. There's no hp or lives so one single hit from any enemy will have you instantly killed and you have to start over again with the same set enemy patterns which only change in initial spawn position, and after an hour I find this gets really repetitive. I also find the visuals very drab and uninsteresting, but that's just personal taste. If you like very monotonous, lovecraftian themes you might enjoy them.

I am an avid FPS player, I love old school FPS like DOOM and Quake and even monster boxes like Serious Sam but those games offer much more variety and are nowhere near as punishing as this. It's not a bad game and you may like it, but it is a niche game and you'll know whether this is the type of game for you or not.

28849568.review:
What a game.

With nostalgic PS1-style graphics and sounds, and basic but exciting and enjoyable gameplay, this is as good an ode to old-style gaming as you will find.

The concept is simple: fire endless streams of daggers at endless hordes of various demons until one kills you. As time goes on, more demons will begin to spawn around you. That's it. This sounds monotonous but the sheer difficulty and unforgiving nature of this game means that you die over and over and over again but you don't get frustrated and you don't get bored. I say unforgiving, the arena is relatively small and there are often more than fifty of these demons to contend with. Take into account the fact that one touch from any enemy will end your run, and it is clear to see how this game would be a tough one.

Regardless, it's dirt cheap, the controls are as simple as they come, (requiring the use of just WASD, Space, and the mouse) and the atmosphere the game creates, especially when played in the dark with headphones on, is incredible- one of the best I've ever experienced in any video game. Each demon has its own individual 'cry,' meaning the player knows, if they listen carefully, which demons are in the arena at the given time, and more importantly, where they are.

This is without doubt my single favourite release of 2016, definitely my vote for game of the year. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this to anybody.

Review: 9/10 -This game is absolute hell... And I love it.
Graphics: Very good. Love the art-style and rendering they chose to go with. seems like Devil May Cry in a 199X shooter.
Gameplay: Instant classic. Reminiscent of the old days with Doom, Quake, Hexen and Heretic.
Soundtrack: Meh. Only realized there's a song in the main menu, needs a Devil May Cry/Metal soundtrack!


Basics: Old-School shooter WASD movement and mouse shooting.
Mechanics: Hold left mouse button for full-auto fire and press left mouse button for shotgun blasts.
Aiming down and shotgun blasting causes "Rocket-jump" boosts.

Shoot the weak-spots of everything and collect red gems, after 10 red gems, your Devil Daggers upgrade.
After a few more gems they upgrade again. Be careful of different enemy types and take them out in tactical order of which is most threatening. Survive for over 500 Seconds to beat the game!


Story is weak, but could be as follows:
Imagine you're a young sorceror/sorceress who has been experimenting with black magic and portals and one day, you wake up someplace you definitely did not go to sleep the night before. You look around the room and find yourself on a big, floating platform. Your agility is great as ever but you feel a strong, dark energy from the center of the room... 

The Devil Dagger you have read all about in your books, said to cause great power and torment, is right in front of you... You know that once you pick it up, you will be hunted, but also have the power to fight back. 

Your Book of Shadows tells you that once you touch the dagger, you will have to survive for at least 8 minutes or you will be right back where you started, this will forever loop until you defeat the clock and then, then you will be free.

28779140.review:
okay, first of all- this is probably the hardest game I've ever played, and that's coming from someone who's beaten Supermeatboy and HotlineMiami 1&2. That said, it's also one of the best games I've ever played. I would describe it as a hardcore arcade game for people who enjoy first-person shooters. Because that's essentially what this game is- an arcade game- since the only object of the game is to beat your previous highscore. Theres no levels, you're always on the same huge platform floating in the middle of a black void. There's also nothing in the way of a storyline, but I think that was intentional, to emphasize how gameplay-driven this game really is. You can tell that a lot of effort was put into perfecting the physics- running, strafing, jumping, and rocket jumping feel seamless. The game makes you feel like a worthless weakling every time an enemy kills you in one hit, yet God-like when you've upgraded your weapon a bit, and you rocket jump around the map like a gleeful idiot, just absolutely shredding through enemies. The level of difficulty in this game is relentless, and if you're up for a challenge (which you should be) it'll drive you to get better. And once you're good at this game, you enjoy it all the more. I've put about 10 hours in to this game so far, and I can anticipate puttin in many many more in the future.

IT'S A FUCKIN 10/10 GG

28609360.review:
I can picture the demographic that this game is perfect for. I'm definitely not in there.

I have to say that I really respect the design of the game. It's is minimalist and laser focused. The aesthetic is consistent and inventive. But the combination of low fidelity and flat colors makes it difficult to read. The sound design is impressive. It's atmospheric and effective, but it's also oppressive and really difficult for me to listen to for more than a few minutes. The shooting fails me, too. It's feels ineffective and imprecise and the gradual upgrades are trickled out in a way that only lets you keep up with the flood, never feel ahead.

I respect all of that, but I can't remember a game that I bounced off of so hard. The degree of aggressive dislike I have for this game is actually fascinating to me.

Unless you already know this is the kind of game you want, do not play it.

[h1]殺り方は自由。自分の腕と運だけが生き延びる術。[/h1]

内容はただただ狂ったように襲ってくる化物をダガーで倒すだけ。
このゲームは"PLAY" "LEADERBOARDS" "OPTIONS"という3つの選択肢しかない。
HUDやFPSでお馴染みのダッシュや照準は無し。出来るのはジャンプぐらい。
攻撃の仕方は機関銃並のダガーを撃つかか散弾にして撃つことになる。
最初は30~40秒で大体終了してしまう。敵に当たれば一撃で死ぬことになるからだ。
このゲームはFPS特有のバニーホップとTF2でおなじみのロケットジャンプをして倒して行くことになる。
一つのミスが簡単にプレイヤーを殺してくるので200秒以上を目指すなら戦略を立ててやる必要がある。
実績は一つだけで[spoiler]500秒以上行かないと[/spoiler]取ることは出来ない。
他の人のプレイ中の内容も見ることで戦略を考えて行くことができる。
全ては自分の腕次第。魑魅魍魎というのが相応しい大量の敵にどう立ち向かうのか。
難易度が高くて、挑戦的なゲームがやりたいならこのゲームが一番だ。

28501146.review:
[h1]Описание игры:[/h1]
Динамичный аренный шутер от первого лица в визуальной стилистике всеми любимой первой "Quake". Перед нами маленькая арена за пределами которой лишь тьма. На нас начинают наступать орды монстров которых мы отстреливаем и пытаемся как можно дольше выжить. Каждую секунду монстров становится все больше, также растет и их разнообразие. У нас в наличии лишь один тип оружия которое может стрелять очередью, дробью и спец атакой. После смерти крупных монстров остаются кристаллы, собирая которые мы можем улучшить силу нашего оружия. Так и проходит вся игра. Стреляем, убиваем, умираем, начинаем заново.

[h1]Плюсы:[/h1]
¥ Очень динамичный хардкорный геймплей.
¥ Атмосферный саундтрек и звук.
¥ Большое разнообразие монстров.
¥ Глобальная рейтинговая таблица где можно посмотреть записи боев любого игрока.
¥ Множество тактик для успешного прохождения (стрелять рикошетом, прыгать в воздух и отстреливаться, стрелять дробью, уничтожать генераторы монстров или нет и тп).

[h1]Минусы:[/h1]
¥ Нет абсолютно никакого сюжета.
¥ Достижения (в игре всего одна ачивки для которой на арене нужно выжить довольно продолжительное время).
¥ Минимализм в графике. Атмосферно конечно, но видеть вокруг темную пустоту начинает раздражать.
¥ Всего один тип арены.

[h1]Итог:[/h1]
От этой игры трудно оторваться. Умираем и снова в бой чтобы продержаться дольше хоть на пару секунд. Лишь через несколько часов игра немного отпускает. Качественная арена, которой не хватает кооператива и небольшого разнообразия карт. Но и без этого все на достойном уровне. Рекомендую.

[h1]Оценка: 7/10[/h1]

[h1]Послесловие:[/h1]
Если вам понравился этот обзор добро пожаловать в группу
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/uojer - тут вы сможете увидеть рекомендованные мною игры, другие обзоры, а также просто пообщаться в хорошей компании.

28432922.review:
[table][tr][td][url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/MentorPixel]Mentor Píxel[/url] - [i]El medio interactivo como entretenimiento inteligente[/i][/td][/tr][/table]

Por la presente en esta auspiciosa reseña, permítame usted insinuar la naturaleza de este título tan simple. Será uno invitado a danzar eternamente con entidades horridas en exuberancia, hasta el momento del roce mortal que interrumpe el baile con el abrupto deceso del jugador.

[i]Devil Daggers[/i] toma inspiración en los shooters de acción vertiginosa de los años 90, colocando al jugador en una arena en mitad de un ominoso limbo, el cual proyecta entidades lovecraftianas a fin de hostigar al jugador mediante una persecución perpetua; una  danza mortal en el cual el jugador irá armado de un arsenal infinito de dagas mágicas que despide ya sea a modo de proyectiles, como también un disparo único y potente. Eventualmente, la cacería concluye con uno siendo finalmente acorralado y se establece un contacto físico que desencadena en la muerte del mismo. [i]Devil Daggers[/i] se luce como un interminable ensayo, de una partida que jamás se va a completar.

[h1]Ecos del pasado[/h1]
Gráficamente evocando al [i]Quake[/i] original del ‘96, el juego luce un apartado gráfico que le hace distinción, y como título que se respeta a sí mismo, sobre él flamea la bandera del diseño por sustracción, haciendo gala en el escenario vacío ―no interactivo― que solo sirve para circular en evasiva, enemigos que solo siguen un patrón simple, y una interfaz inexistente, todo en pos de la inmersión del jugador, evitando todo aquellos que interfiera con la fluidez y sumersión atmosférica.

Completamente carente de argumento o contexto sobre la mesa, [i]Devil Daggers[/i] hace reminiscencia al género retro en el cual se inspira, volviendo a las raíces, a la infancia de la industria como medio lúdico para la diversión y entretenimiento del consumidor, sin necesidad de una justificación narrativa. [i]Devil Daggers[/i] es, en esencia, un título destinado a los amantes del género first-person shooter en su época dorada.

Carente de música o banda sonora, lo único a oír será el interminable eco producido por los rápidos cazadores mientras se acercan y alejan del jugador, todo esto acompañado del impacto de las dagas que de pocas pausas constará. No solo eso, sino que el título hace gala de un sonido envolvente diseñado exclusivamente para cascos, con los cuales uno podrá conocer la posición de los enemigos al oír de donde vienen. Dicho eco perpetuo se irá acentuando conforme a más enemigos aparezcan en pantalla, plasmando una melodía demencial en la mente del jugador.

[h1]Las matices del desafío[/h1]
De jugabilidad simple y rápida, tan intuitiva como le sea posible, con la posibilidad de ajustar el FOV para complementarla a elección, esta fue concebida para sentirse como aquella maniobrabilidad de los años ’90; en [i]Devil Daggers[/i] la única diferencia resta sobre la falta de armamento o equipo disperso por el escenario, pues nada de aquello se encontrará aquí. El protagonista dispone únicamente de sus dagas mágicas y su única manera de mejorarlas es la absorción de cristales que están incrustados a enormes enemigos y actúan de puntos débiles, por lo que uno debe abrir fuego sin perder puntería a la vez que esquiva a incontables hordas de entidades menores.

Los cristales irán mejorando el desarrollo de la partida a nuestro favor, siendo el único requisito para atraerlos tal cual imán el dejar de disparar, a medida que se obtengan el protagonista irá haciendo gala de habilidades especiales con las cuáles la dificultad en el aspecto de manejo se verá reducida, mas no la dificultad del escenario, pues este irá elevando su dificultad progresivamente, añadiendo más enemigos y nuevas entidades de mayor complejidad a un ritmo sin pausas; sin contar con el hecho de que ciertas entidades se harán con dichos cristales si no se eliminan a tiempo y con las hordas menores siendo una constante. 
Es aquí cuando entra en juego la capacidad del jugador de manipular la dificultad mediante la priorización, puesto que cada enemigo requiere una aproximación diferente a un ritmo distinto, y al haber varios tipos de ellos en pantalla, el orden de acciones lo cambia todo.

Pero la adición de estos elementos no es proceduralmente. El juego posee cierto esquema de puzle. Puesto que las partidas están orquestadas desde el vamos, la posición de los enemigos principales y su aparición es algo que no cambiará, por lo que cada partida se sentirá como un acertijo, una combinación de movimientos y acciones a realizar en un momento dado a medida que los segundos pasen, gatillando la entrada en escena de cada entidad horrida. El título requiere tanto reflejos, como memoria y rapidez mental.

[h1]Diseño[/h1]
Una de las cosas más importantes que [i]Doom[/i], entre otros, dejaron a la industria fue un esquema de diseño al cual el diseñador Harvey Smith denominó como [i]Diferenciación Ortogonal de Unidades[/i] que, expresado de una manera sencilla, significa que los enemigos son propietarios de particularidades únicas, siendo el diseño y programación de cada uno independiente del otro. Por lo que Smith concluye que gracias a esto, el jugador, comienza a actuar intencionalmente, realizando decisiones significativas y estratégicas en lugar de solo reaccionar al azar a lo que aparece en pantalla. 

Ya no se trata de esquivar y disparar; uno es forzado a deliberar cada movimiento de manera estratégica o de lo contrario no resistirá. Los enemigos gozan de un ampliamente variado diseño y esquema de patrones a analizar; atributos únicos que al ser memorizadas le otorgan el control de la situación al jugador. Todo lo anteriormente dicho se aleja de los títulos de hoy en día, cuya escala de enemigos es básicamente, la adición de mayor resistencia, acompañada de mayor daño, o simplemente, mayor número.

[i]Devil Daggers[/i] realiza un correcto uso de este diseño, pues para acabar con ciertos enemigos se deben atacar los cristales que tienen incrustados, y el número de estos varía según el objetivo, lo que desencadena en decisiones de priorización. Esto le da a nuestros compañeros de baile un sello distintivo que hace de la danza mortal algo más que solo ponerse a esquivar, y es, ponerse a pensar.

[h1]Bailando al compás de los números[/h1]
Básico, amigable y de fácil manejo, su esquema de controles puede ajustarse para complacer al jugador. Aunque carente de interfaz, esta puede activarse con una tecla; dicha interfaz opcional no es más que un cronómetro que marcará nuestro tiempo de supervivencia en el escenario.

Este cronómetro, aunque no lo parezca, es extremadamente útil, puesto que al estar todo orquestado, ―como si de un puzle se tratase― el tener un ojo sobre el lapso transcurrido desde el inicio le permite al jugador predecir el siguiente acto de la obra macabra del juego en pos de adecuar su estrategia tanto a la posición de los actuales objetivos, como el de los que están por hacer presencia.

[h1]¿Lo hizo bien?[/h1]
[i]Devil Daggers[/i] tomó las referencias correctas y las puso en práctica de manera impecable, dando así, su mejor versión posible en base a su contenido, posiblemente la falta de este le condene a largo plazo, pero su carisma actual es suficiente para hacerle a uno volver al desafío a pesar del paso del tiempo. Lo más llamativo resulta ser el hecho de que haya tomado prestado mucho de antiguas obras de culto y les haya sabido quitar todo aquello que esta obra no necesitaba, garantizando además la dosis correcta de todo lo ya implementado.

[table][tr][td][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9059978]Seguir a Mentor Píxel para más análisis y reseñas[/url][/td][/tr][/table]

엄청 심플한 FPS 게임이다. 간단히 말해 가능한 한 오래 살아남는 걸 목표로하는 게임인데, 계속해서 나타나는 적을 탄창없는 무한한 원거리 공격으로 무찔르며 살아남아야한다.
하지만 플레이어가 한 방 맞으면 사망이기 때문에, 적을 제때 못 잡고 넘쳐나게 냅두면 감당이 안되서 죽을 수 밖에 없다. 난이도야 상대적인 거겠지만, 13종류의 적이 나타난다는데 나는 두 번째 적이 나타날 쯔음에 벌써 적을 감당하기가 힘들었다.
솔직히 나같은 FPS초보에게는 별로 오래 붙잡고 싶은 생각이 안 드는 듯 하다. 더 해봐야 실력도 안 늘 것 같고.. 하지만 하드코어한 FPS버티기 게임을 원하는 실력자 플레이어에게는 나쁘지 않은 게임일 것 같다.
잘하려면 뛰어난 순발력과 민첩성이 필요할 듯?
특징적인 것으로 기괴한 분위기도 인상적이지만, 난이도에 압도당해서 분위기는 신경도 안 쓰인다. 주인공캐릭터의 공격은 무슨 마법인지 뭘 쏘는건지 잘 모르겠다.
트레일러를 보면 한방짜리 강한 공격도 있는 것 같은데 어떻게 사용하는지 모르겠다.

28305034.review:
Devil Daggers is a fantastic game. It blends such old, simple, and new ideas in such a way that I could almost call it perfect. However, I cannot recommend it to the average consumer who is actually looking to beat this game.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]

As you can tell, the game is a survival/bullet-hell first person shooter. The goal is as simple as it can be, to survive. The player must fight hordes and hordes of demonic skulls and other monsters to survive, and anything touched is an instant game over. The player can also fall off of the stage if they aren’t careful.

The controls are as expected, WASD keys to move, Space to jump, hold-click to fire a stream of daggers, and single-click to fire a shotgun like blast. You can also use techniques such as bunny hopping and dagger jumping (like rocket jumping) to improve your survivability. The controls are smooth for the most part, except for when in the air, mid-flight controls and momentum always feel a little off and can be hard to control. This is really the only fault of the gameplay.

The only way to improve your power is by collecting red gems, given by killing enemies. They naturally float towards you when you are not shooting. If you are using continuous fire, they will maintain their trajectory and potentially fly off the stage. If you use a shotgun blast, they will forcefully move away from you, so there a nice risk vs. reward system that adds a bit more depth to the game.

The main goal is to survive at least 500 seconds, which sounds so simple, yet is incredibly devious.

As the waves of enemies start coming and new baddies start to show up, it becomes quite clear that it is not an easy task. Each game only lasts so many minutes, and the process of repetitive deaths and refining one’s skills is how players must get better.

Luckily, with the leaderboards, if the eye symbol is clicked next to a player entry, the game will render their best run in real-time, so you can observe more experienced players as to how they progressed in-game.

There are certain points in the game where the player is thrown either something new or challenging that they can become walls. Learning to break down these walls can take much practice or even a change in strategy to overcome. Breaking them down to the point where you can breeze through that section of a run is a very satisfying feeling. This process sounds so simple and easy to maneuver, but keep in mind that it took me over 100 hours across four months to beat the game.

The game’s mechanics are rock solid, and achieve nearly everything they set out to do, specifically to provide a genuine challenge to the player. It’s to no surprise that the lead developer of the game was also behind [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/65300/]Dustforce[/url].

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]

The game clearly has a late-90’s, early 3D era level of aesthetics, and I feel that the art design is fantastic. The developer used multiple approaches such as simple models, crude draw distance, and unfiltered textures to achieve the level of authenticity they reached. It’s clear that the artist became familiar with the limitations of early-3D games and worked within those limitations to deliver something great.

The designs of the enemies are rather interesting, and as someone who has spent so much time with the game, they have a great amount of detail to them despite them being such low-poly models. The main boss especially looks excellent, as it has such an alien, chthonic design that it really amplifies the game’s intensity when you finally reach it. Even the player hand design is interesting, as how the game begins with only two fingers raised, and as you collect gems, each level up gives another finger until all five are raised. It was a great way to convey how powerful the player is without having to resort to a standard UI.

Also there isn’t even a model of the player character’s body, it is literally just a hand. Why? Because it’s not needed.

Other details I’ve noticed were how the squid spawners even have little nods to the design of the skull they spawn, and how the boss is basically a sick amalgamation of spiders, skulls, and squids. In addition, the Space Odyssey-like event that happens when you walk under the boss is amazing.

The whole game has a mysterious, Cthulhu-like vibe, somewhat similar to the first Quake, but also has its own feel and sense of doom and desolation. It seems that this self-imposed limitation of graphical fidelity worked out for the game rather well. This prowess over graphical limitations is why I feel some early 3D games such as Spyro The Dragon still hold up remarkably well.

[h1]Sound:[/h1]

The sound design is also no slouch whatsoever. There is no traditional soundtrack, in the sense that there are four pieces of music that play at various points outside the core game. Each track has its own purpose and each belong to different genres of music, yet they still all cater to the eeriness and creepiness that the aesthetics are going for.

The main audio that players will be hearing is the in-game sound effects/ambience, and might I say that the entire soundscape is incredible. Each entity in the game carries its own continuous sound, so that it becomes easy to sense how far/close it is in regards to your position. Please use headphones when playing this game, it makes the game much easier to play and progress through. For example, the muffled laughter of the charging skulls is very easy to pick out from the background, which is great design since the charging skulls are one of the few enemies that can outrun you and must be dealt with immediately.

Other sound effects are used to add a real kick to the gameplay, such as the screech that is heard when you shoot daggers with the second or third upgrade, which really makes you feel like you have the powers of a god and that using them even causes yourself to be pained.

All aspects of the audio design are fantastic, are used in a very practical way, and deliver an edge to the game over other games of its type.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]

This game is the embodiment of the phrase, “simple to play, difficult to master”. The game in itself is rather simple, yet every aspect of it is expertly polished. It shows true mastery in each of the developers’ craft. It’s clear that a three person team: a programmer, artist, and sound designer alone are enough to provide an engrossing experience.

But why have I listed the game as “Not Recommended”? It’s simply because I don’t recommend this game to the average person who will be reading this review. The game itself is of pure quality and its execution is remarkable, but in order to even see the majority of this game’s content, you need to fall under the less than 1% of players who are willing to spend dozens of hours on a five dollar game that is just survival with no plot.

If you are fine paying a few dollars to see some of the art assets and ambiance of the first few waves of the game, knowing that you will only go that far, go right ahead and purchase it. If you are willing to spend close to 100 hours trying to master the game and become one of the few dozen to beat it, go right ahead and purchase it. To literally anyone else, which I feel is the majority of my readers, I cannot recommend this game.

It’s not that I don’t want Sorath to be financially successful; it’s just that when they decided to develop such a game like Devil Daggers, they definitely would have expected much more of a niche audience. I wish the best for them regardless.

Thank you.

O jogo consiste em pontuação, ou seja, o principal objetivo é que você mate o maior número possível de demônios, batendo assim seus recordes pessoais assim como os dos outros (há uma pontuação global). Daí vemos simplicidade na sua construção, mas eficiente, pois é isso o que nos instiga a jogar constantemente a fim de melhorar nossas habilidades e conseguir a devida pontuação.

Os gráficos do jogo apesar de serem bastante peculiares, são muito bons. E é por justamente por terem esse toque original, peculiar que chama minha atenção positivamente. Há uma enorme fluidez tanto na movimentação em si quanto nas partículas, onde se vê na magia que sai das mão da personagem e no sangue que jorra das criaturas ao serem mortas. 

O jogo é muito atmosférico, o que dá muita emoção ao jogá-lo. A composição sonora em um todo é excelente, dando-lhe uma profunda imersão no ambiente que, apesar de simples, lhe traz sensações diverdas com os sons das criaturas que lhe rodeiam. 

Por fim, apesar de simples, Devil Daggers é um excelente jogo que cumpre demais seu objetivo. Lamento por ele não ter diferentes níveis de ambientações ou modos de jogos. Mas mesmo assim, vale a pena ser comprado para quem gosta dos gêneros que o compõe - FPS frenético, terror, etc.

Vejam no YouTube uma analise mais completa que fiz ao mesmo tempo em que jogo!

Espero que gostem!
