28226177.review:
Hotline Miami meets Doom in this extremely difficult first person arena shooter that places players in the pits of hell and forces them to survive for as long as possible.

The game is extremely bare bones and simple. The title screen is nothing more than Play, Leaderboards, and Options. When you play, there's only one thing in your vision. A glowing dagger. You pick it up and find that you can shoot the titular Devil Daggers from your fingers in an effort to survive in Hell for as long as possible.

This game has one achievement, and that's to survive for 500 seconds. Sounds simple enough, right? And really,the simplicity of everything is what makes this game work. You can move, jump, and shoot with either a constant stream of daggers or a shotgun like blast, good for close encounters. The spot on controls and simple but deep mechanics make this game the very definition of pick up and play. So what's the problem?

The problem is that Hell lives up to its name in this game. Starting with a wave of flying skull spawning demon pillar things, the game throws wave after wave of enemy hoards at you. You need to constantly be aware of your surroundings, as one hit from anything- ANYTHING AT ALL- and you're sent back to the beginning. And believe me when I say that surviving for even thirty seconds will test the skill of most players.

Much like the aforementioned Hotline Miami, though, the simplicity of the mechanics means that restarting after you die quickly becomes a "just one more try" play session and before you know it an hour has gone by. It's a difficult game to put down, that's for sure.

Special mention should be given to the aesthetics and sound. Monsters make horrifying noises that also let you know when they're near. Their deisgns are otherworldly and disturbing. Honestly, this is a more effective horror game than most others on the market.

And that's about it when it comes to this game. I've made it 88 or 89 seconds so far, and according to the leaderboards, that places me at about the 23000th best player in the world, ahead of almost 50000 others. That should tell you something about how tough this game is. But there's no other game out there that tests your skills with its mechanics and delivers such a pure and uncluttered action survival experience. It's not for everyone, but if it is for you, prepare to lose a lot of time mastering the game.

28001381.review:
A small, simple Quake-inspired score attack game. For the price of a large coffee you can simulate the effects of caffine addiction while feeling as vulnerable as the small, fleshy mortal you are. Score attack games thrive on strong repetition, and the challenge is to keep what's effectively the same thing over and over interesting for a long period of time. This is where Devil Daggers thrives. You have only a moment to appreciate the simulated software rendering and the way the pixelated lighting bounces off the ground, much as you do. You're too busy purging and purifying colossal eldritch pillars birthing clouds of skulls before the rams gore you and send you crumpling to the floor.

Be warned, however, that you need to really like old school shooters to enjoy this for any amount of time longer than 5 minutes. There's no story, no progression, no new things to unlock. The only thing motivating you is the act of playing, and the opportunity to beat whoever nudged 1ms ahead of you on the leaderboards. For someone like me, who holds Quake in an almost holy regard, this game is perfect, and ended up being my favorite shooter this year.

If you ask yourself the question "Doom clones?" at the risk of dating yourself in the video game zeitgeist and the answer is "Cool," this game will transform your face into a quivering pile of flesh-goo.

27989543.review:
Devil Daggers is an extremely pure gaming experience. The core game design is fairly similar to a classic arcade game - there is no way to progress except by learning the patterns and getting better at dealing with them. When you die, you start over. There's no "level 2" to reach, no checkpoints, no continues. Play until you lose, then try again from the beginning.

The game itself has the appearance of a mid-90s FPS, and all of the mechanics are implemented exceptionally well. Movement and shooting feels great, enemies have interesting swarming behavior, and the sound design is incredible. Each enemy type makes a unique sound, and with the positional audio you can often know exactly what enemies are present and where they are without even needing to see them.

Highly recommended for anyone that enjoys fast-paced FPSes and playing a game solely for the sake of improving at it. And if you can get some friends to play, competing with them on the leaderboards can be a lot of fun (especially since you can watch each other's replays).

死に覚えFPS。ひたすら死にまくる。

日本語は無いけど問題なし。
ひたすら敵を殺し、自分が殺されるゲームだからだ。
物語や、ゲーム内設定資料なども無く、とにかく戦うゲーム。

効果音が重要なゲームになっている。そのためBGMが無い。
敵の出現位置や、敵の接近具合が音で分かるようになっている。

敵に出現パターンがあるため、次に何が来るかの予測が可能。
いかにして立ち回るかがポイントとなる。

雑魚敵を先に倒すか、雑魚敵を大量に吐き出す塔を先に崩すか。
円を描くような移動をしつつ戦うか、なるべく動かず戦うか。
一撃死の緊張感の中、次から次へとプレイヤーに危機が迫る。

死んでも直ぐにリトライ出来るのがポイント。
ロードは一切無い。
そのため気が付くと、永延と遊んでいる。

私の最高記録は1分ちょっとだ。大抵は30～40秒ぐらいで死ぬ。
それにもかかわらずプレイ時間が伸びる一方である。
プレイヤーを中毒に陥れるゲームデザインのセンスが光る。

ゲーム内で見る事が出来るランキングでは、
他の人のリプレイ動画を見る事が出来る。
自己最高プレイが自動的にリプレイとして記録される。
自分のリプレイを見ると、良く生き残ったなぁと感心してしまう。
1位のリプレイ記録を見ると、ムリゲー感が強い。
私には到達不可能な領域だ(ちなみに私はFPSが下手)。

製作者はクリア出来たのだろうか。そもそもクリアはあるのだろうか。
そして今後このゲームを制覇するプレイヤーは現れるのだろうか。

マウスを手汗まみれにしながら、私は今後もちょこちょことプレイし続けるだろう。
レビューを読んでいるキミの神プレイを見せてくれ。是非とも参考にしたい。
そして、まだ見ぬコンマ数秒先の世界へ！

[h1] Do you want frustration on a level that is comparable to Super Meat Boy? [/h1]

This game definitely delivers on that factor. Key differences between this and Super Meat Boy is that this is an FPS and instead of levels, it's a survival game based on how long you can go untouched by all hell's spawn that is sent after you. 

Your choice of weapon is a hand that throws daggers. The more spawn you kill, the more gems you get. The more gems you get, the more daggers you can throw. 

This game is super hard, but while frustrating, a lot of fun if you're into the old school Quake-style shooter.
It's also extremely satisfying when you [i] finally [/i] beat your (or some of your friends' for that matter) highscore.

27737333.review:
Devil Daggers is an addictive FPS that is perfect for people who like chasing high scores.

The premise is simple. You start on a flat, dark arena and enemies begin to spawn. Kill them and avoid them. Get touched once and your dead. The longer you survive, the more overwhelming it gets. It almost becomes like a first-person bullet hell game. Your longest survive time is recorded on the leaderboard. The great gameplay and the urge to beat your previous time is what will keep you coming back.

The movement is fast and responsive. You can rocket jump and bunny hop. It's quite like 90s arena shooters.

Killing enemies and shooting feels good.

The game features a unique art style. Somewhat reminiscent of Quake but more demonic. The enemies design are creepy which compliments the intense gameplay.

Audio design is superb. The enemies all makes continuous, distinct noises. After playing for a while, you begin to realise that listening to where the enemies are is key to your survival.

You can also watch replays of other players through the leaderboard which is cool.

It's a fantastic little game available at a cheap price.

27729436.review:
[i]Devil Daggers[/i] es un gran juego. La anterior en una afirmación que no hago regularmente, pero este juego la merece.
¿Qué hay en él para que lo diga? Su [i]gameplay[/i]. No estoy desetimando a sus apartados gráfico ni sonoro. Ambos son impresionantes. Pero la verdadera razón por la que merece la pena jugar este juego son sus mecánicas. 
   [i]Devil Daggers[/i] es un [i]shooter[/i] en primera persona. Lo maravilloso de él es que implementa no sólo las mecánicas propias de su subgénero, sino también las de [i]shooters[/i] más tradicionales. Sí, la cámara presenta la acción en primera persona dejando ver lo que se encuentre frente a ti, incluida tu arma, en este caso tu brazo. Disparas con un botón, saltas con otro. Pero si se usan ambos juntos, apuntando hacia el suelo, se realiza un [i]rocket jump[/i], una mecánica propia no sólo de los [i]First Person Shooters[/i], sino también de los [i]TPS[/i], como [i]Team Fortress 2[/i]. Ahora, una de las mecánicas que cuenta de otros juegos del género es la mejora del arma principal con la obtención de objetos obtenidos por la eliminación de enemigos. O, el tipo de disparo: si se presiona una sola vez el botón de disparo saldrá un tiro de escopeta del arma, pero si se mantiene presionado será una ráfaga parecida a una metralleta, por lo que dependerá del jugador determinar qué tiro es conveniente en cada circunstancia. 
    Parecen pocos comandos, pero han sido implementados de una manera sabia. El salto también permite desplazarse con mayor velocidad si se realiza varias veces hacia una dirección. Y el único comando del que no he hablado es el realizado con la tecla "R". Presionándola se vuelve a empezar una partida y, créeme, esa tecla la usarás muchísimo. 
    Se trata de un juego muy adictivo no sólo a sus mecánicas sino también al diseño de enemigos y la disposición de los mismos que son testimonio de un maravilloso diseño. Es un juego frenético que te invita a perfeccionarlo para durar unos cuantos segundos más en la próxima partida. Un juego que no perdona ningún error, y, por lo mismo, es muy satisfactorio lograr sobrevivir varios minutos.

27650781.review:
Devil Daggers es como intentar coger un toro por los cuernos: o lo intentas y te rindes pensando que ese reto no es para ti dándote la vuelta y llevándote una cuernada en tus partes traseras, o bien le das duro a ese toro esforzándote lo máximo posible y al menos puedes estar satisfecho, porque lo habrás alejado lo suficiente para darte la vuelta alardeando y saliendo de la escuadra. Incluso quién sabe, tal vez eres lo suficiente cabezota y/o valiente para coger esos cuernos, inmovilizar a la bestia y dejarla en el suelo inmóvil para que cientos o miles de personas te aplaudan viendo tu éxito. A esto le llamo Leaderboard (marcadores).

El juego en sí es un símbolo de auto-superación donde unos logran cumplir sus metas y otros se quedan por el camino. Es tremendamente difícil y morirás cientos o miles de veces en cuestión de segundos, pero repitiendo es como aprenderás a superarte, y a pesar de parecer un juego simple, realmente tiene mucho juego el rejugarlo continuamente adquiriendo habilidad poco a poco. Muy poco a poco.

Cabe destacar que los chicos de Sorath han creado un FPS retador que está perfectamente equilibrado para que el jugador no se sienta maltratado (al menos si no se rinde) y que obliga a los menos habilidosos a doblegarse ante su dificultad o morir. Mientras tanto, los más expertos podremos lograr ascender en esa cima de cadáveres para alabar el fuego en nuestras manos y seguir lanzando dagas a diestro y siniestro.

Se podría resumir a Devil Daggers como un simple juego de oleadas bien planeadas que limitan al jugador a superarlas en un entorno cerrado, pero ello no haría justicia hacia la endiablada experiencia que realmente esconde el juego. Porque no solo su jugabilidad posee algo simple pero oscuramente perfecto, sino que la ambientación y desosiego del jugador va a influir bastante en cada partida en la que volvamos a coger una y otra vez esa daga del centro para empezar la matanza. Para mí, ha sido una experiencia brillante este juego, y vale cada maldito centavo que no he pagado al ser una copia de prensa, pero que sí he pagado invirtiendo mi tiempo en escribir esto y que llegue a más personas.

Así que tal vez para algunos esa daga le corte la mano al cogerla haciéndole sangrar de sufrimiento, pero para otros es una arma arrojadiza jodidamente difícil de manejar, y que si lo logramos, las horas y oleadas de masacre serán tremendamente divertidas, adictivas y satisfactorias.

27612911.review: A high score is a horrifying thing. The record holder may have survived longer and more effectively than all the players listed below them, but they did not win. Few games embrace the nihilism that the high score implies, and fewer do it as evocatively as Devil Daggers. It is the inflicted misery of games distilled. It deals explicitly in terror and violence and in the inability of power to save from death. It turns every round into a evocative and profound horror story about gaming itself. 27604527.review:
One the the funnest most chellenging games I own. The game is pretty much identical on every run you do but that is a good thing. You'll find yourself dying over and over again but improving with familiarity and experience of the enemy spawn patterns.

You can fire two different types of shot. A constant line of fire and a shotgun like burst. Either type of shot has its pros and cons and there is no right or wrong usage here, it all boils down to a matter of preference. The only other thing you can do really is jump and "rocket jump" which takes some skill to become useful. You can collect crystals that the spawners and some mobs drop and if you get enough your hand (your gun) will power up temporarily and become more powerful. Watching high score replays I've seen different strategies used to make the best use of crystal collection to obtain ever higher scores from 

Another compelling aspect of the game is the simple leader board. If you have friends that also play Devil Daggers, topping his or her score can become an addicting element of competition.

The visuals and atmosphere are nostalgically familiar to games like the original Quake and other pixely shooters and I have no complaints in that department. I recommend playing with the field of view turned all the way up in order to see the enemies in your peripherals easier.

By far the best thing about this game is the sound and ambient soundscapes. Playing with headphones is a terrific experience as you can hear where the enemies are around you.

For what it is, I have no complaints whatsoever about Devil Daggers and would give it the maximum number of stars if the reviewing system were that kind. For now I'll recommend this game with a thumbs up.

Neste game você controla em primeira pessoa um personagem que pode lançar dois tipos de magia: uma delas é semelhante a um tiro de shotgun - caso o você faça um clique simples e a outra seria como uma metralhadora - caso o você mantenha o clique pressionado. 
 O jogo se passa em uma plataforma com área limitada para andar e poder desviar dos ataques de inimigos (demônios) que vão spawnando aleatoriamente nesta plataforma. Quando são mortos, alguns demônios liberam gemas vermelhas que podem ser coletadas pelo jogador e assim ele consegue upgrades automáticos nas suas magias. Caso você encoste em algum inimigo, ou em algum ataque dele, ou então se descuidar e "cair" da plataforma, você morre.
 O objetivo do jogo é ficar o máximo de tempo possível vivo, coletando as gemas, desviando dos ataques, se mantendo dentro do limite da plataforma e matando os demônios. Quando você morre, seu tempo de jogo (score) é marcado no placar global e entre seus amigos que possuem o jogo. Você pode assistir as partidas de outros jogadores que marcaram os scores mais altos ou as partidas com pontuação mais alta dos seus amigos.
O modo que os inimigos são gerados é baseado em timing, ou seja, sempre no tempo ´´x´´ do jogo, vai spawnar o inimigo ´´y´´, e assim por diante. 
A pesar de ter um gameplay simples, este game tem um nível de dificuldade elevado e sua imersão, composição e arte são maravilhosos para quem curte gráficos 3D estilo Doom/Quake e outros jogos arcade. Recomendo muito!

27351014.review:
This is a simple but honest game that can put you through quite a test. With a simple premise of 'don't get hit' for as long as possible you're treated to hordes of nightmarish enemies.

The game starts benign enough before demanding a true FPS "in the zone" mindset. Enemies will inevitably spawn faster than you can slay. Different foes with different behaviors will test your ability to react and prioritize targets. Devil Daggers soon becomes a chaotic exercise of spatial awareness and crowd control. Victory is in extending your time alive, leaving a feeling of accomplishment (or maybe "I can do better") as the game ejects you on death to the scoreboard and you reset to begin anew.

If there was a benchmark for FPS skill, it would be Devil Daggers, and this benchmarking tool is very cheap with plenty of replayability...if you're willing to try and try again to extend your time by another five more seconds.

Devil Daggers is a shooter with a dark atmosphere.
It's very basic on the outside but full of tactic and perfectionism on the inside.
Your goal here is simple: Survive as long as you can!

The player spawns in the middle of an arena and there a constantly spawning waves of Demons/Skulls and so on. The weapon is a mysteriously Dagger that enables the player to shoot streams of Daggers out of his hand.

If you want to succeed you have to pay attention to your surroundings and learn the spawn times.

Pros:
- It's easy to learn and hard to master
- Retro inspired graphics
- Fluid movement system
- Rudimentary weapons
- Score hunting
- Replay system
- Game updates on a regular basis

Cons:
- Sometimes frustrating
- After some sessions it's getting exhausting

Verdict:
I fully recommend that game to people who like arena shooters, a challenge and retro graphics.
The game is hard, but it's worth to come back and beat your current score.

I hate it. I love it. It's simultaneously one of the best and most infuriating games I've ever played.

Half an hour with about a minute and a half at my top score, and I can't stop playing despite my hands shaking in unfathomable rage. My mind's in another realm, a pixelated Doom-esque heel with floating skulls and crystals at my heels.

The difficulty is cranked up to max, but each time I feel like I was the one at fault, that I didn't turn around, that I twitched my hand a centimeter too far. This results in a nailbiting run that's concise and action packed each time. Gameplay is the main attraction here: minimal story, characters, lore... and gameplay is what I'm about. 

As for visual effects, particle effects are [b] phenomenal. [/b] When each dagger hits the ground and kind of sparks off? Absolutely incredible. Especially for a pixelated resolution, everything from the ground to the enemies and the player's hand is polished, shined and then trimmed to perfection. 

You have here, folks, very close to a perfect game. Very, very close. Go buy it.

26952987.review:
Devil Daggers is a simple game: Survive as long as you can against endless waves of demonic monsters.

To start off with the obvious, the sound design is [i]superb[/i], the game doesn't have any fast paced action music when in the arena, so you're left listening to the distorted cries of the hundreds of enemies swarming around you.

Each game lasts from anywhere from 50-500 seconds, and while there's not much content in the game, I have easily spent almost 100 hours in-game and could easily pull off 100 more, it's one of those games where you're always wanting to have just one more go at it until it's 4am and you can't physically focus on the screen long enough to keep playing.

Another great thing about the game is the controls, to a brand new player you will simply run and shoot, until you realize that there is much more to the game. Pulling off perfect bunnyhops will increase your speed, timing shotgun blasts with your jumps to launch yourself over enemies, after a while everything works together perfectly until you're gliding around the arena and through the smallest gaps between demons.

All in all Devil Daggers is one of those games that you can very easily get addicted to, staying up countless hours just to beat your score by at least a second or two. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who likes a fast-paced shooter that involves quick thinking and reactions!

26929892.review:
There are precious few games that force the player into a sense of pure concentration at its best, where each death becomes little more than a foolish mistake between frantic bouts, and where one can become omnipotent through sheer intuiton and skill.

Devil Daggers is one of those games.

The game reinforces an almost Lovecraftesque vibe, as though you are a mere worm fighting for nothing in the face of the unknown, with each gem taken giving you a slightly deeper look into what should not be known, as you lose clarity in exchange for power through intuition. At its best this game is frustrating, terrifying, and is incredibly addictive in spades, and will leave you with an adrenaline rush and the need to fight for those extra few seconds for that high score.
The game runs exceptionally well, mostly due to its rendering style. The low-poly and low-resolution style is mesmerizing as legions upon legions of skulls dance across the screen, giving it a style not often seen nowadays. Another wonderful draw is the brilliant sound design, which is emphasized by the use of positional audio. There is little like knowing exactly what and where the enemy is merely by the use of sound.

All in all, I would highly recommend this game to anybody who enjoys FPS in its most distilled form, and can happily throw themselves at the game again when they fail against adversary, as death in Devil Daggers is not a question of [i]if[/i], but rather [i]when[/i].

Fantastic game. You'll love it if you like twitch based shooting and grinding for high scores. The enemy spawns are fixed, so there is no chance of an "unfair" run. This also means that memorizing them is an integral part of your success. Enemies also won't wait for you to kill off others, so the faster you are at killing them the less cluttered the arena will be.

It really keeps you on your toes and is super addictive. 

Some things to keep in mind though. The first 90 seconds or so feel really slow once you have mastered it. Replaying the same bit again and again can become a chore. There is also a lack of content. It's one level. I would love for it to have some other levels added. Not necessarily different design, just different enemy spawns. Maybe an unranked randomized mode? That'd be cool.

Absolutely worth it, especially at this price.

26839418.review:
An incredible pure-gameplay experience. 

There is perhaps a modicum of a "story" here but it is basically a pure first-person-shooter gameplay experience and an adrenaline packed one at that. You step forward in the dark to grab the only thing you can see, a dagger and the experience begins. Sounds alert you to what direction you should be facing and you see a low-poly column in the distance. Suddenly it starts spewing out skulls. Kill them all, one hit and you're dead. 

The action builds to a wonderful crescendo, the longer you last, the harder the game tries to kill you. At a certain point if you're like me you'll slip into a kind of zen, where you aren't actively "paying attention" but you are able to do quick, slight turns to knock a skull out of reality. The enemies have a wonderful gothic feel and the game keeps pulling you back even as it pushes you away with punishing difficulty. The goal? Live as long as you can and beat the others who have played. I have made it into the top 1000 players and I think that is the best I can hope for at the moment. 

This game is worth whatever price is currently on it if you like FPS gameplay and challenging yourself.

*Nov 2017 Edit

Game has been updated, added new enemies. Still brutal, hi-scores reset. Get in or get rekt.

First of all, word of warning - you _can_ fall off the platform.

Secondly, this game is a ton of fun.  The entire object is to see how long you can stay alive, and trust me, the game does not make it easy.  The difficulty, however, lies not in the controls, which are nice and tight, but in the increasingly faster-spwaning waves of enemies.  You start fairly simply, then you get a lot of those simple waves, then larger things start to spawn...and well, I don't want to say any more lest I spoil it.  

At 4.99, Devil Daggers seems far underpriced to me, but take advantage of it if you're at all a fan of the shooter.  You're unlikely to be disappointed.

Devil Daggers has got to be one of my favorite games at the moment, you go through never-ending waves of hellish creatures in a smooth pixel styled artwork where everything starts off as black and grey but your "devil daggers" are a bright fiery orange/red and light up the place as you shoot them, things just get more and more chaotic. Dying won't bother you as your highscore is measured in [b]ONE THOUSANDTH OF A SECOND[/b] and the chaos never really gets boring. I highly recommend it as well as an FPS training system - play this game for even just 20 minutes a day and your spacial awareness, accuracy, reaction speed and strategic thinking all improve. [u]GET IT[/u]

26633154.review: An incredibly exhilarating and difficult game!

26624270.review:
No background music, one touch from anything kills you, and your arena is a tiny island floating in the void that you can fall off of. I might have lasted 30 seconds at first by running away from things (includes first 13 seconds of relative calm), but kept at it and eventually lasted a whole minute. 

It was around then that I saw a top leaderboard replay (click the eye) and found out how to play properly. The leaderboard-with-replays-available aspect makes it a competitive game, and sometimes I'll just click on a lower ranked random player to see if I can steal any tricks.

Some thought has gone into the graphics and sound design. Aesthetically it looks Quake-ish, and not surprisingly one can do rocket jumps and bunny hop to get around. The graphics really drive home the whole "you're in hell, death is imminent" theme nicely. On my 5.1 surround I can hear spawners (???) appearing behind me, and those horned skulls charging from my blind spot....getting ever closer. Surround-sound rigs will get a better experience, for sure.

In a nutshell: Devil Daggers is a purist FPS experience with a focus on arena survival. By itself it would be a good game, but having leaderboards with replays makes it competitive and fun. Lasting longer than ever before is genuinely rewarding, because it's hard to do until you note certain patterns with experience (lots of dying).

[b]Absolutely worth 5 dollars.[/b] Fun to pick up and play a few rounds inside ten minutes and get your fix. Just buy it if you're anywhere near the fence. 

**Also, that reviewer who said that "being in the zone creates a state of mind not unlike meditation" (roughly paraphrased) was spot on. This game is all about that feeling. Though being ripped out of said zone makes me curse like a sailor.

This game requires you to replay it over and over and gets very repetative due to some lazy game design where the levels don't change or what enemies you face, it's literally the exact same thing over and over . You must kill everything the second it appears on your screen or die just moments later, the momentum of your "lack of aim" will screw you over later on. I call it "lack of aim" because the hitboxes of the enemies feels off and your bullets feel sluggish. Many times I have actually watched my bullets go through the target I'm trying to kill and I guess it just didn't register, pretty big flaw considering this IS an fps. You have to lead all your shots and your bullets feel very slow moving across the map, yet they shoot out of your hand quickly, doesn't really make sense. The game has a leaderboard and it does have some replay value based on that but this game needs some tweaks, the enemies need to move a little slower, the hitboxes of the enemies needs to be a bit bigger, your bullets need to move across the map a little faster, and they need to implement a toggle for crosshairs. I can't stand guessing where my bullets are going to go without some reticle. Until these changes are made I just can't really recommend this game. It gets very frustraiting to have your bullets just go through your target, and having to repeat the EXACT same "sequence" over and over and over and over again to try and get back to where you were at. Even though the game isn't expensive I would still wait for it to go on sale.

26549095.review:
Devil Daggers is a game where you, the player, is sent to battle against hell itself. Brandishing magical daggers, you need to survive for as long the beasts of hell will allow. Paired with beautiful and morbid stylistic direction and art, this hearkens back to the likes of Quake, Diablo and DOOM, with it's gritty, enigmatic, demonic, occult, and somewhat Lovecraftian style.

This is a decently "competitive", fast paced game that has tenfold more strategy and metagame than would would expect on the surface, especially for the small retail price tag of £3.99/$4.99 (which you can probably get for less regardless.). The game will test you, as you will test yourself, finding new strategies against the onslaught of demons with the very little and cryptic information that you are given. Learning nuance and piecing together the mannerisms of the demons. Learning sound cues with constant awareness as all of the otherworldly, demonic wails and cries mesh together (seriously, the sound design is stupidly well done, holy shit) to create a brilliant cacophony you try to make sense of, marking your inevitable defeat.

Best of all? You will try, and try again until you rule out every single variable that you know to get just a dozen seconds more, until something new throws you off and makes your journey through hell even harder.

A must buy if you're into Quake, and if you crave an oldschool, hardcore 90s PC game vibe.
A must buy if you want a game where you need to process dozens of different things in a handful of seconds.
A must buy if you're looking for a game that will test your prowess.

Alrighty. First meaninful review of my life. Helps that i think this game is fraggin awesome.
Devil daggers is a game that i would say is much like demons souls. It really depends on if you are into games that will take you a while to get used to or not. This game is, in my 2 hours of playing it, a game that im going to have to play constantly and get used to the controls, and the spawns just to get at least 10 seconds farther then i already have gotten to. This is a 5 dollar game that is completly worth the amount of time that would get put into it. 

Basically all that you do in Devil Daggers is, you guessed it, throw daggers at devils. There is one level that you will be on for the rest of your patience level allows you to be on it until you close the game to calm down, and its a simple movement scheme, and a right click game. You hold right click to fire a stream of blades, and double tap it to shoot what i call a shotty of blades. The way the game is designed is that every time that you start you start again from the beginning with the same spawns. Everything spawns the same every time that you play the game. However that doesn't make it easy. There is a good chance that in this game you will be finding yourself in impossible situations when you don't clear the arena of enemies. Another thing that most people don't find out as there is no explanation for it, is that you collect these diamond shaped thingys, and once you hit a certain amount you "level up" your stream of blades and shotgun as well. 

Not gonna say anything about the rest of it cause i haven't even gotten to it yet, but i think that this game is going to be the game that i go to whenever im bored, think i have nothing to play, am waiting for a friend to finish something, or basically whenever i feel like a challenge is needed. 10/10 game.

26237208.review:
I was first drawn to the game by a screen shot of the unique art style. Its unique blend of pixel/3d brings wave of nostalgia for a gamer like myself, fed intravenously on the first person shooters of the nineties. Also, I love challenging rpgs of any shape or size. This game seemed to be hitting all of the right notes and critic and user reviews seemed to positively reflect this. As soon as I saw it on Humble Bundle, I snatched it up and installed it. Quite a feat considering the towering shadow my steam back catalog casts on me with shameful disapproval every time I turn on my desktop.

This game was nothing like I thought it would be. It is not an rpg. It does not have a story. There is no customization. I love it. It is brutal. It is terrifying. It is beautiful. The game is so hard you have to quickly mop up your tears of how unfair it all is and decide to try and overcome odds that would make Han Solo go pale. Once you crest that initial sense of crestfallen despair, every small second, literally, is a gaming rush like none I can recall in recent memory. You are Gandalf. You will fall. But you will take the demons with you.

In pure mechanics Devil Daggers breaks down into a first person shooter where you have one weapon, a magical dagger spell, and your own raw skill. You are then faced against a horde of enemies so massive, countless, and terrifying, in a Lovecraftianly dark fantasy sense, that you know there is no hope for survival. There will be no happy ending. So with a mindset of Spartan martyrdom you begin to relish in the ecstasy of each and every additional millisecond you hold back the gates of hell. This game makes my heart pound, my mind churn faster than humanly possible, and leaves me hopelessly addicted to come back for more.

Devil Daggers isn't for everyone. It is a game that will visually chime with the retro shooter crowd, vibe with the masochistic challenge seeker, brutally scar the dreams of the horror aficionado, and give unadulterated ecstasy to the fps player who thrives on skill alone. One of my favorite games this year, and I'm really more of the Xcom or Skyrim guy. Happy Devilween.﻿

26236475.review:
It's an actual, honest-to-god skill-based hardcore game. Little to no unfair randomness, success is entirely up to the player, genuinely difficult instead of marketing difficult *cough* Dark Souls *cough* Darkest Dungeon *coughcough*.

To sum up the gameplay, the game is an arena/wave based shooter where the only objective is to survive for as long as possible. You can only take one hit and only have one life, your one weapon can fire either a continuous stream of projectiles (think the Nailgun from Quake) or a powerful shotgun blast and can be upgraded by collecting gems. While the arena is completely flat and enemies spawn in the same order every playthrough and only their spawn positions are randomized, the game is chaotic enough that no two runs are quite the same. Despite the arena being flat, the enemies' swarming AI, extreme numbers, mechanics and size come together to shape the boundaries of the arena. The game has one difficulty setting but there are risk/reward mechanics in place to make the game optionally more difficult without instating a difficulty setting.

Pros:
Uncompromising design that demands excellent aim, ability to quickly pick up game mechanics and analyze situations, skillful movement and situational awareness from the player. Dark artstyle driven by an engine that faithfully simulates older 3D graphics. The excellent audio and visual design come together to create a palpable atmosphere of malice towards the player, which fits thematically because the game absolutely will hurt you. Over and over. All aspects of the game complement eachother perfectly to create a cohesive theme. The gameplay design is a finely-tuned and inventive mix of both pre-existing and original mechanics that demonstrates an excellent talent for game design from Sorath and it is a game that is absolutely worth discussing and analyzing.

Cons:
Might give you a heart/anxiety attack. No biggie!
It's not for everyone. There are no options for casual play, and there probably won't ever be options for casual play as introducing them in a way that doesn't cheapen the core game would likely be a difficult task.
Might not satisfy you if you want levels, exploration and a huge arsenal of weapons but, then again, [b]you should probably already know that it doesn't have any of that just from the store page[/b].

Solid 5/5, bretty gud.

26191825.review:
--Warning-- Prepare to get skullfucked

This game, is beautiful. Easily the best five dollars I have spent. The graphics are nostalgic heavily based on the original quake. Polygon jitter, heavy pixellation filter. A ton of other rendering techniques to produce a game that looks beautiful. I would love the option to toy around with these settings, as after playing for so long the games visual nostalgia wears off. The game has a soundtrack that can be played through the steam music player. It doesn't play in-game but some parts of it do. The soundtrack really sets an uplifting yet corrupted dark atmosphere.
I personally enjoy playing darksynth music while I play, it makes me feel like a complete badass. Mowing down hundreds of skeletons with my demon arm.
This game is a perfect orgasm of nostalgia, and superb sound design, and feeling like a complete badass whenever you beat your high score slowly climbing to the top. Until your reflexes are godlike, wiping the floor with demons, and strafe jumping around perfectly dodging enemies left and right, while managing trying not to fall of the map.
Do I recommend this game? Fuck. Yes.

Seriously though the games system of progression is so simple, yet bold and rewarding. Slowly figuring out enemies movement patterns, and using them to your advantage in order to reach the highest scores.

Listen to some Perturbator on spotify while playing this, otherwise its hard to get into. Seriously darksynth, or synthwave in general will keep you going. Eventually your musle memory will kick in and be doing all the work for you, if you continue playing it will become instinct, and you will just be desicrating everything in sight. Before realizing, holy shit I just did that.

Also back on the sound design, every enemy has a distinct and different sound so you know what enemy is behind you before you even turn around --- as well a nice touch is the fact that enemies don't randomly spawn, they all have set time periods to spawn. So its not completely random, you have to progressively memorize different enemies spawning in different time periods. This comes in handly with the timer at the top of your screen.
Also one of the best things I love about this game is the fact that your hitbox is so small you could fit through things thought impossible. It makes you feel badass running between the tiniest crevace between two enemies.

This is easily one of the most impressive games, that actually manage to make a 'hardcore 90's shooter right'. Rather than just luring people in with neon-esque colors, and an awesome soundtrack. It actually delivers on the promise, both with the gameplay and visual design.

If you aren't the kind of person who wants to play games purely to get better at playing them, this isn't your game. If you are that kind of person - [b]buy it right now.[/b] Five bucks isn't that much and you'll get hours of entertainment. 
That's more than buying a cup of coffee would give you.

26107061.review:
Devil Daggers is a game that has a [b]lot[/b] going for it despite being incredibly simply. It captures the best elements of the arcade and brings it into the PC market. You get one life, an unlimited number of chances, and infinite possibility. The game lasts as long as you do. The only elements present are you, a dagger, a floor, unending darkness, and a plethora of monsters whose only job is to make your life as short as possible.

The game mechanics are dirt simple. You begin on a large circular platform with a dagger, and from the moment you grasp it, demons begin spawning trying to kill you. You can run, jump, strafe, get a real bunny hop going if you're so inclined, and shoot in two ways - either a endlessly fluid stream of daggers shooting out from your person, or a harsh, brutal shotgun burst that disintegrates anything unfortunate enough to be immediately in front of you. This is really being overly simplistic: there are more mechanics to the game than that, ones that you will realize while playing that lie in enemy behavior... and there are power crystals to be collected that will power up your weapon which belie a dastardly game design decision: the only way to power up your weapon is to stop shooting, because shooting causes crystals to move further away from you. Of course, this is Devil Daggers, and the moment you stop shooting you might regret it big time.

You don't need to kill your enemies - all you have to do is survive. There are no unlockables, no goalposts, no carrots dangling over your head except for the glory of the leaderboard. Your attempts will be dismal. I can last 3 minutes on a good day; the world record is a bit over 14 minutes. It doesn't take long to learn what Devil Daggers has to offer, but it can take forever to see what you are capable of.

That's the crux of the game - easy to learn, difficult to master. And it's the hallmark of a good one. Anyone can pick up Devil Daggers and understand it in seconds. Make no mistake - the game is hard, brutally so, but that's the point. You [i]will[/i] die, it's only a matter of how long you can prolong the inevitable. Killing enemies only serves to stave them off until more arrive; and sometimes you will want to kill enemies in certain orders to better strategize how you can move amongst them. If you're good enough, you'll meet your end in a flurry of red, brown and grey monstrosities when you're no longer able to squeeze through the gaps in the hell that engulfs you.

The game's presentation is slick as hell (no pun intended). Its graphics are pixelated and obscured... a sea of red and and brown and grey and orange that seeps out of the screen like fire from the darkness of your screen. It's a simplified look that matches the gameplay. Monster designs are great: they range from simple skulls to horrific swirling tentacled monstrosities, each of which look like something ripped out of H.P. Lovecraft's work and all of whom want you dead.

Sound design is on point here. The music isn't overly complex, but varies between a low-key thumping to hellish industrial music that sounds like it was ripped from the original Quake. The feel, in fact, shares a lot with the original Quake's feel; a very simple 3D game done very well... and speaking of 3D, the surround sound here is fantastic, and you'll want to listen to it no matter how nightmarish it gets, because the different enemies surrounding you give off sounds that will betray their position and give you important information about what is swirling about you when you don't have the time to look.

In the end, Devil Daggers is incredibly simple; [b]it is a wonderful exercise in the type of game that it is, a masterclass in short, arcade-like arena shooting[/b]. If that type of game isn't for you, though, you're not going to find much to enjoy here. Simply watch the trailers for the game: if it appeals to you, then know that it's worth every penny. If you don't see the appeal, playing it is unlikely to change your opinion. Devil Daggers only gives you what you're willing to put into it.

26009247.review:
Devil Daggers, c'est un jeu qui se termine en 500 secondes ! Pas de bol pour vous, vous ne verrez jamais la gueule de la 500eme seconde (seulement une dizaine de joueur y sont, sur plus de 50000 joueurs au classement). On fait ici difficilement plus minimaliste, une arène vide, des mobs qui spawnent, une arme, un point de vie et en avant la musique. Le jeu est dur, très dur (trop dur ? :D), et il ne pardonne absolument pas. La progression relève principalement de la gestion de crise, les timers des spawns sont fixes, et si vous ne tenez pas la cadence, vous serez dépassé par les évènements, et c'est la mort garantie.

On regrettera un peu une présence d'aléatoire un peu trop chargée au niveau des patterns de spawn de certains mobs qui est un peu irritante dans un jeu aussi exigeant, mais le skill reste l'élément majeur d'un beau run. Niveau graphismes, c'est retro, mais en 3D, et soyons francs, s'il y a bien un truc qui a terriblement mal vieilli, c'est de la 3D low-res moche des débuts de la 3D. Le style graphique est certes indéniable, mais indéniablement moche (et pourtant je suis un grand amateur de pixel art dans les jeux 2D), qui contribue à rendre l'action encore plus fouilli, ce dont le jeu n'a clairement pas besoin.

Bref, c'est un jeu "what you see is what you get", il n'y a pas de contenu caché ou quoi que ce soit, c'est toujours le même niveau, en boucle, qui se termine toujours (généralement assez rapidement) par une mort. Doté d'un seul achievement possédé par seulement une poignée de joueur, le jeu ravira les masochistes et fera hurler de rage les autres, qui rage-quitteront probablement le jeu assez rapidement, l'ensemble était rapidement lassant. Peut-être amusant si vous avez des potes qui y jouent aussi pour se tirer la bourre dans les classements (qui sont par ailleurs bien foutus, avec la possibilité de DL le run de n'importe qui dans le classement pour l'observer), mais une fois premier, ce sera l'heure de le ranger !

25953333.review:
La historia

Devil Daggers carece de historia, por ende, voy a escribir una historia para él.

Tomaremos el papel de Perengano, el más impopular de los cuatro hermanos y que casi nadie usa en una oración. Perengano es un joven bonachón y regordete, siempre dispuesto ayudar a las personas aunque lo traten mal. También le gusta mucho las canciones de Alejandro Sanz y colecciona estampillas.

Un día Perengano saca a pasear a la mascota de la familia, un perro chiquito y juguetón, una actividad que no es del agrado de él pero debe hacer caso a su hermano mayor Fulano.

El día es soleado y agradable, perfecto para salir a pasear al perro. Por el camino, Perengano se consigue a una señora que esta accidentada en medio de la calle, su carro no esta apagado y no enciende. Perengano amarra al perro en un poste, luego va presto a ayudar a la señora y empuja el carro fuera de la vía transitada para que la señora espere una grúa en un lugar seguro.

La señora le agradece la ayuda y le regala un dinero para que se compre algo, Perengano lo recibe con beneplácito, busca a su perro y continúa el paseo.

Más adelante se topa con una niña llorando, ella llora por su helado que esta en el suelo. Cuando Perengano se le acerca y habla con ella se entera que la niña llora porque no tiene dinero para comprar otro helado, Perengano toma una decisión y entra a la heladería y compra el helado favorito de la niña con el dinero que le dio la señora y la niña se pone muy feliz. Perengano sonríe y siente la alegría por hacer felices a los demás.

La suerte le sonríe a Perengano porque más adelante divisa una estampilla tirada en el suelo y no es cualquier estampilla, es una rara que Perengano no posee en su colección. Sin tomar precauciones va por la estampilla y en la emoción se enreda con la correa del perro, lo que hace que se caiga y se rompa la correa, el perro sale corriendo tras una perra callejera que esta en la acera den enfrente atravesando la calle atestada de vehículos. Perengano, asustado va tras el perro sin pensar en lo peligroso de su acción.

Cuando Perengano abre sus ojos luego de estar un largo tiempo en penumbras, logra ver una daga flotando enfrente de él y más nada a su alrededor, toma la daga como lo único que puede hacer por ahora.

Inmediatamente es trasladado a una especie de Arena rodeado de la misma oscuridad de la cual nacen horribles criaturas que buscarán acabar con él, puede defenderse gracias al poder que da la daga pero la cantidad de monstruos que salen de la oscuridad es infinitas y con eso tarde o temprano resulta en la muerte.

Al morir, Perengano vuelve a revivir una y otra vez la experiencia de la lucha y muerte, es un ciclo infinito sin un escape posible. Perengano sabe que muy bien que esta en el infierno y luchar contra la legión infernal es su castigo para toda la eternidad.

Por eso Perengano no se ha vuelto a ver ni escuchar en las oraciones, solo se conoce a sus hermanos, Fulano, Mengano y Zutano.

FIN.

La historia puede resultar poco creíble pero algo que si les puedo asegurar es que; el infierno está reservado a aquel que le gusta las canciones de Alejandro Sanz.

Moraleja: no escuchen las canciones de Alejandro sanz XD 



El menú contiene los cráneos de los que han intentado sobrevivir.

El juego

Es un shooter de primera persona de la vieja escuela pero condensado en un lugar cerrado y donde no iremos por los monstruos son ellos lo que vendrán a ti. El objetivo de Devil Daggers es sobrevivir el mayor tiempo posible, disparando y saltando.

La jugabilidad es fluida y responde bien a los controles en esos momentos intensos cuando la Arena esta atiborrada de monstruos.

En Devil Daggers tendremos el poder de la daga, con ella podremos disparar a los monstruos. Para acabar con ellos debemos disparar en ciertos puntos marcados de color rojo (otros no son así) para destruirlos. Algunos monstruos soltarán un cristal rojo que aumentan el poder de la daga, hay que tomarlas rápidamente porque desaparecen con el tiempo.

Otra herramienta útil para sobrevivir son los saltos, que si logramos calcularlos bien obtendremos un impulso que mejora la velocidad de "Perengano", fundamental para esquivar y seguir disparando.

Recuerda que la Arena esta limitada, si llegas al borde te caerás y morirás, si un monstruo te toca te mueres también. No hay escape.



Sojk obstante el titulo del mejor en Devil Daggers, ¿lo podrás superar?

Mientras más tiempo dures vivo más monstruos salen, no existe una pausa a la oleada de monstruos, quiere decir que no podemos descuidarnos ni un momento, la carga de adrenalina es constante. Afina bien la puntería, tus reflejos y la paciencia.

Actualmente el record de supervivencia en Devil Daggers es de 15 minutos con 13 segundos. Podemos ver el ranking mundial en todo momento y sentirte mal como yo, que de broma alcanzo el minuto y medio de sobrevivencia. ¡No me dejaré vencer!.



Ahí esta mi posición :'(  . Watermelon man es mi usuario de Steam.

Gráficos y sonido

El apartado gráfico posee una calidad especial, no sé compara con la calidad gráfica de Battlefield 1 o de otros vídeo juegos similares,  Devil Daggers esta realizado con un estilo propio, muy útil además para cuando la Arena esta atiborrado de monstruos y Devil Daggers no se “lagee” (se ponga lento).



El monstruo del inicio, un calamar invertido que pare calaveras flotantes que te persiguen.

La atmósfera está bien lograda y es apoyada por el apartado sonoro, nos hará sentirnos en un terrible lugar, solos y desesperados.

Cada uno de los monstruos tiene un sonido propio, así podremos identificarlos, también sabremos qué distancia hay entre tu y el monstruos, importante porque los monstruos llegan por todas partes y nuestra espalda estará desprotegida.

Recomiendo, si te atreves a jugar sin sonido y escuchando tu banda de Death Metal favorito, la experiencia Metalera es magistral.

Como nota curiosa, podemos ver la jugadas de los otros jugadores con solo ir al Ranking y elegir cual demo ver. Algo muy útil, nos ayudará a mejorar nuestro juego.

Conclusión

Es un vídeo juego sencillo, con un objetivo sencillo, con una dificultad de locura. Carece de historia pero no lo necesita. Devil Daggers está realizado con entusiasmo y busca darte una experiencia única en cada partida, no importa cuanto mueras, siempre vas a regresar a jugar.

Puede que Devil Daggers resultar frustrante y quieras lanzar el monitor por la ventana y no lo harás porque el juego es un vicio, disfrutarás morir (?), recuerda: Perder no es una opción, es la ley.

Un vídeo juego que sorprende por lo sencillo de la premisa, los gráficos agradables y un ambientación bien logrado. Si te gusta los vídeo juegos shooter de primera persona y difíciles, te lo recomiendo.

Por mi parte me voy a seguir jugando Devil Daggers.

25928176.review:
[i][b]Devil Daggers[/b][/i] is more akin to a trance than a game in a lot of ways. The game is hypnotic, and before long, every split second  becomes an unconscious decision as you run, jump and shoot in an unrelenting, but ultimately futile attempt to survive.  Less than 0.1% of all players who own the game have actually earned the game's sole achievement - to survive 500 seconds, and I don't know that I ever will. It's a game in which you constantly shoot to fend off the unrelenting legions, but if you don't take your finger off the trigger you will never get any of the quite vital powerups.

The visuals of [i]Devil Daggers[/i] are quite clearly meant to evoke classic FPS like the original [i]DOOM[/i] and [i]Quake[/i], complete with shaky polygons, Jagged edges and a low resolution. The enemies are all visually distinctive, and have their own audio cues: it's quite vital to wear headphones to survive. The music is also spot on, adding further to the games atmosphere.

There's no explicit story to this game, and perhaps it's better to be all your own imagination. You touch the dagger, and from that point on you're doomed to die, but all that matters is how long you can draw out the inevitable. For this price, I highly recommend [i]Devil Daggers[/i].

If you're looking for a traditional FPS like Doom or Quake, then Devil Daggers isn't for you. While the graphics are similar to Quake, Devil Daggers is more of an arena survival game where you have to survive enemies constantly spawning than a full FPS game with levels. Despite this, for people who are fans of this genre, this is a pretty fun game and has a lot to offer them, and even fun for FPS fans who want to play something a little different from a normal FPS game. The controls are simple and easy to learn, but have a lot of depth to them as you can bunny hop and rocket jump like in other FPS games. Each enemy is distinct and it can get really crazy and fun when there's a ton of them on screen.

Furthermore, the atmosphere is also really interesting. Its really hellish and creepy. The graphics are also very minimalistic and therefore work really well for this game. All of the monsters look great and the sound design is great too of how each monster has a distinctive noise and they all buzz around you as you around. The weapon, which you can alternate between rapid fire and shotgun blasts on the fly, is really fun to use. One minor problem I found was that its often difficult to get a sense of height when you jump given there is only. Overall the game is really unique and fun in short bursts.

Definitely worth giving this game a go!

25863198.review:
Devil Daggers is a very intersting hybrid of a Bullet Hell shooter and late 90's arena shooters such as Quake 3  Arena and Unreal Tournament. You play as the bearer of the titular Devel Dagger, which you fire from your hand in either a stream of daggers or shotgun like bursts, and the main objective is to kill every demon SOB that gets in your way and survive as long as you can. 

The gameplay is extremely fast and easy to pickup but takes lightning reaction times and patience to master. Firing daggers in a stream or burst is satisfying and the controls are fluid and allow for all sorts of crazy snap movements and leaps through the omnipresent horde of demons after you. The game only allows you one life per playthrough but don't let that make you think there's not deep gameplay here. The enemies swarm in predatory packs and will strike right when you think you have things in hand. The game will test every bit of old school shooter skills that you have from your reaction time down to your accuracy. It makes a great training tool for twitchy shooters without the constant bickering and taunts of "git gud" from rando jerks. Only thing that might make the game a little less appealing for some folks is the lack of controller support. 

 The visuals immediately remind me of some of Quake and Quake 2's enemies and environments, and by that I mean that they really nail that grim dark gothic look. On top of that, any fairly modern PC should be able to run this game quickly and with maxed settings. Outside of that, the style is fairly true to form for 90's style retro shooters. The textures have that great mixture of grain and vibrance. The models of the enemies are more complex than they would have been had this game been made in the 90's but they're still in keeping with the visual themes of a 90's 3d FPS. 

The audio in this game is really great. There's a soundtrack that comes separately with the game, but you wouldn't neccessarily want to play it while playing the game. The reason I say that is, the sounds that the enemies make and their loudness are a key part of the gameplay as they act as a form of aural radar giving subtle warnings of enemy positions.
I play it with a 5.1 speaker setup, but the game also has options that allow you to use headphones to great effect. 

TL;DR
Devil Daggers is a great twitch shooter in the style of 90's 3D FPS games. Buy it!

I appreciate the simplicity of this game, it is fast paced and quick to continue once you die. Nothing is explained because there’s very little to explain. (It would though be nice to know that a single left click first a burst of daggers and that you can use this to jump higher without having to look online).

However I can’t say that I [i]like[/i] it. There’s a fine line between fast paced and frustrating and continuously failing at the same point around 60 seconds in is very frustrating. This is long enough to make it hard to practice strategies against this specific enemy, and very bored of fighting the first few waves over and over. It also doesn’t help that the same enemy eats the crystals you need to upgrade the only weapon and it appears right before you have enough for the first one.

If you’re better at shooters than I am, perhaps you will enjoy it, but after over an hour I’m still no more than 60 seconds in, it’s more boring than fun. I’m sure there’s a lot more in this game, but I’ve only managed to see the first 4 enemies because the difficulty ramped up so quickly.

I would only recommend this for people who are hard core FPS fans that also happen to like retro Doom style graphics. Maybe consider buying very cheap if it looks at all interesting to you, but don’t expect too much.

25821213.review:
First off. Let me warn you. This game is Simple, Short, and Difficult. For what it lacks in content, it makes up for in focus and style. Its an endless "wave based" Survival FPS. (I don't when the waves start or end... Does it even have waves?) One mode, one purpose, no end.  This game oozes horrific style, the sound design is bone chilling, and the difficulty is proper high. (Shit takes place in hell. Do you think its gonna be easy?)

Ok the game looks old at dirt. Like a Doom or Quake. Which to me add to the horrific look and style of the game. Is it for you? I dunno. But the game DOES NOT drop below 60 FPS. Although is has slow motion moments. Do not mistake it for slow downs. It lalso has FOV slider and Fullscreen function.

Also the game does have 3D positional audio which helps you survive the madness around you by telling you where enemies spawn through audio queues. Its a big help. This game doesn't have much of a soundtrack. I think it has only 1 song... the menu music. So have your own badass hell-slaying Soundtrack at the ready. Since your in hell, make it all the music you hate the most for the full effect.

Other features? Has Leadersboard. Global and Friends. Has Stats tracking, Accuracy, Deaths, Time, Hits, Best, Etc.
Has fully functional replay system. Beat that league of legends. 

Anyway this game is for any hardcore player to just burn a few mins on. For 5 bucks it definitely delievers on it's content. I personality would value this game at 7.99. But im just some rando Interweb dude writing a review thats likely riddled with misspellings and grammatical errors. But if my opinion matters to you, try this game and keep your head up for whatever this dev puts out next. I'm certainly looking forward towards their next game.

25741299.review:
Devil Daggers is an extremely simple and straightforward first-person arcade shooter.

The gameplay is really basic. You have one life and you must survive in one small arena against endless waves of enemies. The difficulty ramps up really quickly too, don't expect to survive for too long.

I have never been a huge fan of these kind of pure arcade experiences. To make matters worse, the game uses an art style inspired by the early 3D shooters. I found this kind of art ugly already back when it was new, and it certainly hasn't improved with time.

I didn't enjoy the game much and wouldn't recommend it. However, if you like pure arcade experiences this might be worth a purchase, especially during a sale.

The good:
- Tight controls

The bad:
- Ugly art style
- Extremely simple gameplay
- Relies too much on memorizing enemy spawn patterns

25718156.review:
There are two things weak people do under pressure. Break or become strong.

This is not a game where you fight against demons.
This is a game where you fight against yourself.

Devil Daggers is not a game, but a grind. Each time you start this game you start right where everyone else does. There are no short cuts. No cheats. Only skill, practice and countless hours of game time.  Each time you smash that R key you are submitting to the alluring call of the famous, "one more round" siren. And each time you fail, just precious seconds away from a new high score, you are tempted to quit. And yet, every time you start a new game almost immediately. Mechanics are solid 10/10, simple, unforgiving, but fair. The enemy design is so creatively twisted, you can't help but appreciate the effort as you are senselessly torn limb from limb. Sound is completely on point, creating a chaotic atmosphere as all the sounds seem to blend together into a symphony of terror.

In conclusion, Devil Daggers is definitely worth the $5, good mechanics, beautiful art, punishing enemies. What more can you ask for?

Now, are you going to break or become strong?

When the Doom Marine has a nightmare, it looks like Devil Daggers.

While most "retro" games are to Retro what "frozen dairy threats" are to ice cream, Devil Daggers is 100% Cream. The graphics are just perfect for the genre, the enemy AI is robust and predictable, the controls are responsive. The dev rolled out a custom made 3D engine... That is a level of dedication we do not often see, and it pays out with this game.

It is a [b]very[/b] difficult game, and dependant on your skills alone. If you don't usually play modern shooter at the hardest difficulty, of can't finish a Doom level without abusing the quicksave, then this game is not for you. 

Contrary to popular opinions, this gave do have a skill tree. Here is some of the skills I have acquired in 3 hours of play:

[list]
    [*]Recognize Horny McSkullface's Laugh
    [*]Learn to rotate with Squid Towers
    [*]Skull Flockery
    [*]Red Good, Green Bad
[/list]

They are bought in game with Git Gud credits, which you aquire by making an effort.  

There is even a mode to see more enemie! It's in the option, it's called Field Of View.

25672100.review:
A friend got this on humble bundle but didn't want it so gave the code to me.

Devil daggers is a competitive First Person Shooter where you fight endless enemies whilst fighting on a small arena.  What I mean by competitive is that you are put on leader boards and obviously if you’re on a leader board you’re tempted to get higher. 

In the options menu there are a few options; those being the input options with the obvious look sensitivity, keyboard options and you can invert y axis. However you can also adjust what hand you want to shoot with so instead of default which is the right hand you can have it on the left hand. This is an option called flash hand but I’m not sure what that is. You also have the audio option which doesn’t have much but there is a HRTF option which is interesting; what HRTF stands for is head-related transfer function which basically is a response that characterizes how an ear receives a sound from a point of source. And finally you have the video options which has the obvious full screen, FOV and v-sync, nothing too special 

You also have a leader boards menu where you can obviously look at other peoples score. Finally in the menu you have the obvious play and exit buttons.

The game play in this game is reminiscent of the touhou project games which are bullet hell type games akin to this one but this isn’t “bullet” hell, this would be considered an enemy hell type game which is a game type where instead of too many bullets there are too many enemies flooding to your location and a genre I just made up also this game isn’t a top down shooter.

The enemies in this game are mainly comprised of bone but there are squid enemies which have tentacles. The enemies in the game consist of skulls, skulls with horns, squid type enemies, spider like enemies, centipede demon, a fortress skull thing which I have yet to face and apparently there is a crab boss but I have not got up to that point. There are two types of enemies which can spawn the skull enemies you first see. Those enemies are the squid which is the very first enemy you see which can spawn skulls and one skull with horns the other enemy is a spider which spawns eggs which will hatch if not taken care of. Also on a side note there are different tiers to the skulls and squid and of course each tier will become stronger and have more health.

There are upgrades in this game which enable you to do more damage but the final upgrade allows for homing bullets. There are also 2 secrets in this game.

Overall this game is a great hell game, it’s similar to dark souls in the difficulty sense but I can defiantly say this is much harder because it is endless. So in conclusion it’s a great game with great pixel graphics which is why I give this a 7/10.

25669105.review:
Devil Daggers, or "The adventures of Sir Strafealot".

I can see the game merits, when it comes to reviving the gameplay of old style FPS games, this one looking like a hard-core version of PainKiller, and I guess that if it's a pure, adrenalinic experience, you will really like this game.

However the game is poorly executed: the sound department borders on the non-existent, the graphic is functional but doesn't go behiond a couple of days of blender modelling and there are some bugs (on linux I cannot find any way to get a decent resolution, which I *hope* it's a bug, and at the 2th playthrough I had to restart the game because the controls where drifting in one direction...).

I guess the game is kind of fun, and the replay for each playtrough is a nice touch, but it doesn't justify for its 5E pricetag.

I would give the game 2 or 3 stars, and hardcore FPS enthusiasts might even overlook the faults and give it a 4, but due to the broken 1/0 Steam review system, it's a thumb down.

UPDATE: gave the game a 2th, 3th and 4th chance, and I admit that the fun outweights the defects. Still a ripp-off for 5E, but recommended as a quick distraction.

25668176.review:
Devil Daggers. A game so simple yet so challenging.

I have only played an hour of this game and I have to say I am enjoying it a lot. Devil Daggers is as the description says : a 90's themed, bare bones FPS arena shooter (Quite Literally an arena shooter). The way I see this game is as an endless runner. Survive for as long as possible in a simple arena. As you progress in time, so does the difficulty of enemies. As I am experienced in Arena Shooters, it did not take me long to understand how the game works as well as its mechanics. So is it worth buying this game if there is so little content. Yes it is. Why ? Because the developers of this game have put effort into making the game so fluid and responsive. The enemy variety is also a big plus. 

Do not be fooled by the games simplicity however. Without all the fancy things being an issue, this game is brutally unforgiving. It forces you to be extremely twitchy, always on the move, always listening for sound of wails behind you and around you. One mistake could cost you your life and your run. But with every try, you gain more knowledge and more skill and because of its endless runner style, you will always be stuck in that phase of 'oh just one more go and I can beat my score'. Arena shooter veterans and fans, I highly recommend this game to you. You will enjoy the living hell out of it. I still recommend it to everyone, but then again not everyone is good at arena FPS. With such a low price like this, there is no reason to pass this game up.

25656654.review:
[u][h1]Devil Daggers Review [/h1][/u]

Devil Daggers is a nightmare that I keep coming back to. It’s demanding and frightening – an intensely difficult first-person arena shooter set in some forgotten circle of hell, where survival happens only a handful of seconds at a time and death is constantly looming over your shoulder. But it’s also exhilarating, a frantic high-score chaser that buries hours of rewarding playtime deep within its punishing core for only the most determined players to claw out.

Devil Daggers grounds itself in the look and feel of old-school PC shooters of the ‘90s like DOOM and Quake, then strips the experience down into its purest elements and drops you in without explanation. There are no weapons to pick up, no armor, and besides collectible crystals that power up your dagger shots in tiers, there are no items whatsoever. There are no stats to increase and no levels to beat, either. It’s just you, the daggers that inexplicably fire from your outstretched fingers, and an endless legion of hellspawn battling it out in a dark arena for as long as your skill can carry you, which probably won’t be that long.
Trying, failing, and trying again is a particularly brutal process in that abyss, where there’s always some new monstrosity threatening to cut your latest attempt short. Hordes of floating skulls and disembodied demon heads spew out of tentacled behemoths, mindlessly giving chase while increasingly grotesque beasts spawn from all sides until the mobs become too overwhelming to fend off any longer.

With the amount of intensity packed into a single second of gameplay, even a one-minute run can feel like an eternity. The relentless thrill of blasting baddies and the smooth transition between the game over screen and a fresh start (tapping R instantly resets it at any time) make it easy to get sucked in, losing entire hours to the black hole of “just one more try.”

[h1]The Devil Is in the Details[/h1] 

 As simple as Devil Daggers’ run-and-gun routine may seem, there’s enough technical detail to make exploring and exploiting its various systems one chaotic hell of a good time. Unlike other twitchy, reflex-based games from recent memory, this one doesn’t spawn your opponents randomly. It might be hard to believe at first, but there’s a consistent order to the waves of enemies that appear. As I played more and more, I grew accustomed to the exact conditions and exact timing of moves that I needed to pull off before the next sequence began.

If I didn’t have all four skull spawners from the first wave destroyed by the time the first spider shows up, I’d inevitably find myself over-encumbered by the next wave of upgraded spawners. If I didn’t take the spider out immediately after the first centipede spawns, I’d lose all the centipede’s crystals to the spider’s gem-converting powers and have dozens of critter-spewing egg sacs to deal with. Every single error compounds on each other, making things exponentially difficult going forward and adding intense levels of urgency to your every move. Memorizing and maintaining a mental checklist of pixel-perfect motions isn’t necessary to have a good time shooting down demons, but it does make every run feel like a puzzle that I grow closer to understanding each time I return to it.

There are certain games that the speedrunning community has spent ages chipping away at, learning how to exploit weak spots in their code and defy their boundaries, but also working within their restraints to pull off seemingly impossible gaming feats. Devil Daggers feels like a tribute to that spirit, a throwback to a time when games were simple and uncluttered (but not shallow) and completely unapologetic about their intense difficulty.

The faithfulness with which it adapts these principles makes Devil Daggers more than just a retro-for-no-reason gimmick that slaps on the unfiltered textures of old games as a cheap nostalgia trip. It earns its low-detail art direction because it also has the appropriate playstyle to boot.

[h1] Raising Hell[/h1]  

Despite the apparent simplicity of the controls and your abilities, there are plenty of ways to stay a step ahead of your enemies. Fluid movement physics allow ample opportunity for mastering new techniques in speed and agility: bunnyhopping to gain a slight boost in speed became a near-constant necessity as I wove my way around deadly spawners, leading swarms of skulls around the arena until I could take them all out with a good clean side shot.

The Devil Daggers equivalent of rocket jumping (firing a shotgun-like blast of daggers into the floor mid-leap) let me soar over my pursuers, adding some Z-axis movement to the featureless circular arena. Staying on the move is vital, so it’s a huge plus to have smooth controls that make pulling off these quick and cool moves feel great. Your failures will never result from your character not moving or jumping how you told it to. And naturally, you can rebind keys, invert the y-axis, switch to left-handed mode, and adjust your look sensitivity in the options menu for added comfort.

There are only two ways to use your dagger shots to destroy enemies, but the lack of variety becomes more of an interesting gameplay restraint than something unfairly limiting. Holding down left-click shoots a steady, machine gun-like stream of daggers great for precision aiming, while tapping left-click fires off a shotgun-like blast for dealing with close-range threats. Both firing modes become more powerful after collecting 10 crystals, and then again after collecting 75 crystals, but they don’t change beyond that. Finding the right ways to make such a standard weapon work in the increasingly chaotic realm of Devil Daggers is part of the fun.

This is especially true in the way this means of attack interacts with the way different enemies move through the arena, and the way the locations of their weak spots affect how you move through it as well. While your typical floating skull can be taken out with one shot, the horned ones take a few direct hits – or one slower shotgun blast – to kill. Other threats, like spawners and spiders, have to be shot in their weak spots (clearly marked by those coveted red crystals), creating tricky situational challenges.

[h1]Devil Music[/h1]

Devil Daggers also puts its incredible sound design to practical use. In lieu of a soundtrack, every enemy’s unique, continuous noise – from the cackling of the skulls to the insectoid click of giant spider legs – combines over time into a rising chorus of Hell. The more crowded the arena gets, the louder and more intense it becomes. This chilling cacophony doubles as a warning system for your impending doom, a signal to step up your efforts to cull the herd or change your priorities to deal with a new threat. Distinct and deliberate sound design makes it possible to know which enemies are where without even having to look – a clean way to work around the restraints that come with an arena shooter that’s first-person, rather than top-down. Spatial awareness and mob management are required for survival, and Devil Daggers’ combination of fluid movement and utilitarian sound design acknowledges both beautifully.

[h1]The Verdict[/h1]
 
Devil Daggers’ stripped-down and distilled essence of first-person shooter intensity will take up a lot of my time in the weeks to come. Every second longer that I survive in its hellish arena is a new record for myself to break, over and over again. It’s a brutal, but brilliant shooter that finds strength in its minimalism, stretching a few seconds of action here and there into endless hours of dreadful fun.

25636172.review:
Devil Daggers is a delightful little indie title in the vain of games like Geometry Wars (2003) and Asteroids (1979), but masterfully mixed with the original Quake (1996). You play as the unnamed hero, armed only with your magical hand that shoots - nay, spews - daggers. Your mission is to survive for as long as possible against endless waves of Lovecraftian demons, ranging from flying skulls with horns, and giant spiders made of bones, to flying snake skeletons. Did I mention there were tentacles? Well, there are. 

This is a very simple game, but that does not make it a simplistic game. It's a beautifully crafted shooter, that looks and feels just as we remember the shooters from the mid 90s. While it doesn't offer much variety in its gameplay, what it does it does really well. If you spent any time at all playing Quake 20 years ago, this game will surely feel right at home. I can only hope the developer furthers this concept and makes a full-fledged game out of it in the future - and maybe, just maybe, we'll see something that resembles a true-to-roots singleplayer experience with a multi-level campaign.

25634288.review:
★★★☆☆☆
（前回は酔っ払いながらのレビューですので、修正しました）

[h1]アーケードみたいに、短時間で楽しめれるＦＰＳシューティング。[/h1]
ＦＰＳ（cs1.6)出身者の感想です。
従来のＦＰＳと基本は変わらないのですが、ただ、、リロードができなかったり、aim設定が弱かったり、従来のシューティングの面白さが微妙に欠けてます。逆にカジュアルという意味では楽しめれると思います。
良い点としては、スコアーチャレンジができるやりこみ要素。ランキング対応です。
弾は無限でaimがカジュアルで、敵が四方から大量に襲ってきて難しく、その中でちょっとしたホラーテイストがアクセントになってます。
個人的にはそこそこ面白いと思いましたが、値段相応だと率直に思いました。
いつもは値段関係なし（値段とは個人の財政に左右されるから）に他の同類ゲームと比較して★（お勧め度）を付けレビューします。
そういった基本的な観点から考えると、KF（キリングフロアー）や他のＦＰＳ系と比べると微妙という感じなのです。なので、圧倒的好評ですが★３をつけました。値段相応と考えれば、圧倒的好評かもしれません。
★３とはＢ級ゲームランクと同じく、ごく一般に売られているゲームレベルの中では楽しめれる部類ということです。
次に値段を考慮すると、グローバルマーケットでのＤＬ版価格は１００円ぐらいです。
昔、１００円均一でＰＣゲームを良く遊びましたが、そのランクよりは少し良いです。
今はグローバルマーケットでのＤＬ値段が主流ですので、コスパ的にワンコインなら買って損はないでしょう。
評価額＝１００円

あと、個人的にＶＲにガンコン対応したら面白そうだと思いました。

25630349.review:
(2 hours into the game, 22/09/16)
So, a lot of the time spent into this game will be spent in getting gud.
After 500 (or 600, perhaps) seconds of surviving, there won't be much to see. 
However, looks are deceiving, and this is no easy game.
So, it should be noted:

*The game has the best rendition of John Cage's 4'33" (that is, no music)
*The ambience (graphics, sounds, general feeling) is well-achieved
*It's got no difficulty settings; go big or go home
*Hearing the distinct sounds of each enemy and the direction they come from is important (and delightful)
*It has 13 enemies and an increasingly powerful weapon with 3 kinds of attack
*For the most part, the game is not random, and you'll probably get to know the beginning well, but that is not a bad thing
*Unforgiving

8/10 would press R again
