21406128.review:
[b]Don't buy Devil Daggers, if...[/b]
[list]
[*]You want as much content (weapons, characters, levels, skins, maps etc.) as possible for your money
[*]You want to finish a game in multiple playthroughs, or finish them at all (out of the near 10 000 players, none have finished the game yet, so only the devs know if it's even possible)
[*]You don't like old-school [b]inspired[/b] graphics and gameplay mechanics (as in, Quake)
[*]You think $5 is too much for a singleplayer arcade arena mode (though, more modes may come in the future)
[*]You hate horde survival arcade FPS games with slow projectile type ammo
[*]You suffer from CTS, are easily stressed out by unforgiving games or you like happy games

Devil Daggers is for masochists. Especially if you're not too good at FPS games, you will get either frustrated with this game or you will break your wrists trying to survive longer and longer. DD is a hell simulator. No one will hold your hand in hell and neither in DD. 

With persistence and patience you'll learn how to kill the skulls more efficiently or focus on enemies that are harder to dodge. You'll learn how to use the more advanced movement techniques to your advantage and survive past the few waves. By this time, if you're like me, you're hooked.

Playing Devil Daggers is one of the fastest ways to train your (virtual) spatial awareness, reaction time and accuracy. If you suffer from "ingame laziness" or you often pray to RNG gods to be in your favor, you'll quickly get rid of those habits. I play DD in short amounts, that's why I don't have too many hours in it yet or a good score (probably 95 seconds). I wouldn't call DD a time waster, more like an energy booster or brain resetter. I probably couldn't even play DD an hour straight, but I still enjoy it a lot when I play.

Right now, DD is very minimalistic and doesn't have much content in it. It is not easily moddable nor does it have a level editor, but with enough support and interest the game might be updated with either tool officially. There's no timeline when this happens though (not that I know of). The game is already really solid and the graphics look awesome, but I can't help it if I want more eventually. I am not alone with this opinion either and I hope DD will some day support modding and community made levels.

Get it. It's only $5. That's less than what you'd spend for a pint in a bar or for a pack of cigarettes. Yet you can always come back to DD, both of the above are one time use only.

21403597.review:
Not since Geometry Wars Retro Evolved have I been this addicted to a one-life score attack game. Instead of twin stick shooting, however, Devil Daggers looks back toward the jumpy, floaty FPSes that only '90s kids will remember. This game, however, manages to use a nostalgic genre to create something entirely fresh.

The art is spooky and cool. It's not the vague retro-ish style that I've come to expect from this sorta game. Sound design is impeccable and headphones are necessary because the aggghs and skull bounce noises are your best way to determine how close enemies/spawners are located.

It's also neat that the game lets me watch replays of players near my skill level. 

Worth the five bucks so far. It's really refreshing to play a game without persistent upgrades/XP bars. I definitely prefer leaderboards for my replayability carrot-on-a-stick.

21397456.review:
This is one of the greatest games I've ever played and also one of the most simple.

You start the game in an arena with a shiny dagger in front of you.  Pick up the shiny dagger and chaos ensues.  This title hearkens back to a time when all we cared about was high scores in games, and the funny thing is that I can't remember the last time I've been so addicted to a title.  The other thing is that it's 5 bucks, I mean skip coffee or your favorite sugary drink for 1 day and you have the money for it.

There are no levels, no difficulty settings, and no special weapons.  Although you can power up your daggers with gems that the bigger enemies drop, this is about the only thing that changes throughout the course of the game to help you.  The rest of the game changes to destroy you as time goes on :)

This game reminds me of why so many games nowadays reach too far or are just too complicated.  Who gives a crap how complicated a game is if the core of it doesn't stand up?  Well this game is all core and no frills and I just can't stop playing.  Every run is a chance to show yourself how good your reactions, strategy, and aim is.  This is just pure game.

Get it.  Now.

21397335.review: Made with 1990s FPS (ala Quake) and arcade gameplay experience in mind, Devil Daggers is a game that channels the chess-like combat of Doom, arena shooters, twin-stick shooters and plane shooters into one singular intense FPS experience. Despite a relatively sparse gameplay experience (one arena, one weapon), Devil Daggers is packed with extreme replayability, challenge and well-designed aesthetics and atmosphere. With each "credit" lasting from a few seconds to a few minutes (if you're lucky), players will find themselves eventually putting hours into the game.

21397001.review:
Possibly the most elegant FPS devised. Every element serves a purpose. From the scraping dry laughter to the red glint of gems. Devil Daggers is lo-fi poetry in motion. 

The eponymous weapon combines doom 2's double barrel shotgun and Hyperblaster into a single devstating instrument of death. The movement system is straight out of Doom, Quake and Painkiller. Strafe running, strafe jumping, bunny hopping, it's all there. But don't let that speed go to your head. While you can accelerate faster, the enemy has higher top speeds. But their swarms cannot turn as fast. The demonic swarm also has exploitable behaviors, notably they will try to avoid your daggers. This allows you to carve paths of destruction, splitting the demonic hordes as you punch through. With sharp target prioritization, skillful shooting and the grace of a satanic, bullfighting ballerina you can eke out extra seconds of life as you climb the leaderboards. And speaking of the leaderboards, they have a wonderful demo feature. Every scoring run is recorded. Probably the best anti-cheat feature possible for a leaderboard, as well as a wealth of information and techniques.

Sure to fall flat with the cinematic shooter crowd, this is a love letter to ID's glory days, right down to the gritty textures of the low poly models and the palettes that color them. There is no story to tell or goal to achieve except the tale of your own mastery. A total emphasis on skill, no margin for error and absolutely zero downtime (even death holds no loading screens) is this game's hallmark. Devil Daggers demands nothing less than your total attention, and while razor sharp reflexes will serve you well, you need to have an even sharper grasp of position and target priority. Hell has many lessons to teach. It communicates so well there is no need for a HUD. All the information you require is in the motion of your enemy, the sound of bone scraping on stone, your own momentum as you strafe the edges of this platform suspended in the void. 

Devil Daggers is a purposeful distillation of what made the greats so compelling.

21395511.review:
I also covered this game on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aLUTnjiOpzI

I hate Devil Daggers but I love Devil Daggers and unless you don't like brutally hard games that are quick to play and reward lots of practice, you should probably get it.

The concept is simple. You're thrown into a small arena where you will face off against an ever-increasing endless barrage of Hellspawn creatures and need to survive for as long as you can. The only scoring metric is time and you're fighting for top placement on the leaderboards. Sessions are usually very quick (most people will be lucky to survive a minute) and things start hard and only get harder fast. You have unlimited ammo and can fire either a continuous barrage or if you tap your mouse button, blasts similar to a shotgun. There are only a handful of upgrades available, some of which are obtained by collecting red gems the enemies drop and others that you just get automatically for surviving certain amounts of time. That's basically it.

The leaderboards also allow you to view anyone's run. This is a great feature that will not only keep people honest and point out cheaters but is also a great teaching tool, allowing you to glean strategies and ideas for how to improve your own runs. Devil Daggers is all about iterative progress so be prepared to die a lot and to need to play hundreds of times to get good.

Devil Daggers runs on a custom engine and purposefully uses a graphical style similar to old DOS first person shooters like DOOM, Duke Nukem 3D and other Build Engine games. It won't be everyone's cup of tea but as a huge fan of those games, I thought it was a really cool throwback.

This game is cheap, dead simple to understand but brutally hard to master. You'll hate it and love it at the same time. I highly recommend it.

21394146.review:
Devil Daggers, to put it bluntly, is a masterwork. An elegantly designed arcade style arena FPS that not only is an example of a simple idea done well, but its posterchild. From the introductory screen onward, the bleak Gothic atmosphere takes hold, clearly worshiping at the altar of Quake, with stark colors and industrial edged background music. Starting the game, the goal is simple: navigate and combat a horde of demons as they spawn into the arena. The longer you survive, the higher your score, and the higher your place on the leaderboards. One hit however, and it's all over. The game is punishingly difficult, but not unfair. It provides you with a plethora of tools to deal with the onslaught. You have incredible fluidity of movement, that allows you to bunnyhop and dodge and weave your way through enemies. You have a single weapon, the daggers, which are actual projectiles (as opposed to hitscan) with two alternate fire modes, a spraying rapid fire which must be well timed and lead, and a shotgun like blast, that requires twitch accuracy for maximum effect. You can use that blast to catapult yourself into the air, a "rocket jump"-esque maneuver. These abilities not only skyrocket the skill ceiling, but the excellent pace of the game allows you to learn without becoming comfortable, pushing your ability constantly. Once in motion, this is where the visual and sound design shine brightest, both from a mechanical and artistic standpoint. Artistically, the game is one of the most cohesive and focused visions I've seen in games recently. The monster design is impeccable, managing to be both complicated and clear, grotesque and horrifying, and how everything is rendered evokes the days of the old school shooter. On top of that, the 3D sound allows for complete immersion, with each monster giving off it's own call until the arena is crescnedoed into an orchestra of foul clicks, jittering, and crys. Mechanically, these same things give the player all the information they need to move about the arena: monster silhouettes are easily distinguishable, and the host of audio cues not only tell you where the monsters are, but what kind of monster it is lurking outside your vision. But even with all that, the game will kill you. Thankfully it never steps into frustrating territory. The game allows to you instantly restart a run at any time, placing you back at the beginning in less than a second. This ease of access prevents frustration to set in between attempts, and greatly increases the draw of an already addictive formula. And to top it all off with a nice little bow, the leaderboards feature a replay system. Not only will you be able to watch back your own high score, to either show off, or to see how you did it, but anyone on the visible leaderboard will have a replay available of the run that put them there in the first place, enabling you to study those ahead of you simply by clicking an icon. It's a brilliant package, but understandably not for everyone. The steep difficulty paired with the admittedly low amount of content will be enough to put some off, and that is understandable, but at five dollars it's difficult to argue against its value. Wholeheartedly recommended.

(Steam Awards 2 Edit: 30 hours later, still a masterpiece).

21381835.review:
OK, this game is brutal.  But it is brutal in a great way.  It punishes you, but not in a cheap way.  When you die, you die through your own faults.  Not paying attention, not listening to the audio cues that tell you death is eminent, not strategizing on which enemy/spawner you need to take out first, and failing to take out said spawner in enough time before the other several spawners on the floor start spawning more monsters.  There is no delay in controling your invisible protagonist.  It will take one to two attempts of playing the game to get a feel for how the daggers (your only weapons) perform.  Every I played, I managed to get just a little further in.  As I have progressed, its difficulty has scalled up and up and up.  Glorious, and engaging.

Gameplaywise, this game is solid.  Easy to understand controls, easy to understand mechanics, and really easy to jump in and jump out regarding game play.  One session or an hours worth, you can put as much time as you like in this game and continue enjoying yourself as long as this sort of action FPS horde mode game is your cup of tea.

The enemies keep coming, and they keep you on your toes constantly, with virtually no breaks to catch your breath.  Which brings me to really the only thing holding this game back from general players.  

There is a limited variety provided by this game.

You have one weapon, while it does evolve as you progress (hoovering blood crystals or what ever they are), it is still the devil daggers by which the game's title implies.  As you progress through the waves, the enemies increase in number, but seem to be limited to around 10 total types of enemies (this is as much as I have seen through my playthrough and others playthroughs.)

There is also only ONE dimmly lit arena (that you can kill yourself by falling off the edge), that can leave you wishing it was just a little bigger.  If the game ends, I have not seen the ending yet (at the time of this review).  This unfortunately sets the game with a very small amount of content provided for its cost.

I understand how this sort of thing can be a turn off to people.  As far as I am concerned, this game is simply addictive and amazing in the vein of a solid arcade title.  If the developers decided to add more to the game, it would be amazing, but I personally feel it is not nessesary to maintain a level of interest that will keep me coming back.

Given its price tag, I would advertise this game as an arcade gem, and well worth the investment.

21380947.review:
Wow. Absolutely blew me away. 

First of all, especially given the price point, YES, it's worth your investment. Think of this game as mixture of Unreal Tournament, Doom, Magic Carpet, and Geometry Wars. The intensity, addictive quality, and horror are all top-notch. Of particular note is the SOUND DESIGN and direction. I'm an extremely jaded survival horror fan, and it's tough to impress me with audio - or scare me with it, given that I'm a noise musician in my spare time - but the relentless, terrifying soundscape that this game includes grates on you and psychologically fatigues you in the best possible way. 

It's truly a refreshing experience and a ton of fun. A brutal challenge but sooooo worth the money.

Now, DEVS: If you're reading this, I think you have an amazing formula here and I hope you expand on it. I could see this functioning very well as a stand alone title. Part of what makes it so unique and cool is that it's not bloated with a million additional add-ons, and seems like a genuine labor of love. Another reviewer described it as a nearly perfect game, and I agree. HOWEVER, I'm concerned with the game's longevity. I would appreciate a few power-ups and/or additional weapons along the way. Maybe a minimalized system like Binding of Isaac's character selection, where you can eventually unlock some different abilities or something like that. I would totally respect you if you disagreed with that opinion - in fact, I would admire your commitment to your aesthetic! However, that might be the difference between me playing this game for 5 hours or for 50 hours.

 Ultimately, I'm glad this game exists. I very much hope you will entertain the possibility of making a sequel or some DLC to expand on the ideas you have. You have an incredibly solid foundation and I hope to see it grow. Then again, if it doesn't, I'll love it all the same. 

In fact, I like the game so much I would be happy to volunteer to work on it. Not that you guys need the help, but if you're willing to point me in the direction of a way to mod the game, I'd be happy to prototype some features - I have some experience with game design and coding. I guess what I'm saying is... this game gets me excited about making and playing games! I hope that serves as a compliment - it's certainly intended as such!

This game has given me arcade fever. It feels like Quake with more hellish legions. The sounds and visuals are stunning, the rounds are fast and brutal, and the controls are super tight. There's just enough momentum in your hopping and shotgun-jumping to make tight maneuvers challenging but rewarding to pull off. Each round lasts about 60-90 seconds (for me) and they always get me pumped. I'm not really someone who's typically driven by competition, but the challenge this game presents is too tempting for me to turn down. It's an incredible bullet hell that's devilishly satisfying to play. 

One of my favorite features is how you can download and watch replays from the people topping the leaderboards so you can learn some of the tactics they use to stay alive. And in a game like this where mechanical mastery and knowledge of the challenges you'll have to face are key to survival, that's an amazing feature. Even the top-scoring run is less than eight minutes long at the time of writing this - which means the game is incredibly challenging - but there's a lot of nuance in understanding the enemy design and movement, so having an opportunity to see the game from the perspective of someone who clearly has a level of mastery beyond your own is invaluable. 

The game almost feels minimalist in design. There's one game mode, and the core of the gameplay is super simple to learn. But it's brilliant in execution. It's extremely satisfying. I'm addicted to trying to beat my friends' scores. I cannot recommend this game more highly for the price.

21368195.review:
A fantastic title well worth the asking price.

You load up the game, click play and you instantly start playing. No tutorials, no boring ass cutscenes or dialogue to suffer through. This is a game where you have to learn everything yourself unless of course you look up directions.

Visuals -
A nice retro 90's shooter aesthetic made on a completely custom engine the devs built.
Enemies are demonic and creepy with some really nice touches. The giant spider who sucks in gems is especially scary.
The level is nothing more than a flat piece of land with repeating textures with an abyss of blackness around it.

7/10. Would be higher if the ground had a little more to it, but I appreciate it for what it is.

Audio - 
Everything is a creepy crunchy, crackle and ambient sound. As you progress through the game and new enemies appear, they make different sounds. Each enemy makes a unique sound so you know what to be aware of. Your hand that shoots "Devil Daggers" at the start make a low hum but as you progress gets louder into a screeching almost screaming sound, like tortured souls of hell.

10/10. I know that seems generous but it has been quite some time since a game has blown me away with the audio.

Gameplay -
The game is about as simple as it it gets. You spawn in and shoot enemies, however, you also have other objectives to be aware of. The floating pillars for example spawn the flying enemies who chase you down to kill you. If you do not kill the pillars they will keep spawning enemies over and over. The game is also set with a timer that always spawns set pieces of different enemies so if you don't take out the pillars they will keep spawning as the game progresses. Getting the red gems upgrades your Devil Dagger arm and those are absolutely crucial if you want to progress, so you have to always be collecting whilst killing. Each enemy moves differently and has different weak points so you have to be quick with you aiming and skillful as well. This game is VERY DIFFICULT.

5/10. The gameplay is fantastic but suffers from a repetitive feel after so long, but when you pick it back up after a break it feels fresh again. The ranking leaderboards also keep you striving to get further. 

OVERALL - The game is a breath of fresh air do to its dark art style and excellent sound design. It takes your traditional horde type gameplay and adds in horror and desperation making you feel the adrenaline as you get firther along. Fun in short burts but lacks long term playing due to no level design. I'd recommend this game only to those who strive for leaderboards or a challenge, anyone who is looking to shoot and go through waves with relative ease or enjoy a more slow paced game should skip this.

FINAL SCORE - 6/10.

21367501.review: Devil Daggers is an extremely fast paced twitch shooter entirely focused on score attack. This focus on score attack may be off putting to a lot of people, as it means there is very little content outside of improving your rank on the leaderboard. The game does some work to help this issue by layering new gameplay and enemies as you progress into a run however if you aren't focused on improving your score from the beginning you won't see this as the point where this begins to occur requires at least an hour of grinding to reach. If you are interested in score attack however, this game is a treat. The feeling of rising the leaderboard is very satisfying and the skill based twitch gameplay ensures that skill is the primary factor of getting a good score. This results in a very satisfying and addictive experience that you will keep wanting to play again and again. If you're looking for a fast paced shooter with a lot of content then look elsewhere. However, if you want a fast paced zen-like leaderboard grinding experience then this game may be for you.

I won't spoil anything, but I will reccomend you carefully examine everything, the ui, the mechanics, everything, and experiment experiment experiment. This game is HARD. 

The game mechanics are simple: kill demons, gather crystals and don't get hit while shooting a stream or bursts of daggers from your fingertips.
You will get punished for waiting around too long, you need to keep moving, dodging and being aware of the enemies around you.

The sound design is brilliant. Enemies are really creepy when you hear them chasing you. You can hear crystals being pulled towards you, which gives you the choice to stop shooting for a moment and become stronger or keep on fighting.

The gameplay can be frustrating if you keep getting impaled by that nasty horned skull, but also very satisfying if you do manage to overpower the hordes and survive for just a few second longer.

21362577.review:
Devil daggers is a supercharged shooter that is very close to games like the original quake in terms of speed and super hexigon due to difficulty. The game itself just starts up with you standing in front of a dagger and once you pick it up you are immidiately attacked by an array of 3 types of enemies which only get more and more difficult as the timer goes on, it can be extremely difficult for some people to even pass the 60 second mark.

Outside of that the game has no story, no secrets (unless you count figuring out how the game mechanics work) and nothing but the challenge of the game. In that respect it is a lot like super hexagon where the whole game is centered around beating your friends highscores and beating your own previous score. It should be said though, that the enemies do become predictable after some time and often you can tell immidiately when the new enemies are going to spawn so once you play the game a whole lot the beginning can become a bit tiring as you face the same pattern of beginning enemies again and again.

Altough i cannot verify one thing it does feel like the game is always using the same random seed per session, so you will always face the same pattern of enemies every round, i would count down the seconds between each enemy spawn because i had been repeating the same pattern over and over (3 spawners, 1 super spawner and then the skull spider with more super spawners). 

However, despite that i have to say the game is exactly what i expected it to be when i got it and as such i am enjoying the nailbiting difficulty of it and i will probably play until i reach a point where i simply cannot beat my previous score. 

Pros:
- Really addicting and makes you want to constantly beat your previous score.
- High speed movement and twitchy shooting makes the skill ceiling extremely high (tip: you can shotgun blast yourself up into the air)
- The enemies are varied and are a constant challenge, however you can learn their patterns quite quickly
- You will always want to dethrone your friends high score

Neutral points:
- From what i've noticed the game seed is always the same. I cannot verify this but whenever i play the enemy spawn is always the same so learning patterns is sometimes part of the challenge.

Cons:
- Everything you see in the trailer is all there is in the game. There are no secrets, no story no nothing so if you get bored of the base game then there is nothing to hook you back in
- There is no fov slider and altough the fov is not bad it can still cause some people motion sickness and cause it so you can't see enemies coming from the side.

21360017.review:
Devil Daggers is an arcade scoring FPS. While this review is negative, it only means that I do not personally recommend the game. It does not mean that I think that this is a terrible game, so please do not vote me down just because you are a fanboy defending your game.

That being said, Devil Daggers consists of surviving as long as possible in a (very small) square where darkness reigns, while killing hundreds of skulls thrown at you. That's all there is to the game, no levels to beat, no permanent or temporary progression, just occasionally a new enemy type makes its appearance while the skulls keep swarming and swarming. 

Tentacle pillars dispense skulls and need to be disposed of quickly after their first batch before they vomit an overwhelming army. Flying skulls are quick, they home in on the players, and are a CONSTANT pain to deal with. Very rarely there is a moment to breathe, which means that the pacing of the game is very intense, and in my opinion completely off. It feels tedious and repetitive. Moreover, always the same enemies are coming at the same moment, so unlike roguelites the player does not learn the systems and then adapt to different situations: here, the sequence is the same, so the player has to do the same thing over and over until they learn the partition of the music they play (although there is no in-game soundtrack).

I would compare this game to Super Hexagon: play the sequence over and over until you get good at mastering it, and then get farther into the game.

Conversely, I suppose that some very skilled players would be able to get quite far without needing to learn the sequence, just by sheer skill of shooting and moving, The shooting consists of pressing once for shotgun or keeping the finger of the mouse for machine gun fire. Collecting gems from enemies (stop shooting to attract them like a magnet) eventually upgrades the firepower. Shooting feels good, just too bad that I am fighting swarms of skulls and not interesting enemy types that come in waves inside a bigger arena.

A very interesting addition to this game is the ability to watch the replay from anyone in the leaderboard. Very useful to learn or just be mesmerized at the graphics without focusing on surviving.

To me the main draw of the game is the art style and atmosphere (although there is no in-game soundtrack). The graphics and gameplay throw back to Quake, and will probably attract the same kind of elitist crowd. Sadly, the content is too simple and repetitive.

21359280.review: If you started gaming in the early 1990s then this will feel all too familiar. Simple, yet extremely complex in terms of strategy and movement. Gets your heart goin.

21358579.review:
"This game is metal as fuck" -Brad Shoemaker

Devil Daggers is a really cool game. It has a lot of /style/ and does something I never thought could be possible: use a visual style perfectly reminiscing the swimmy, trashy look of PlayStation 1 games... and make it look good. The graphics remind me of FROM Software's seminal PS1 masterpiece "Shadow Tower", and while that might not be the direct influence, it's clear that the dev has a fondness for the dirty, unfiltered look of the PlayStation's early 3D games, and due to the buttery smooth framerate, it looks pretty dang neat.

The sound design is phenomenal, but I feel like it needed some kick-ass music, and I recommend using the QUAKE II soundtrack as a perfect supplement to this game's rough, spartan, and devilish design.

The gameplay is rock solid, but it is almost unbearably difficult, and the people at the top of the leaderboards are insane. Your mileage may very on whether you like the constant retrying that this game forces you to do. 

I love it though.

A spooktacular game about the worlds most talented floating hand coming across satans favorite cutlery. I guess he wants it back because every demon and their cat wants to fuck me up now that the hand absorbed it. 


This game sparked my interest just from aesthetics alone back when I saw it as a greenlight project. Knowing greenlights reputation most would be wary of this games fate. Thankfully it turned out to be a gem. The kind of gem that was put under the same kind of pressure it will now put you under when you play it. 

This game makes me sweat balls. Ten minutes of playing it and I am sweating balls. This game puts you under more stress than the gemstones you carve out of your enemies bodies. The opposition starts out pretty light but no less than ten seconds later you are up against an avalanche of the spooky skeleton swarms from every direction, your only means of detecting the spook parade being their incessant chattering over your shoulder. 

Which means wear headphones. This game is intentionally dark and the only means of knowing where the next swarm is coming from is audio qeues and the faint gleam of gemstones. The fantastic audio design makes me sweat even more balls as skeletors testicles are chattering mere inches behind me.

The gameplay is basic, and thats good. Its the Hotline Miami of shooters. You spray daggers faster than the beads of sweat will roll down your face or you double click to shotgun blast them. You get touched, you die, you restart, you sweat balls again repeatedly in short bursts of life trying desperately to survive more than mere minutes. Its amazing. 

If you like sweating balls and getting stressed out of your mind you should play this game.

Devil Daggers coutinues to amaze. With every update comes new enemies and challenges, but be warned, this content is usually locked to the best of the best. It's a shame because the second large difficulty boost really puts your skill to the test. I'm slowly getting there, but that is the point of Devil Daggers. Die, die, and die until you overcome. Then start it up all over again.

My biggest reason for extending this review is because I feel like in the time that I've played Devil Daggers, I have literally become a better FPS player.

This game is like bootcamp for fast, movement heavy shooters such as Q3A, CPMA, Reflex, and (shoutout) Neotokyo.

Movement, positioning, situational awareness, timing, and aim. All of these play such a big part in Devil Daggers that as long as you keep pushing yourself here, you'll keep getting better at everything else. How a game can be so focused on its objectives to the point where it spills over into other shooters in the genre shows that the game should be up there with the greats. Truly inspiring stuff.

Hail Sorath.

21350107.review:
This game is not going to be for everybody, but the people it IS for are going to adore it.

As brief as possible: this is a retro-style arena shooter with bunny-hopping and rocket-jumping, and your only goal is to kill as many demons as possible and survive as long as you can. Most games will initially end within 20-40 seconds. World record was, up until yesterday, 8 minutes. Kill things, grab the powerups they drop, learn the nuances of the individual enemies, the enemy spawning (this game is not random every time), and try to beat your high score. And do it over and over again.

The graphics, sound, and feel are second to none. If you loved fast-paced shooters like Doom and Quake back in the day, you'll feel right at home. Some will feel it's too limited, but limited is the point. This is distilled to a pure essence, and anything added would dilute the intensity of that pure experience. Which isn't to say that more couldn't be done or added, but this game is a steal at 5 bucks, and the limited nature of what it currently is is exactly what makes it so special.

Not for everyone, but it's intense, difficult, and will make your heart pound like nothing else.

21350063.review:
A small but shining gem of what an indie game can be. It does everything it says it can on the package, and does it all while looking great, feeling great, and sounding great too.

Positives:

-The visuals, the sound design, the gamefeel, all of these work together very well to create something new and unique while also harkening back to older, more cozier days of PC gaming.

-Satisfying and challenging combat that usually makes you want to give it another go after you die.

-Really cool leader boards system that lets you see your friends and other top players runs with the ability to slow them down and see how exaclty they survived for that long.

-An overall awesome little package for only $5.

Cons:

-There might not be enough in the game to interest some players. An endless survival mode has the possibility to be boring for some, even when everything else in it is great.

-The sheer challenge of surviving long enough to see what other types of hellish hordes the game has to throw at you might be simply too challenging for some players to accomplish. So far, there are no easy modes or cheat codes to accomodate them, albeit if there were easy-modes/cheats, it would be best that the leaderboards would be disabled in those modes of course.

Overall:

This game shows real heart, talent, and effort. It is beautifully Hellish, and capitolizes on this with it's punishing but satisfying gameplay. One can only hope that sometime in the future there will be more to this, or more from these devs, because the engine is amazing in how well it makes retro work on modern day machines. It would be a godsend if it were to one day become open source... But for now, I'll enjoy ramming my skull against others in this Devilishly Demonic game.

21345157.review:
Devil Daggers est l'exemple ultime du jeu "easy to pick, hard to master". Conçu comme un shooter boosté a la cocaïne et a l'ambiance glaçante, Devil Daggers est à la hauteur du temps que vous comptez investir dedans.

L'unique intérêt du jeu (hors ambiance visuelle et sonore) c'est son leaderboard. Si vous vous investissez dans Devil Daggers c'est pour tenter de voir votre nom le plus haut possible dans le classement. N’espérez pas y trouver un autre intérêt, son gameplay en fait un jeu a scoring. Certes, c'est toujours sympathique histoire de vous faire une petite partie comme ça pour le fun après une journée pourrie, mais je pense que ce qui rend Devil Daggers vraiment bon, c'est avant tout le joueur. Devil Daggers est frustrant, mais pas dans le sens ou il va faire rage-quit, mais plutôt dans le sens « bordel je suis mort comme un con, je peux pas laisser passer ça, encore un essai ». J'en suis a neufs heures de jeux et je pense y passer encore beaucoup afin de m'améliorer ainsi que mon score.

Le score, parlons en, est simplement le temps pendant lequel vous avez survécu avant de vous faire misérablement tuer. Une partie moyenne après un temps d'adaptation et d'apprentissage du jeu, des mécaniques et des ennemis, est a peu près de 2 minutes. Bien sur, au premier try il y a peu de chance que vous arriviez a ce score, mais au bout d'une petite heure, ce score sera largement atteint, pour peu que vous fassiez attention. En effet, la courbe de progression sur le jeu est très agréable et brosse toujours le joueur dans le sens du poil. « T'es mort ? C'est que t'as fait une erreur, mais t’inquiètes, maintenant tu sais comment fonctionne cet ennemi et tu devrai être en mesure d'éviter l'échec au prochain try ». Chacun des ennemi a un comportement bien spécifique, qui est de temps en temps altéré selon votre placement et vos actions, mais c'est justement l'apprentissage de ces comportements qui vous fera survivre de plus en plus longtemps.
Bon maintenant, quid réellement du gameplay ? Comme je l'ai dit c'est un shooter chargé à la coco. Imaginez Quake (premier du nom) dans une arène très restreinte qui ne vous laisse pas de marge d'erreur. Si vous sortez de l'arène, vous mourrez. Si vous vous prenez un ennemi, vous mourrez. Si vous foncez dans un pylône qui fait office de spawner, vous mourrez. Une touche et c'est la mort, expéditive mais riche d'enseignement.
A chaque ennemi (sauf les cranes de base), vous gagnez une gemme. Enfin, celle-ci tombe au sol et ne vous sera attribué que si vous la ramassez, ou si vous arrêtez de tirer, vous laissant vulnérable. Ces gemmes n'ont aucun intérêt pour le score de manière directe, mais concernant vos chances de survies... elle sont indispensables. A chaque palier (10 gemmes pour le premier, 60 gemmes pour le second, etc), le jeu vous donne une amélioration pour vos dagues : plus de cadence de tir, de dispersion pour votre tir « shotgun », des dagues a têtes chercheuses. Inutile de préciser qu'elles seront plus que nécessaires pour votre survie.
Pour survivre, l'apprentissage et les gemmes ne seront pas vos seuls alliés. Vous pouvez aussi profiter d'un panel de moyen de déplacement. Courir tout simplement ne suffira pas a survivre aux assauts incessants, par contre, vous pouvez faire du bunny-hopping ainsi que du rocket jump pour profiter d'une plus grande vitesse. Mais attention, vous perdrez aussi en contrôle et vous risquez de vous jeter tête la première hors de l'arène ou dans un ennemi.
Plus haut, j'ai parlé d'une ambiance glaçante. Je ne parlais pas simplement de l'esthétique infernale, des cranes volants, des spawners a tentacules. Le jeu profite d'un sound design absolument parfait, qui n'est pas juste là pour vous faire frémir, puisqu'il est vital de faire extrêmement attention aux sons environnants pour savoir ou sont les différents ennemis et pour éviter de vous faire avoir bêtement dans le dos.
N'essayez pas de nettoyer entièrement l'arène, mais soyez précis. Privilégiez les cibles susceptibles de vous amener vers la mort. Le jeu vous encouragera a plus faire du crowd control qu'il ne fera de vous un Rambo des enfers. Aussi les cranes simples ne seront pas ceux qui vous poseront le plus de problèmes vu qu'ils vous suivent bêtement (m'enfin, ne soyez pas trop confiant non plus, des runs se sont terminées de manières abrupt par un excès de confiance).
Devil Daggers permet aussi de farmer les gemmes, en laissant les spawners cracher des hordes infernales. Plus de gemmes, plus de pouvoir comme je l'ai dit, mais c'est un risque conséquent, aussi bien au niveau des ennemis qui se feront plus nombreux, mais aussi des spawners susceptibles de freiner votre bunny hopping  a reculons de manière assez cocasse... Oui en crevant comme un con.

Bref, pour faire clair et concis, Devil Daggers est le jeu de scoring que j'attendais depuis longtemps. L'exécution est quasi parfaite, je ne pourrais que lui reprocher une perte de contrôle dès que l'ont fait du bunny hopping, mais même la je chipote, le système est si bien réalisé que l'on peut faire du bunny hopping en cercle. Je pourrais aussi pester contre les ennemis qui ont des fois des comportements un peu aléatoires, mais la encore je chipote. Devil Daggers vaut très largement ses 5 euros et rien qu'avec les 9 heures passées dessus j'ai largement rentabilisé l'investissement. Devil Daggers est dur, exigeant et nerveux, un pur jeu de scoring.

21344047.review:
Beautifully eerie, gothic art style, coupled with some truly unsettling sound effects; Devil Daggers is a wonderfully hellish game.

Very easy to pick up and play, with immediately satisfying gameplay (shoot a stream of daggers from your hand by holding fire, shoot a shotgun blast of daggers by clicking fire), it will destroy you in under a minute. But then you'll try again, and last just a little longer... and so the cycle begins.

Don't expect great depths here - you're on a flat platform, floating in blackness, as enemies spawn and swarm you. That's it. That's literally it. But that's really all it needs to be.

One caveat though, and a personal request for the developer:

The art style is so brilliant, I'd love to see you make some actual *environments*. Some hellish temples, with twisting bone spires; some Doom-style nightmare landscapes. Devil Daggers is so distinctive, it deserves to become a franchise, and I would love to see... *more*, in every respect.

21341128.review:
Devil Daggers is an endless arcade shooter that's incredibly challenging, yet satasfying.
It's best suited for short burst gameplay, around 30-60 second rounds, but of course if you're capable, even longer. Infact that's the real goal. To survive as long as possible.

The mechanics are pretty simple. You can shoot a stream of "devil daggers" or tap your shoot key for a shotgun-like burst. You can also collect red jewels as you kill larger enemies to improve your devil daggers' strength. It's all about micromanaging your spatial awareness, and priority in what to kill. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Lgq7yKxj4tw
Though the premise is simple enough, the challenge is incredibly high. You'll get overwhelmed with enemies very quickly if you're not careful. Surviving for longer than a minute per round is a true achievement. There is an addictive value to the game's design loop with "one more game" as the initiative to replay over and over again. 

The game's visuals are striking and stylized. With an eerie Gothic horror look, rendered in a pixel-3D aesthetic. The sound design is disturbing and compliment it's visuals quite well. It presents a moody atmosphere that drew me in.

The game can certainly be considered repetitive, and with only one mode to play it dosn't help it's repetition. After playing just a few rounds I quickly understood why the game was so cheap at $5.00 USD. There really isn't much content here. Luckily for us, what is here is addictive, challenging, and satasfying.

Overall, Devil Daggers is a cheap, grotesquely gorgeous endless shooter that is well suited for score attackers. It's short on content, but makes it up an addictive designed gameplay loop. 

Pros:
- Atmospheric visual and sound design
- Incredibly challenging
- Very addictive
- Appropriate price tag

Cons:
- Short on content
- Might not be for everyone

21340590.review:
Straight forward and simplistic first person shooter where you try to survive as long as possible.
Global and Friends leaderboards with the ability to watch replays straight from the leaderboards.

The artstyle reminds me of a cross between DOOM and QUAKE. Has the pixely texture qualities of DOOM but the somewhat simple model geometry of QUAKE (its actually more complex but feels classic).

It's super tough and made me hate it.
But it dumps you back in for another run so fast it's hard to stop.

Value really depends on what you can get out of what is really a completely repetitive game where you are just trying to live as long as you can. At this time the longest run is around 8 minutes. Average runs are around 1 minute. 

But again, it's super tough and made me hate it.
But I can't stop...

21340241.review:
Devil Daggers is probably the most addictive game I've played this year. 
The controls are perfect, the seamless transition between each run (hint: use "r" to quick restart) makes dying just an incentive to play again, shooting and moving feels fantastic.

The enemy design is wonderful, the sound design is obviously amazing.

If I had to criticise: it could probably do with giving new players a little more information on the controls. And, the arena could stand to be a little large.

Overall though I highly recommend this game to anyone who either wants a great, classic FPS, or even just something to get obsessed with.

21329218.review:
Imagine Quake and Geometry Wars got together and had freaky loving, using positions from HP Lovecraft's Kamasutra, and the resulting Mellisandre style shadow-baby that crawled it's way forth is Devil Daggers.

The game plays like a first person bullet hell, the sound design is amazing and all the creepy scuttling and vworping you hear around you isn't just there to freak you out, but to aurally position enemy hellspawn. The graphical style evokes classic 90's era shooters, and it works extremely well here. Gameplay is stripped down to the absolute bare minimum, there's only one goal; seemingly to stay alive for as long as possible. I think I would've enjoyed the game so much more if there was more to it, some levels to traverse instead of just a straight up endless wave survival mode, but for a game that's whole focus is being so ultra stripped down, it's hard to really fault the pure simplicity of it. And for the price? Not bad at all.

21322121.review:
Devil Daggers is a fast-paced arena shooter in which you rely on your skill to survive wave after wave of demonic monsters.  The graphics and engine and movement are inspired by classics such as Quake and Doom and it looks absolutely outstanding.

Unfortunately, that's where my praise ends.  It says I've only played 0.3 hours, but it requires less time than that to explore the features of the game outside of the need to keep practicing the game to get better to hopefully make it to the end.

*edit: I spent 2 more hours on this game to get into the top 10% of the leaderboard (at the time) and to make another video because I was unfair in the one I linked here.  My opinion is unchanged.

Frankly, there isn't anywhere close to 5 dollars worth of content in this game.  You get one relatively small arena with no physical obstacles, no differentiation in how the game begins, with one gun that supposedly upgrades as you proceed (though admittedly I'm not good enough to get that far).  You know what else you can get for 5 dollars?  The Binding of Isaac.

There is a replay feature that you can find from the leaderboards to see how the best of the best get through it, which is actually pretty cool.  That's a feature I'd love to see in more games in some capacity.

I can respect what this game wants to do with its movement and its graphical style and its engine and I think all that is really cool, but it simply needs more.  One arena with one gun with one set of waves simply is not enough.  What really confuses me is how this game currently has over 90 positive reviews singing its praises and only 7 negative reviews that are constantly being flagged as "unhelpful" for some reason.  It almost seems a little bit sketchy, as I've seen better games get shat on for less.

Also, there is no invert mouse option.  In 2016, there's no invert mouse option in a first person shooter.  [i]Ridiculous[/i].

I made a video for this game, which you can see here if you'd like to see the gameplay in action:
https://youtu.be/kggCdt2GYc8

Key was provided by the developer and Dietrich Online Services. I'd have thought this game would be a fun little time waster for a dollar, but if I had spent my own money on this at 5 dollars I would have been profoundly disappointed and demanded a refund.

21317971.review:
https://youtu.be/1lu35ui-Iqc
[i]Game:[/i] Devil Daggers
[i]Genre:[/i] Old-School Endless Shooter
[i]Developer:[/i] Sorath
[i]Publisher:[/i] Sorath
[i][u]Copy supplied by developer[/u][/i]

[b]Devil Daggers[/b] is a first-person endless shooter developed and published by Sorath.

[h1]GRAPHICS[/h1]
The custom made engine works fludly and the game does look really good, with a strong Doom vibe from all the monsters you fight. I would like to see something more in the area in which you fight, like small obstacles or walls, because like this it tends to get repetitive.

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
Your goal is to survive an endless wave of monsters for as long as you can. Your only weapon is an unlimited amount of daggers that you shoot from your hand. The longer you play, more monsters start appearing, and you unlock some bonuses for your attack. You can also bunnyhop to gain more speed.
This is literally the entire game. It's simple, straight-forward and hard to master. It does get very repetitive after a while, and it works better in short game sessions.

[h1]CHALLENGE[/h1]
The game is tough as nails: you die with one hit by either getting hit by enemies, running into them, or falling off the map. Only masochists and hardcore Quake fans will really enjoy playing this game.

[h1]SOUND[/h1]
The sound design is pretty solid, however it does lack a lot in music and you will easily get annoyed by the constant throwing of daggers and monster noises after a bunch of minutes.

[h1]REPLAYABILITY[/h1]
You also want to play another time, just to get a higher score. But you probably won't. It gets very frustrating, but if you like to get better scores every time you will most definitely spend hours and hours mastering this game.

Overall, fans of endless shooters will have a blast playing this game, and for its cheap price I do recommend it. Remember that it is tough as nails and kind of repetitive in the long run.

21314114.review:
I was so hyped for this game and sure enough, ESPECIALLY for just five bucks, this game is a satisfyingly dark and addicting FPS romp through your most devilish and demonic nightmares. The enemies are delightfully horrifying, the combat and movement are unbelievably smooth, and the scoring and ranking mechanic is simple but gratifying, especially if you can get your friends into this game.

I can see how it would get repetitive for some, but this is the kind of game where you need to perfect your technique and strategy to a T if you want to keep improving your score. I was afraid the "low-res" textures and art style would become tiring or strain my vision, but after playing this game almost two hours straight I haven't had to worry about it.

Simply put, if you watched the trailer and aren't totally appalled by the game's art style, and you like fast, fluid, buttery-smooth FPS action, you need Devil Daggers.

21314044.review:
I hate time and/or score attack games, I really do. But Devil daggers is something different.

It brings back those absolutely delicious Quake I looks with Herectic/Hexen/Doom feel and mixes it all in a pot with it's nightmarish atmosphere and AMAZING sound design.

The gameplay is simple: Run around shooting skulls and other really weird and creepy stuff until they die, collecting gems to get a couple of levels that make your daggers better. Get touched once, you die. Rinse and repeat, each time getting a higher score, or just dying in the first 30 seconds because that skull should not have been there! Or because you just fell off the ledge...

[b] Conclusion: It's fast paced, it's satisfying, it's nightmarish, it's good, it's Devil Daggers. [/b]

Devil Daggers feels like playing a Quake mod designed by the Hotline Miami developers. It's got the grimy aesthetic and gameplay of the former with the high-stakes intensity of the latter. Make a single mistake? You're dead, press r to retry. Lose focus at all? Oops, press r to retry. Have a conscious thought? Noob, press r to retry. The life span of a Devil's Dagger game is 

The difference with Devil Daggers is that it's a wave/horde/arena shooter that takes place on a circular platform hovering above a deadly void. That tiny circle gets flooded with enemies so quickly that lasting a full minute feels like an accomplishment. Then some cheeky bastard will blindside you, and you'll die. And then you'll press r to retry.

R/10 would retry again.

21311870.review:
It's goooooood.  

There's not much else to say.  It's a simple game where the few moving parts are made beautifully.  You have one gun, the Devil Daggers, that can fire like a shotgun or machinegun.  You shoot the weakpoints and collect them to upgrade your fingers. WASD movement.  Survive long enough to get on the leaderboards.  That's it.

Except that isn't just it.

It's a game about making a million binary choices every second.

The first enemies you face are a tower that spews a swarm of fast moving skulls and one bigger one that just kind of runs away.  Do you destroy the tower quickly, or clear the mobs first?  Depends on the moment. Destroy a few and a massive skull spider shows up.  You need to destroy it quickly or it'll send out a bunch of spider hatchlings.  But wait, the larger skulls from earlier just flipped over, have 5 times the health, are chasing you now, and are cackling maniacly.  Do you destroy the laughing skulls and risk the spiders hatching?  

Maybe you just want to run away.  Game's got you covered.  You can bunnyhop easily by jumping every time you hit the ground, making you slightly faster than the swarms of skulls.  Of course, then you can't turn easily.  Do you want to risk bunnyhopping when it could lead you into a swarm you could easily avoid on foot, or will the speed be your best bet at the moment?  Need to just go backwards as fast as possible?  Or possibly up?  Use the shotgun blast to rocketjump.  You got away!  Of course, you might accidentally launch yourself off the edge of the arena.  Is going backwards worth that risk?

See?  Just a bunch of simple risk/reward choices.  But you only have one health, so every choice matters.  And even the first enemy makes you make 3 of those decisions the moment you set eyes on it.  Should I bunnyhop towards it or not? Should I shoot the crystal to destroy the tower or focus on the swarms.  Should I try and kill the larger skull it spawned that's leaving me alone at this moment?

And every enemy just starts piling these choices on.

More and more.

Faster and faster.

It's the risk/reward of Galaga with the graphics of what Quake wanted to be.  

If you like arcade games:  GET THIS.


P.S.  The ability to download and watch the replay of anyone above you on the leaderboard makes improvement much easier.  Great feature.

21311793.review:
[h1] A Hell of a Good Time [/h1]

[i]Devil Daggers[/i] is an intense Arena Shooter that pits you against endless hordes of nightmarish abominations and I love it. I just bought this game on a whim and I'm happy to say that I've become completely enthralled in [i]Devil Daggers'[/i] breakneck shooter gameplay. With the industry's current state of being oversaturated with sponge shooters, [i]Devil Daggers'[/i] would've been heaven-sent if it didn't happen to also be so [b]devilishly impious[/b]. [i]Devil Daggers[/i] is a visual feast to say the least, which is interesting considering my initial reaction of there only being "13 horrifying enemies" as skeptical of the longevity that number would normally imply; but, I'm happy to say that such worries were immediately put to rest when I found myself confronted by the first 4 horrifying demons, as each are beautifully designed while also being HR Giger levels of ghastly. 
I'm not normally one for Arena Shooters, but I was somehow immediately taken by [i]Devil Daggers[/i]. Perhaps it was its $5 price tag, it's unique and nightmarish aesthetics, or its fluid and fine-tuned controls; regardless, I'd say it's certainly worth its price of admission.

21311604.review:
Conquer your demons in this difficult arcade FPS in the style of hexen/quake/serious sam. Shotgun / MG + bunnyhopping + hordes of enemies in a flat arena. One hit and you're dead. Scores are ranked simply by time survived, with viewable replays for all ranks (good for learning and anti-cheat). Graphics are cool downsampled 3d style(looks bad in screenshots but great in motion) and there's excellent atmospheric 3d sound which is very important for positional awareness (use headphones if possible). If you are expecting an oldschool shooter with levels/bosses you'll be disappointed; this is strictly an arcade score-attack game.

A couple things that aren't explained clearly: collecting diamonds will level you up (increased damage, and later unlock homing shots w/ mouse2); You'll attract the diamonds when you aren't shooting, but they stay still when you are. Good luck

21310065.review:
It would have been yet another endless arena shooter if it wasn't for that hell of an artstyle.

The game itself is quite tricky so to speak, as you die in one hit and the enemies tend to be everywhere, so it can take a fair amount of practise to stay alive long enough to see everything it has to offer, but it's damn satisfying when you manage to see that "New High Score" message.

Again, none of that would have worked if it looked boring, but it doesn't look boring. It looks (and plays) like your own personal hell. However, it does have one flaw and that's the sound design. Some noises that the enemies make sound like people trying to imitate airplane and car sounds, which isn't as funny as it sounds when you consider that you are supposed to be fighting demons in an environment that could only be described as "nightmarish".

...Okay I admit it, it was rather funny... but it didn't last!

There isn't much variety honestly, just the same area with the same monsters always located at the same spots. Thing is, you are supposed to keep playing and learn where and when the monsters appear so you will live longer. Blindly adding more variety to that formula would only make the game more annoying.

Also it's just 4.99, which is fine!

Cheaper than a pint, and more fun than a jumping castle, this game is a great way to spend an hour here and there. I like how movement based this game is, with the movement feeling smooth and satisfying, bhops and all. Coming from primarily playing the counter-strike series, and enjoying the movement and bhop side of that, devil daggers feel satisfying to just run and jump around while engaging with enemies. The enemies are designed great, and the sound is amazing. Pushing yourself to master the movment and mechanics is satisfying combined with the mood gained as the game progresses into a more demonic mess the further you get, keeps you coming back for more. Some people complain about this game not having levels, and being too basic to warrent playing, to which I think, A) It's not meant to be that type of game, but more importantly B) This game is more about the movement, mechanics, mood, aesthetics, and skill-testing. No levels are needed for that. And for it's price, this game is definately worth playing. It's good fun!

21308785.review:
TL;DR Game is hard but not engaging. It feels nothing like Doom/Quake - the ONLY weapon you get is boring to use, there isn't a proper level to run through (just a wide open room), and the beginning enemies are so monotonous that you won't feel a drive to even excel at the game. If you want a hard FPS throwback game with a bit of roguelite, I'd recommend [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/308420/]Ziggurat[/url], [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/266110/]Tower of Guns[/url], [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/250580]Paranautical Activity[/url] or just go to the source and get Doom and Quake.

Devil Daggers might claim to be inspired by 1990s FPS games, but make no mistake: this is nothing like Doom or Quake. 

You're dropped onto a wide open circle of ground and enemies spawn randomly on the edge, spewing tons of flying skulls when they do. If you get hit once, you die. There is nowhere to hide and the area is dark so some enemies will be hidden in that darkness. In Doom/Quake, a lot of the gunplay came from moving quickly through cooridors, finding secrets, ducking in and out of doorway cover and being surprised by a monster closet opening behind you. This game only spawns monsters around you with very little fanfare, and you'll spend most of your time simply bunny hopping and circle strafing. That's it. This might be a fluid movement system but it does not supply an enjoyable nor interesting space to use it in.

The difficulty is very high, as you'd expect. I can appreciate one-hit difficulty, but frequently you'll die because something spawned behind you without much or any warning, or one lone skull did a Tokyo drift and nipped your ankle, or something else altogether. The game won't give you feedback about WHY you died. Probably a lone enemy snuck up on you? Who knows. There are tons of floating skulls everywhere but it simply isn't fun or interesting to fight them or die to them. In the end, the game killing you doesn't feel frustrating or terribly unfair really - it's just kind of boring. 

The only weapon you get is the devil daggers. If you click mouse-1, you have a weak shotgun attack that is nothing like the boomstick from Doom. It feels like a nerf gun. If you HOLD mouse-1, you get a minigun like weapon that actually does feel good to use.  I don't know why they chose to tie these firing modes to the same button (you can't remap this either!) - it feels clumsy to use and it often will not work at all, simply giving you a one shot from the minigun instead of the shotgun. Combining the weakness of the shotgun shot with the unreliability of the controls, I'm not sure why you'd bother to use it. Apparently the game gives you homing daggers for mouse-2 at SOME point, but I honestly never played enough to get there before I got extremely bored.

Normally in difficult games, you'll have a desire to get better at the game, to learn from your mistakes, and last a bit longer next time. I didn't have that feeling in this game. The gun (dagger?) play felt so dull that I just accepted each death and tried again. 45 minutes later, I felt like I only got marginally better but had no desire to try again. There are 10 more enemy types that I never got to see, but I simply don't care enough to play longer to get to that content. I also never got any double jump, nor homing daggers, or any upgrade. 

Finally, you can watch replays of the top scores on the leaderboards, so you can watch people who have mastery over the game play. It's a lot of circle strafing and holding mouse-1. Not the most riveting gameplay to watch, but you can appriciate how good these people are at the game. I'm just not sure why they feel driven to achieve that mastery when it just doesn't seem interesting to get there. There are better, deeper games out there that fill this niche.

21303274.review:
Great simple game!
Stylized like the golden age of unrealistic FPS with truly virtuous sound, Devil Daggers is a short and sweet game. Pick it up when you have 3 minutes to kill. Well maybe a bit more since it seems to take quite a while to load up. But once done, you get thrown right in the action. Move around with WASD, look around with mouse, hold LMB to fire a continuous stream of "daggers" and tap LMB to shotgun more "daggers".

Easy to understand your only objective is to survive as long as possible with the constant demon barrage and that's it! You get a leaderboard that shows the best players in the world as well as your friends to brag around.

My only complain is the minimalist options available. You can only decide mouse sensitivity, volume level and if you are left handed or not. I wish there would be an option for resolution as to me it appeared as a good old 800x600 scaled up to my monitor. At least it ran a constant 120 FPS no matter how many hundreds of demons were sprawling around my screen.
